reviewText: A rare phenomenon has happened in the movie theater tonight!I witnessed a sold-out audience applauding the screen quite hardily at the conclusion of this new film version of "Les Miserables".I recommend this film to mature audience members only. The rating of PG-13 is okay but I must warn that this is a serious adult story about two men who start out hating one another, and one of them finding it in his heart to forgive. This story is a tragedy. This is not a kids movie. It contains many scenes of cruelty, strife, war, death, and blood. There are a few scenes containing sexual situations.This film is a true musical. That means the singing is non-stop throughout it's entire running time of 157 minutes.There is a bit of spoken dialog here and there. But not much. Mostly all dialog is delivered with song.For younger people this type of musical may be tiresome and boring. It may be a challenge for them to stay interested and have enough patience to see it through. If they could it would be good for them.Director Tom Hooper has commanded top-notch acting from his cast. Character delivery by each and every one of this films actors and actresses is excellent. Claude-Michel Schonberg's score bring substance and weight to this beautiful film. I'm thrilled to see the very talented, Russel Crowe playing the part of the morally confused "Javert". He's fantastic! I thoroughly enjoyed his acting, singing voice, and every single scene he was in. Hugh Jackman is excellent as mentally tortured "Jean Valjean". He masterfully carries this films story-line with presence, a powerful singing voice and mesmerizing skillful acting. Anne Hathaway's heart-wrenching singing and acting delivery as the ill-fated "Fantine" will most likely be remembered for a very long time to come. I'm sure her skillfully amazing performance will earn her a 'Best Actress' Oscar nomination and possibly a win at this years upcoming Academy Awards. I must also mention the lovely British actress Samantha Barks who's acting and vocal delivery as tragic heroine Eponine was fabulous! Her Oscar worthy death scene was one of the most breathtakingly beautiful scenes in this film.It was an unexpected pleasure and surprise to see award nominated and award winning stage singer and actor, Colm Wilkinson in this film. Look for him playing the part of the "Bishop". He acted and sang in the starring role of "Jean Valjean" on Broadway in the musical stage production version of "Les Miserables" for many years.The pacing was excellent in this film. I believe many, if not all categories for the creation of this film will be nominated for awards. The attention to detail in this film is excellent! The Costumes, Art, Set Direction and Decoration are all superb. Special-effects, lighting and sound are impeccable. Make-up is amazing and worthy of nomination's as well. This film is very good and deserves many accolades.I recommend this film but warn that you may want to bring many tissues with you into the theater. This film will make you cry. It was is a pleasure to watch. Enjoy!Update: Golden Globe winner-Best Picture, Best Actor-Hugh Jackman, Best Supporting Actress-Anne Hathaway.Academy Award Nominations: Best Picture, Best Actor-Hugh Jackman, Best Supporting Actress-Anne Hathaway, Best Production Direction, Best Make-up, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Costume Design.Update: Winner of three Academy Awards. They are...Best Supporting Actress-Anne Hathaway, Best Make-up, Best Sound Mixing.Release date: 25 December 2012Running time: 157 minutesRating: PG 13 ~ for violence, sexual content and language.Drama/Musical/RomanceGrade: B+
summary: Phenomenal stage musical empresses on the silver screen!

reviewText: If I could sum up the pitch for this movie, it would go something like, "I'm going to film Les Mis, the actors are going to sing live, and I'm going to do lots of extreme close-ups of them singing."  The first two work pretty well for the actors in the movie who actually know how to sing.  For the rest (I'm looking at you Russel Crowe), I'm wondering what kind of ego you must have to think this was a good idea to put yourself in a musical.  Russel Crowe, you can't sing well enough to play Javert.  End of story.  I loved you in Gladiator, but this was not for you.  Regarding the close-ups, my God, I don't need to see the saliva in the actors mouths.  I'm pretty sure I could see the stale bread lodged in Hugh Jackman's molars.
summary: I loved Les Mis...on the stage

reviewText: **WARNING: This review may get rather long. I have a ton of thoughts about this movie, after seeing the stage show so many times. So this may just be me rambling. Also...SPOILERS! SPOILERS! SPOILERS! EVERYWHERE!My review for the higlights CD was less than glowing. However, I can say happily that the CD is a very, very, very, very poor reflection of the movie itself. Ignore the highlights CD. Forget about it. It doesn't do this movie justice. Because while it's far from perfect, I'm can happily say that it is the Les Mis movie musical.THE ACTINGHUGH JACKMAN (Jean Valjean)--8/10 Aside from Russell Crowe, Hugh Jackman's been getting quite a bit of flack for his Valjean. To be honest, I don't see it. Acting-wise, Jackman is awesome and embodies Valjean. I agree with those who have said he carries the movie. However, singing-wise he was occasionally lacking. He had a habit of speak-singing a LOT. As many have said, his "Bring Him Home" wasn't exactly stellar and was somewhat disappointing (but not terrible.) So, Hugh Jackman makes for a really good Valjean, with a few vocal flaws that make him a little less than perfect.RUSSELL CROWE (Javert)--7/10 Perhaps the most controversial member of the cast! Personally, I don't think he was that awful. Was he the best Javert ever? No. Do I feel they could have gotten someone better? Yes. However, his voice really isn't that bad. It's off-putting at first, but you get used to it, and once you do, he's decent. His acting made up for his singing. What makes his Javert nice is his more subtle moments (there were little moments in Fantine's arrest and the barricade scenes I really liked.) So, he really isn't that bad. By no means is he amazing, but he's not godawful.ANNE HATHAWAY (Fantine)--9/10 Methinks she was born to play Fantine. First of all, holy CRAP, does Hathaway have pipes. I had no idea she could sing like that. Her Fantine is much more fragile than Fantines in the stage productions I've seen (which makes sense.) She's not a belty Fantine. But although her voice isn't Broadway powerful, you can hear the vocal power underlying in her voice. Her acting is amazing. If she doesn't break your heart, you have no soul. (Her delivery of "Come, Cosette. My child, where did you go?" Ahhh! Tears!)SACHA BARON COHEN AND HELENA BONHAM CARTER (Thenardier and Mme. Thenardier)-- 6/10 They were fine as the Thenardiers. I didn't feel they were anything spectacular, but they weren't bad. Their "Master of the House" felt a bit off for me. On one hand, it was much toned down for the stage version, but at the same time, it still felt to gaudy for this movie (although this may have to do more with direction than the actors themselves.) So, like I said, fine, serviceable, but nothing truly special.AMANDA SEYFRIED (Cosette)--5/10 Yeah, she just didn't work for me. Personally, I thought she was worse that Crowe. While I definitely think she has the looks to play Cosette (and her costumes were awesome), she doesn't have a very strong voice. It was shrill and her vibrata was insane. I will say though, she was rather heartbrekaing in the epilogue at Valjean's death.EDDIE REDMAYNE (Marius)--9/10 Like Anne Hathaway, Eddie Redmayne appears to have been born to play Marius. He's got an AMAZING voice, he's attractive (at least, I think so). He also seems to give more depth to Marius's character. His acting, his facial expressions, all add so much more to Marius. His "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables" was just...there are no words. I will say that his "jawbrato" got a little distracting. There's nothing really wrong with this, per se, and it may have been more distracting because of all the close-ups. But, hey, I can deal with the jawbrato because Eddie Redmayne is perfection personified.SAMANTHA BARKS (Eponine)--9/10 Vocally, she's awesome. Her voice is more toned down from her theatre days, but it's still amazing. She plays a more fragile Eponine, who's not the more street-smart, tough Eponine we see in a lot of stage productions. This isn't to say she's weak. Her Eponine has some fight in her, she's just more subtle. Her part seemed quite reduced though, which isn't really her fault, of course. It just would have been nice to see her more.AARON TVEIT (Enjolras)--9/10 Like Samantha Barks, Tveit plays a more subdued version of his character. When I first listened to the recording, I was a tad off-put by how...weak Enjolras seemed. I'VE NEVER BEEN MORE WRONG IN MY LIFE! Aaron Tveit has an awesome voice and has a commanding prescence as Enjolras. You almost want more screen time from him.ISABELLE ALLEN and DANIEL HUTTLESTONE (Young Cosette and Gavroche, respectively)--8/10 I was surprisingly impressed with both. Usually, young Cosette and Gavroche are played by terrible singers. But both were freaking adorable. I loved Isabelle Allen, so adorable. Daniel Huttlestone made for a good Gavroche, with plenty of spunk and pluckyness. However, his accent felt a bit forced. (Or maybe it's real. I don't know, I was sort of hoping they'd get rid of the Cockney-accent-straight-from-Oliver-Twist Gavroche and just make him sound like veryone else.)THOUGHTS ON THE CUTS/ADDITIONS/LYRIC CHANGESBeing a fan of the musical, I know the libretto pretty well. So I was interested to see what cuts/changes/additions would be made. There were a few changes/cuts I really didn't like. These include:*CUTS FROM "ON MY OWN" AND "A LITTLE FALL OF RAIN": Probably due to time. I'm not completely anguished over these cuts (since, if we're being totally honest, Eponine's not the most important character in the first place). But it would have been nice to see Samantha Barks a little more.*CUTS FROM FANTINE'S ARREST: The part that suffers most is the fight between Fantine and Bamatabois. It goes from "Here's something new...the usual price for just one slice of your pie" to "No, no, m'sieur..." to "You've got some nerve..." and then Fantine attacks him. A lot of the lines were cut, including Fantine's "I'll kill you, you bastard, try any of that!" Again, not to broken up about these cuts, as it helped with time (and I feel like the "I'll kill you" would have seemed a bit awkward coming from a very weak looking Fantine.) However,e the cuts made the fight seem much, much shorter and if you blink, you might miss all of it. ;)*CUTS FROM "DRINK WITH ME": This is the last song the students sing together and it has some really good lines in it (Grantaire's verse, especially.) But a lot of it was cut, which was unfortunate, since it was a really good song. It's still there, just not the whole thing.*CUTS FROM "EVERY DAY": I don't know why they cut Marius's "Every day, I wonder who it was that brought me from the barricade" as it makes it appear Marius all ready knows who saves him, which then makes Thenardier's whole thing at the wedding seem rather odd. So a little plot hole there.*CUTS FROM "THE CONFRONTATION": Valjean loses a chunk during the Valjean/Javert harmony, so it's just Javert singing, "I was born inside a jail..." They also cut everything from "And this I swear to you tonight" on, which made me sad, especially since it sounded like it was going to be very sad in the script. (Valjean was scripted to be singing to Fantine's dead body as it is flung into a wagon to be buried in the cemetery.)*CUTS FROM "THE ATTACK ON RUE PLUMET": This cut annoyed me the most. It just seemed so jumpy! Not to mention it sort of creates a little bit of a plot hole. It jumps from Eponine screaming to Valjean hearing it, instantly assuming it's Javert, and deciding to pack up. That's it. He doesn't even interact with Cosette, whose lines there sort of finalize his decision to leave. In the movie, it makes it look like Valjean is just leaving because he heard Cosette scream at who knows what.The cut I did like was reducing the length of "Turning." It's always been such a filler song to come before "Empty Chairs." (And it was only written so the women ensemble had more to do than be prostitutes.) So, it was nice to see most of that gone.And, I know some of you will stone me for saying this, but I didn't mind that "Dog Eats Dog" was cut. For one, it really would have slogged the movie's pacing at that point. The way the movie sets it up, you're invested in Marius and Valjean. You probably don't want to hear about Thenardier robbing corpses. So it helped tighten up the pacing. Also, the sewers in the movie are NASTY, so I don't really think I would want to see Thenardier singing a three minute solo in poop.I did like the additional interactions between Valjean and Javert in Montreuil-sur-Mer. It added more depth to Javert's character (like when he asks to be relieved of his position.) Also, these new additions gave us more reason as to why Valjean just sort of turned his back on Fantine at the factory. So, I liked the added lyrics.As for lyric changes, most of them I didn't like. For example:"And the plague is coming on fast, ready to kill!" Why did that need to be changed? "Winter" was fine. In fact, it made more sense when the lyrics earlier were "At the end of the day you're another day colder and the shirt on your back doesn't keep out the chill." "Plague" just sounded sort of silly. This is the 1820s, not the Dark Ages."Follow to the letter your itinerary! This badge of shame you wear until you die." The lines just felt awkward. The other lyrics in the stage version were fine, although I did like the "It warns you're a dangerous man" in the movie.The lyric change I have mixed feelings for is; "It's a story of one who turned form hating. A man who only learned to love when you were in his keeping." I actually like this line a lot, as I think it's just something really sweet for Valjean to say to Cosette. However, the original lines from the stage musicl are, "It's a story of those who always loved you. Your mother gave her life for you, then gave you to my keeping." It's a sort of pivotal, if you will, scene in the musical (and book) where Cosette finally learns of her mother, so it was disappointing to see that cut.And the lyric change I love is "Would you weep, Cosette, if I were to fall?" Not because it's anything stellar or beautiful, but it makes so much more sense. In the musical is, "Would you weep, Cosette, should Marius fall?" It sounds really dumb. I mean, why is Marius talking in third person about himself anyway?THOUGHTS ON THE SONGS/HOW THEY WERE DONEFor the most part, I liked the way everything transitioned to the screen. The new placements of "I Dreamed a Dream" and "Stars" work so much better, in my opinion. IDAD is that much more tragic. Stars makes more sense there, as he's just lost Valjean, and in the stage play, I feel like "Stars" coming between "Look Down" and "Red and Black" sort of interrupts the flow. However, I have mixed feelings for "On My Own" getting moved. It makes sense as it probably would have been awkward during the barricade scenes. It would have changed the mood midway through. However, I feel like "On My Own" being right before "A Little Fall of Rain" works much better, as we've been with Eponine longer and she's finalyl letting it all out. Earlier, we feel pity for her, but not as much. Not to mention that in the new movie placement, it's right after the Rue Plumet robbery, where Valjean decides to leave for England, which is a pretty big moment and then...oh, we're listening to Eponine talk about her love life. Mmkay.I liked how a lot of the songs looked in the movie."Lovely Ladies" looked sort of like something out of a horror movie, but I think it helped emphasize the sort of hell the prostitutes are living in. It was very toned down and sort of sexless (or at least as sexless as a song about prostitutes can be), which I like a lot. I feel as though "Lovely Ladies" should focus more on Fantine's fall and the horrible life the prostitues live, as opposed to being overly raunchy and gaudy, like it is in the stage production, for the purpose of just being raunchy."Come to Me" was beautifully tragic, with Fantine hallucinating of Cosette. *weeps over keyboard*"The Confrontation" looked way more epic on screen. It's a cool song in the musical, but it can sometimes be ruined by the cheesy stage fighting. Here, it looks awesome. Javert has a sword! Valjean has a...stick of wood he ripped off a wall! Valjean makes his escape by jumping out of a door into a river! Yay! Cool!"Chain Gang/Work Song" looked awesome, with the men pulling in the giant ship. Much better than the staging of "mime tools."Loved how the finale turned out, when Valjean died. The church, the bishop, ahh! Beautiful!Anyway, to sum this rambling review up, Les Miserables is a semi-flawed, but overall excellent adaptation of the musical that should please most fans.

reviewText: I saw this movie a week before it came out because I won advance screening tickets and I have known the song I Dreamed A Dream my whole life but I have never seen the musical on stage or any of the adaptations before. I went into this with no expectations at all. At first I thought the movie started off kind of fragmented and I figured because it had to introduce everybody and I was right. The film ended up as it went on drawing me in more and more and making me fall in love with it and by the end i was mesmerized with how wonderful and amazing the movie is. I believe they picked perfect roles because after i saw the movie i listened to the broadway soundtrack and i believe they did very well on picking out the cast for their vocal ranges and capabilities. I think anyone who loves the musical or is a musical person should definatly see this movie because they will not be disappointed one bit by how amazing it is.

reviewText: *** Not For Family Night, too much skin is shown!  Also not for anyone who is under age - it's very graphic in it's adult content. ***Over all, yes, I give it 5 stars - they put alot of heart and soul into this movie and it shows.Our family holds "Les Miserables" high in our estimation and even have the Focus On The Family Radio Theatre Audio Drama of it.Reasons I would not watch this 2012 Movie Version again:1. It may be accurate for the time in history...However, We felt that the *low necklines, *bare bottoms and *sensuousness where a bit too much and over the top.2. The Thénardier family has a lot to do with objectionable content found in the movie.  They almost made me want to quit watching the movie completely, but I forced myself to wait for a better part to come along.3. Not Enough DialogEverything was a song - yes, it's a musical, but a lot of the excellent dialog was left out.  It is a beautiful story that deserved more talking.For these reasons, I will not be buying the DVD.

reviewText: 2012 Les Miserables is one of the best movie adaption musical I saw in recent year! It was NOT my favorite on-stage (saw it in London with bad seating, and I fell asleep!), but this version managed to attract my attention throughout!Hugh Jackman was outstanding, Russell Crowe did his job. All the young actors were great, including Amanda Seyfried!Of course, Anne Hathaway performance was worthy of her Oscar win, though she died just half an hour into the movie! Her version of I Dreamed A Dream was one long take, NO CUT! She was great - both singing and acting!Properly framed at 1.85 with DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1, this Region A Universal released come with sufficient Bonus Features and DVD copy! Image is sharp and sounds great!At 2 hours 38 minutes, it is a long movie! Be prepare!Highly recommended!
summary: Outstanding musical adaption, with great performance1

reviewText: Based on some of the poor reviews, I didn't expect much from this. I was wrong to be so pessimistic. Aside from casting Russell Crowe, a big mistake, the other casting choices were great. Performances were strong. I understood the story before from having seen the show on Broadway, but I understood it much better after the film. Film was able to give some intimate shots that live theater doesn't do nearly so well, at least in my opinion.Any show that makes me choke up and even cry several times during the space of nearly three hours gets a thumbs up from me. Drop the comparisons to live theater and see this for what it is: a great story told by great actors (Anne Hathaway was amazing, Hugh Jackman was simply terrific) with wonderful music. I've watched it twice and loved it both times.

reviewText: The story is so strong, the emotions are aroused.  I cannot give it anything less than the best.  At the end, my spirit soared and the tears fell.'Tis true, Anne Hathaway's Fantine is weak from the start, but Hathaway earns her awards with her amazing performance of "I Dreamed a Dream."Hugh Jackman's performance was beyond words.  He hit the notes he had to hit to have credibility and gave a performance of a lifetime.  He was Valjean.Samantha Barks as Eponine is again the heroine of the story.  Truly.Isabelle Allen as the young Cosette was extraordinary.  The best I have seen.  Amanda Seyfried as the older Cosette was acceptable.  Her singing was strong at the start, but faded into mis-hit notes during critical musical passages.  Her over-blown pupils, worse, were distracting.  I understand that they wanted her to look wide-eyed and innocent, but those pupils were so large that she just came out looking stoned.Marius was miscast.  The bloke who makes fun of him falling in love should have been Marius.  Sorry Eddie.Poor Russell Crowe.  Arguably a great actor who floundered because of the music.  He didn't sing horribly--he actually sang quite well, but his focus on trying to sing well killed all the emotion Javert has to have.I was determined not to like this Gavroche as I preferred some of the chubbier ones on Broadway and in London, but this little guy sang so well and charmed me right in.The ensemble's performance was divine!Somehow, someway, the cast overcame the mis-steps and made me cry in the end.
summary: It brought me to tears -- completely against my will.

reviewText: A lot of diehard fans of the original Broadway musical were awfully skeptical about the actors' singing and cinematic interpretations of a musical they have loved and adored for years. And I was one of those same fans. However, let me put this to rest right now. The film version is just as good as the Broadway musical. There are pros and cons to the cinematic version. One pro is also a con in that the singers can really emote better with their voices and faces, making the film seem more real; however, their voices sometimes go a bit too soft -- although it is a very minor occurrence. Another con is Russell Crowe's singing voice as Inspector Javert. Now, I know his songs are extremely difficult to sing, and Crowe does have a singing background, but his voice just didn't "wow" me like the others did. Still, he did OK. Samantha Barks as Eponine (one of my favorite characters) was fantastic and really honed the character she'd been playing since 2010 at Westminster's Queen's Theatre. Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter as the villainous Thenardiers did OK, but they just couldn't hold a candle to Alun Armstrong and Jenny Galloway's performances. Hugh Jackman retains his theatrical chops as Jean Valjean and has the power to both sing and heavily emote, making you believe he is the tortured, reformed man of God; also, I loved that director Tom Hooper cast the original (to me) Valjean, Colm Wilkinson, as the Bishop. But the heavy hitter here -- the Academy Award-winning performance -- is that of Anne Hathaway. If you've ever read my blog or heard me talk of her, you know I'm not the biggest fan of hers. Then,The Dark Knight Rises (+Ultraviolet Digital Copy)came out and I had to admit she did pretty well. Now, with that plus this performance, I'm eating crow. She was spectacular. Her performance while singing "I Dreamed a Dream" was the best acting -- and, at the same time, singing -- I've seen in a very long time. There's a moment in the song where she's about to hit a high note and you see her convulsing, almost hyperventilating, and think she won't hit that note. But she does. And the fact that all of the actors sang live on set lets you know that she's got talent. If she doesn't get some kind of major award for this role, then awards will be useless. A great musical and a great movie; director Tom Hooper has a great eye for cinematography and some of the most simple shots in the film come in at the right time and are magnificant to look at. The musical is all here (in the film) in its entirety -- singing and all! (Slight note: the only lines cut in the film is at the beginning of "Beggars at the Feast"; I guess the filmmakers wanted to be more politically correct, so they cut out the verse that contains: "Here comes a prince/There goes a Jew/This one's a queer/But what can you do?") Overall, this is one of the best films of the year as well as one of the best movie musicals ever. Even better, fans, it's all in here -- all of the music and sing-talking, as well as the underlying message of how our actions can touch and affect others -- "to love another person is to see the face of God" and "even the darkest nights will end and the sun will rise." Just make sure you use the restroom before going into the movie ... since it clocks in at just a shade under three hours.
summary: Les Mis is lengthy but VERY much worth it! 4 1/2 Stars!

reviewText: I love 'les mis' and have done since i first saw it on stage when i was 10 years old. I went on to read the novel the details of the characters in that were amazing, really shown in the 10th and 25th anniversary concerts. This movie however struggles on a few fronts.The first, and perhaps most obvious, is Javert. Russel Crowe tried his best but the part was just too difficult for his vocal range. The complexity of Javert comes out in his voice and Crowe is simply unable to do this consistantly, the result being a character that doesn't comes over as well as he could. I'm not saying anything against Crowe's acting ability here or his strength as a singer in general. He is a good singer who simply overreached himself a bit with this particular project (although the live singing probably didn't help him).The second front which the movie struggles on is the music itself. At times in the movie the directors either re-arrange the music, remove it completly or write new stuff. The movie directors seem to think that a ultra successful show that has been seen by millions doesn't know how to tell a story. For people who have not seen the musical before this is not a problem but for those who have it can cause confusion. The biggest changes have got to be the lines removed at the begining to introduce Javert and Valjean (as this is the whole plot of the story).The song 'do you hear the people sing' is also changed (and not for the better), the song should be Enjolras' call to arms but it has become a chorus song that has minimal musical impact. The removal of the song 'turning' also deminishes the impact of the revolution in the movie, making it seem like no-one but Marius is bothered about them.Overall the movie was good and I enjoyed it. The visuals were amasing, although at times they concentarted too much on visuals and not music. The costumes were good and so was the acting, unfortunatly the choice to make the actors sing live (although it made it more emotional) made the singing inconsistant and showed the struggles the actors had reaching and holding notes.This movie is worth watching if you have not watched 'Les Mis' before. If you have then just bare in mind that changes are made and if you are very specific about the musical don't watch it.

reviewText: To say that I was walking into this film with bias eyes may be a correct assumption.  I’ll be honest here, for there is not another movie in the history of film that I have been more excited to see than ‘Les Miserables’.  That isn’t to say that I expected it to be the greatest movie I had ever seen, but in all my years of movie watching, I have never anticipated the release of a film with such rabid obsession as I have with ‘Les Miserables’.  It probably stems back to my childhood and the fact that by the age of twelve I had already seen the stage musical four times and was pretty much obsessed with it as a whole.  Living a hop, skip and a jump away from many of the finest theaters in New England, my family frequented the theater.  I still remember the first time I saw ‘Les Miserables’.  I was seven.  It changed me.Musicals are, in my opinion, one of the greatest genres film has to offer.  They deliver to us such depth of storytelling in a way that is unique to its own.  You don’t see people running through the streets communicating in song and yet when it is done with such passion in front of the lens it all makes sense and feels so complete.When the initial reviews for ‘Les Miserables’ started to flood in with largely negative notices, I was nervous.  How could this be a flop?  How could this material get butchered?  Not that it couldn’t, since we’ve all endured the mess that was 1998’s ‘Les Miserables’, but I still had faith that Hooper would do the source material proud.  In all honesty, most of the vicious attacks against the film felt so contrived and calculated that it was almost as if critics were anticipating a failure.  Nathanial Rogers over at The Film Experience noted this same thing.  Whether it be angst against Hooper for stealing Fincher’s Oscar (like it was his fault, but I get it sort of) or an aversion to the movie musical itself, it seemed since the start of the year that this particular film had a lot of naysayers before it was even finished being made.Well, Christmas rolled around and I got to see it for myself.I loved this movie!‘Les Miserables’ is not a film for everyone.  It’s funny to leave a theater and hear complaints from people behind me like “did they really have to sing everything” and I’m thinking to myself…IT’S A MUSICAL!  Seriously, if that is your complaint then why bother going to the movies.  I, for one, was thrilled when I heard that this was going to be completely sung throughout.  ‘Les Miserables’ has some of the most beautiful songs and composed music that it deserves a faithful adaptation.  Hooper’s triumph is about as close as you can come.  Of course, no film is perfect and I am not blind to certain imperfections, but overall I was extremely pleased with this film and consider it a marvelous representation of what a true movie musical should and could be.What Hooper and company get right here is the tone of ‘Les Miserables’.  This film is about the depths of despair but also the rising power of hope that come blossom from redemption.  Jean Valjean, a man swallowed up by his past mistakes (and the looming oppression of injustice) is attempting to right his wrongs and turn his life around.  Being spared a life of slavery by the kind gesture of a Bishop, Valjean breaks his parole in pursuit of a life without chains and makes himself over as a wealthy mayor and business man.  There are two people in his life that cause unexpected friction and set his life spiraling into a different direction.  First is Fantine, a young woman trying to provide for her illegitimate child.  The second is Javert, the ruthless general who is in feverish pursuit of Jean Valjean.  As the years pass by Valjean’s guard is constantly up as he fights to evade Javert’s clutches, all the while taking on a new responsibility that opens his heart and teaches him the importance of love; something that has be choked out of his soul thanks to the heartless realities of life.For the fan of the source, Hooper’s film is going to make you smile.  I wept.  My parents wept.  In fact, the majority of the theater wept, and this is only the third time in my life when the theater broke into applause during the credits.  ‘Les Miserables’ is an emotional wonderment and a film that will break you down.  The performances by the entire cast are wonderful, with Anne Hathaway delivering one of the finest supporting performance of the past several decades (her take on ‘I Dreamed a Dream’ may be one of the finest cinematic moments, ever) and Eddie Redmayne completely taking me by surprise with the amount of depth and heart he brought to what could have been an easily dismissive role (loverboy).The pacing is also pretty spectacular.  The film just glides from one number to the next.  It certainly doesn't feel like a nearly three hour movie.  We are constantly drawn into each scene, not one feeling unnecessary.  This is a feat in itself, considering that this is a film consisting entirely of song and score and a lot of the score is redundant (and yet it is so beautifully composed that one never tires of hearing it).Some have balked at the vocals of some of the cast, in particular Russell Crowe.  To them I say this; film and theater are two very different things.  When one goes to the theater, they expect to hear voices that cause their hair to stand on end.  You are watching actors who are trained to sing to the cheap seats so-to-speak.  It is part of the experience.  Film is a different animal.  If this film were spoken word, you would expect the actors to dig deep.  You’d expect to hear their voices crack and their breath give out; why would you expect any less from a song?  It is very obvious that Hooper was going for a more realistic approach, a more earthy and grounded take on the musical.  Instead of expecting vocal perfection from his cast, Hooper wanted to unearth their emotional response to the story.  I mean, Hathaway goes as far as to suck snot up her nose as she belts out her big number, and it works.  Crowe, while not capable of hitting the big notes, has a very pleasant tone to his voice and handles himself quite well here.Yes, there are faults.  Hooper’s obsession with closeups is a bit overwhelming.  The film is so beautiful, from the costumes to the set pieces, that it is such a shame that for the most part ‘Les Miserables’ basically shifts from one person’s face to another’s.  I understand it to a degree, since watching Hathaway crumble during ‘I Dreamed a Dream’ in one take with no cuts and no makeup and full on pain works wonderfully, but it does become somewhat claustrophobic after a while.  It’s baffling to me that Hooper wouldn’t want to expand his view a bit and let us take in the vastness of the cityscape, especially since he did so quite effectively in ‘The King’s Speech’.This, and ‘Bring Him Home’ is a terrible mess.At the end of the day, I loved this.  My parents even noted to me that it was better than the stage musical.  I don’t agree to that degree.  There are few things that can rival the power of this story told on the stage, but I feel that Tom Hooper and company captured it to the best of their ability.  I feel pretty confident that if the cinematography weren’t so monotonous (the dutch angles at least added some flamboyance to otherwise boring camera work) this film would be the clear frontrunner for the Oscar.

reviewText: This is one of those movies that captures the essence, adds the familiarity of the songs, and honors the story of the play and converts it into a movie. The movie should be judged as a separate entity. Those faithful to the Broadway Musical will absolutely have mixed feelings about this. I am not sure about the DVD, but the Blu-Ray has a Singing Live special feature and talks about how the cast sang live, and it also explains the differences between the play and the movie. Anne Hathaway described it best when she said " I can't sing this pretty." And she said it not to say she can't sing but instead it was an issue of believability. You just witnessed all the things Fantine had to go through and you can't believe that after all that this song would be sung pretty. I had never heard I dreamed a Dream sung that way before and it gave me a whole new feeling to a story thatI thought I knew pretty well. And It wasn't just Anne. All the cast really made this film extraordinary. Also in that same documentary, the actors could choose how to act and sing, and Eddie Raymond made a good point about how usually you pre record the music and then lip sync to it and the problem with that is you need to make acting choices months before meeting the cast, crew and sets, which doesn't necessarily match up when you are actually acting and engaging with the elements. The actors actually acted and did not just go through the emotions and lip sync to prerecorded material. At the last part of this behind the scenes, they show how the director and the conductor directed the orchestra in changing the way the music is played to fit the emotions and singing methods of the actors, and the songwriter for the broadway version was there to listen and give feedback, so they really covered all their bases. It was truly some of the best 10-20 minutes of behind the scenes footage I ever watched. As for Russell Crowe, because he is probably the most criticized, he is growing on me the more I watch this. Stars is my favorite song from the men, and it was a little rough the first time I heard it, but I have to say watching the movie over and over again, he seems to get better sounding to me, and he is a lot stronger by the time Javert's Suicide came on. His presence fit as Javert, afterall he was the Gladiator, but vocally I wish he was stronger, especially pitting him against Hugh Jackman who is vocally trained.In conclusion I absolutely love this movie and it should be judged separate from the play, and the actors really made the songs their own, which added a different dimension to the story and it's characters. 5 STARS TODAY AND ALWAYS!
summary: A True Combination Of Broadway and Hollywood

reviewText: Okay reader, I'm going to tell you a little bit about what I thought about Les Miserables (2012), and will try to keep it shorter then the book was. Now, right off the bat I'm going to tell you that I LOVED Les Miserables, saw it twice, and that it's on my top 10 list of great films of 2012.So below I'm going to first tell you the stuff that was AWESOME in Les Mis, and then I'll go through some of the negative bits, because, although amazing, Les Mis is far from perfect.Shall we begin?1. WHO DOESN'T LIKE HUGH JACKMAN?Let's talk about the cast a little bit. First of all, Hugh Jackman is worthy of any and all praise you can throw his way. He plays a meaty role that almost singlehandedly carries a huge film with so much hype that even the hype was hyped, and does so with emotion and aplomb. Look for his standout moments in "What Have I Done" and "One Day More" and "Bring Him Home". His character development, especially his change from resentful convict to kind and just mayor, is handled with utmost skill, and I especially loved the evolution of his relationship with Crowe's Javert. Watching the two Aussie actors go head to head as in "The Confrontation" is riveting stuff.I'll talk a little about Crowe below, but I think he deserves a second mention. Say what you want about his singing (I loved it), but you can't deny he looks the part. Broad, tall, and intimidating, Javert IS. The. Law. Crowe perfectly embodies Javert's years of bottled-up vengeance, hatred, rigid adherence to rules, and unshakeable (albeit misplaced) honour.And I suppose Anne Hathaway deserves a LOT of mentioning. I mean, she won an Oscar - a well-deserved, hard earned Oscar! Just look at her heartbreaking rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream" - in my opinion the best ever. Talk about method acting, Hathaway lost a lot of weight for her role, and had her hair shorn off onscreen. But it is completely worth it; her Fantine steals the scenes and is long in the audience's minds after she exits the film in the second quarter. If "I Dreamed a Dream" doesn't move you close to tears, you have a heart of ice.A few notes on the supporting cast:Amanda Seyfried: Didn't really work. Her portrayal came of as whiny and pampered. I mean, falling in love with a guy after seeing him for 10 seconds? Who does that? But her harmony in "A Heart Full of Love" was beautiful.Eddie Redmayne: Contender for best voice in the film? Best Marius I've ever seen, and he sure beat Nic Jonas in the 25th Anniversary Musical Production! Redmayne's stunning performance of "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables" is perhaps the second best solo performance in the film, after Hathaway.Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen: As Monsieur and Madame Thenardier, Bonham Carter and Cohen provide most of the comic relief. They're entertaining, I'll give them that much, but do they ever go away?Aaron Tveit: When you're done throwing praise at Hugh Jackman, throw the rest to Aaron Tveit - he deserves it! His fiery young revolutionary Enjolras steals. the. SCENES. "The ABC Cafe - Red and Black" is my favourite song in the film. It's entertaining, catchy, and perfectly sung! And his death scene is one of the most poignant and rousing scenes in the film. Stellar work, Aaron!Samantha Barks: And last, but by no means least, Samantha Barks was a perfect Eponine. She lived an almost absurdly sad life, but Barks (who played the character on stage before) sang beautifully, almost angelically. Her heartbreaking performance of "On My Own" is emotional and memorable. A most underrated actress!Extra callouts go to the little kids who played Gavroche and Cosette, and to Colm Wilkinson (The Bishop of D) - one of the first Valjeans in the musical.2. LES COSTUMES, LES DECORS, ET LA CINEMATOGRAPHIESum up what Les Miserables LOOKS like in 3 words: Grey. Bleak. Dirty. Take Anne Hathaway for instance; one minute clean and neat, the next dirty, caked in dirt, and in sore need of a bath. Take Hugh Jackman, crawling through the sewers. If your stomach didn't roil as he slogs through 5 and a half feet of sewage, you're a stronger man then me.And that's precisely where Les Miserables succeeds: in the costume department, in the makeup department, in the cinematography department. One critic mentioned that it took a lot of hard work to make Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway look so ugly. It takes an equal amount of hard work to make 50 extras look like 18th Century French gutter rats. It takes an equal amount of hard work to transform a concrete warehouse into the streets of Paris. It takes an equal amount of to make a film look so real, so dirty, so accurate. It takes an equal amount of work to design, sew, and age army uniforms for 50 extras.So lets give a big round of applause to the unsung heroes of cinema - the makeup artists, the set decorators, the costume designers, and the cinematographers!3. CAN YOU HEAR THE PEOPLE SING?Now here's something I've wanted to do for a long time: Rank the excellent songs in Les Miserables. So here you have it: the 10 best songs in Les Miserables, according to me:10. The Confrontation - Javert and Valjean sing in counterpoint, and the result is fast-paced and entertaining.9. What Have I Done - A heartfelt, emotional song by Hugh Jackman, with an amazing finish.8. A Heart Full of Love - People, take notes. THIS is how to do a harmony, and the result is nothing short of angelic.7. Javert's Suicide - I don't know what I love more about this song. The fact that Javert dies, or the fact that Crowe gives such an AMAZING performance.6. Do You Hear the People Sing - A patriotic, catchy, inspiring, thundering song that make you want to sing along and shout "Vive la France!"5. Who Am I? / The Trial - I never realized how damn good this song was until I saw Les Mis a second time. It starts slow and contemplative, but the ending - "2-4-6-0-1!" is positively thrilling.4. Empty Chairs at Empty Tables - A sad song, sadly but beautifully sung by Eddie Redmayne. Emotional and haunting.3. Red and Black - A rousing, entertaining, catchy song, sung glouriously by Redmayne, Tveit, and company.2. One Day More - A brilliant, blood-stirring, rousing piece sung by almost everyone in the film. Starts slow, ends with you leaping up and cheering with your fist in the air.1. I Dreamed A Dream - Could it really be anything else? Anne Hathaway gives such a raw, emotional performance; it's beautiful.4. CAN YOU HEAR THE AUDIENCE CRY?In my opinion, Les Miserables - the book, the play, the film - is timeless.Almost everyone in the audience went into Les Mis having read the book, or studied it in school, or watched a film, or seen the musical. They knew what to expect. For months before the film was even released, hype built up to an almost unimaginable level.And yet the beauty and brilliance of the film is that it astounded and moved us once more.And it does move us. It completely and utterly justifies it's name as The Miserables. We accurately (if romantically) see the hardships and trials of living in post-Revolution France. Much of the film is bleak and grey.And yet in the hardship; moments of striking, startling beauty. The moon shining on Javert as he stands at the top of a tower. Candlelight shining on Cosette as she sings in her room. Hundreds of revolutionaries singing on a huge barricade in the sunshine.All this adds up to a very emotional, heavy experience. Many of the audience left teary-eyed. We have Tom Hooper to thank for this. He took a classic tale, and created something new, moving, and astonishing! It's brilliant.And now for the cons. The things that didn't work in Les Miserables:CONS:1. I YAWNED A YAWN AS TIME WENT BY...Les Miserables is undoubtedly too long. Admittedly, Les Miserables the BOOK by Victor Hugo is, when translated, the 14th longest novel in the English language; and clocks in at around the 1,500 page mark.Les Miserables the MOVIE clocks in at just over 2 and a half hours.Now don't get me wrong - I'm a fan of long movies. All my favourite movies are over the 2 1/2 hour mark and some clock in at over 4 hours (The Return of the King, Lawrence of Arabia, Seven Samurai). And compared to the book, Les Mis is like a Sparknotes summary. It's a little over 10 minutes longer then The Avengers, and it's shorter then The Hobbit; yet those two movies keep you riveted till the credits roll!Not Les Miserables. We drag through the doldrums of Valjean's sad sad life, then come to Fantine's sad sad life, then to Cosette's sad sad life, then Eponine's sad sad SAD life, and finally we slog through the sad sad post-climactic wedding and death scenes. It just feels so LONG!The second time I watched it I leaned back in my cinema seat, rolled my eyes back in my sockets, and began to wish that someone - ANYONE - would quit singing and start talking.And that leads me to my next con. (Trust me, this won't go on forever.)2. SING TALKING...Oh my god, where to begin? This is one of those things that really shook my faith in the film, like, to it's roots. I cringed, I gagged, I rolled my eyes, I groaned. It's what I call "Sing talking". The worst scenes in the film are the ones where Valjean and Javert carry out these little conversations in song. They sing their introductions, they sing their insults, they sing their questions...they sing everything, and the worst part?What they sing in 3 seconds could be said in 1. What could have been short and sweet is now long and dreary.And now for my last con:3. RUSSELL CROWEJust kidding. Russell Crowe is not a con. He's awesome. Why is everyone harping on about Russell Crowe? He is the only professional singer among the main cast, the only one to win an Oscar, the only one to play Maximus Decimus Meridius.Any criticism directed at him should actually be aimed at the director, because 1.They make him sing too high, and 2. They only give him two songs in which he can use his signature booming voice.Amanda Seyfried on the other hand...has a really annoying soprano like a Barbie doll. I didn't like her solo performances, but her together with Eddie Redmayne and Samantha Barks = harmony heaven.P.S. Some (just SOME) of the camera work; held up reeaaal close and shaky, in Hooper's signature style does not fit the style or theme of the film. It does capture emotion excellently, though. I also find his overuse of Dutch angles in wide shots somewhat cheap and completely unfitting.CONCLUSION: In conclusion, Les Miserables isn't perfect. It's too long, bombastic, ragged, and features some questionable singing. But you won't care at all. Les Miserables, with it's fine cast and accurate visual style, will move you, sadden you, uplift you, and entertain you.Les Miserables is un triomphe!Vive le Tom Hooper!
summary: Please Consider THIS Review on Les Miserables...

reviewText: This is one of those movies that no matter what someone says about it, they're right.  The concept is interesting and well-worth seeing for fans of the musical.  But, for those who haven't seen the stage musical, this could be one of the longest movies they've ever seen.  The movie is shorter than the musical, and the cuts have made the transitions difficult at times.  And, because things that work with the staging of a musical don't work the same way for movies, there are odd parts that might be flat out annoying for some people.I thought the approach to the music was interesting.  The actors are definitely acting WHILE singing, which gives a new perspective to many of the songs.  If this were my only exposure to "Les Miserables," I think I'd be disappointed.  But I've seen it a few times, so I liked seeing a different adaptation.  But, stage purists may hate this version.The music was mixed.  I had heard so much about Russell Crowe's singing that I was prepared to be appalled, but Russell Crowe CAN sing--he just isn't Broadway material.  He hits all his notes, though I've heard much better versions of the songs.  But I'll bet he's quite good singing pop songs or oldies.  Hugh Jackman is a very talented man, though I'm afraid Colm Wilkinson has so completely set the bar for Jean Valjean for me that no one has ever quite lived up to the original for me.  Still, I enjoyed seeing Jackman's take on the part and he's certainly no slouch.  I thought Anne Hathaway was wonderful as Fantine, though so many of the cuts involved her story that I think her story might be the most confusing part for anyone who hasn't seen the stage version.  I didn't care for Amanda Seyfried's singing, but that's just personal preference.  She's quite talented and certainly others will enjoy her performance.  The only true complaint I had was the Thenardiers.  I love Helena Bonham Carter as an actress, but if one has a well-trained ear, it's obvious she's missing some of her notes.  I'd have much rather seen her in something else as a major character as an actress than a small part in a musical.  As she was also cast in "Sweeney Todd," it seems that her acting ability is strong enough to carry singing parts by Hollywood standards, but at least in dvds one can skip over scenes one doesn't want to watch.I think it's well worth seeing, but some people are definitely going to hate this movie.  Perhaps that's the mark of truly taking a new approach to material--they chose not to take a "safe" route and I think it's worth seeing for that alone.

reviewText: My husband had seen "Les Mis" on Broadway several times and absolutely loved it.  When we met, he introduced me to the music.  Although I enjoyed it, the impact wasn't solidified till he took me to see it on Broadway for my birthday one year.  I was hooked.  When I heard the new movie was being released Christmas Day 2012, we planned to go (since our families were all up north and we were celebrating the holiday alone).  I figured he would be critical of the movie and not enjoy it because of his loyalty to the Broadway presentation.  Not so ... he LOVED it just as much as I did ... plus, I found this movie really connected some confusing pieces of the story for me.  We both just LOVED the movie and have enjoyed having the DVD and being able to watch it over and over now in the comfort of our home.  We were totally in awe of every aspect of this movie presentation.  We feel it represents perfection on every level.

reviewText: Les Miserables is quite simply the best musical made to date.  The casting is superb, the music and orchestral composition is phenomenal, and the set design and acting is top-notch.  I have seen Les Miserables on Broadway three times, and I would EASILY say this is just as good as any of those performances.  With the thrill of seeing a live-performance aside, I would even dare to say it is better!  Can I give any higher praise than that?!  If you have a great surround set-up, then you owe it to yourself and your family to purchase this film.Tom Hooper made one of the most brilliant decisions when directing this film - to have the actors sing each number as they acted, rather than to dub their performances with studio music afterwards.  I CANNOT STRESS how much this impacted the film in a positive way, and I cannot believe other directors have not utilized this in the past.  I was skeptical about having prominent actors such as Hugh Jackman and Russell Crowe cast into such well-known singing roles, but I believe they did an exceptional job.  Russell Crowe's singing may have been the weakest in terms of solo performances, BUT his acting is EXTREMELY powerful for the role.  In the end, I found that I really believed him as Javert and appreciated the fact that he was chosen for the cast.  He serves as a fantastic foil for Jackman's Jean Valjean.If you don't like musicals, then even a stellar film such as this will not change your perception.  But if you do, let me tell you that this is a movie that is powerful beyond words.  The staging, casting, color saturation, cinematography, singing and instrumentation are simply off the charts.  Samantha Barks's rendition of "On My Own" is better than any of the three Broadway shows I have seen, and Eddie Redmayne did a standout job as Marius.  I was moved to tears several times, and felt like giving a standing ovation following the film - and this is from my living room, watching the movie by myself with surround sound.  I am not a sentimental person either.  Wow!  Jeez..I'm still reeling with shock from how fantastic everything was - right up to the final chorus.I urge you to view this movie for yourself, and to see it through from start to finish.  This is not simply another rendition of Les Miserables, it is THE BEST rendition of Les Miserables.  If you are not a believer by the final note, then you may want to consult a local audiologist to test your hearing.  I am so happy I decided to buy this instead of rent, because it is a movie for the ages!"This one goes to 11"/10
summary: As Good as Broadway - The Best Musical Film Ever Made

reviewText: Please take my review with a grain of salt.  I don't understand the appeal of musicals either on stage or on screen.A musical is exactly that- a story that is based entirely around singing and dancing.  The problem usually is that the music is overbearingly pretentious and cringeworthy (but to be fair, not always terrible) and that's what makes Les Miserables a chore to sit through.  It's not bad in the beginning, but about halfway through the music losses its sense of melody and joy and instead feels like a bunch of people showing off by hitting all the high notes for an extended period of time.  It gets on my nerves.  Not a preference of mine.Another problem is that, with Les Miserables in particular, the melodies are really derivative of other sources.  Many of these songs remind me of the rock operas that bands such as Jethro Tull, Queen and the Who had done.  Yes I realize rock and music theater are two separate beasts, but it doesn't change the fact that the vocal melodies themselves are similar.  One melody that Russell Crowe sings near the beginning even sounds exactly like the Bee Gee's "Words".Another problem is that spending a considerable amount of time hitting nothing but high notes makes it near impossible to make out the actual words being sung and as you know, in order to follow a story you need to hear and understand the words.  But... in this case, you can't.  It's not just because of the constant use of high notes either- sometimes the melodies are sung too darn fast, or there's too many people singing at the same time.  Plus there's a strange accent to most of these songs.  Sounds like a fake attempt to sound British.  It's weird.  Either way 60% of the words are hard to understand.  Perhaps grabbing a lyrics sheet would make it easier to follow along.I find it sometimes annoying that *every* *single* *line* has to be sung.  Sometimes I think given the lackluster vocal melodies on a few occasions, that it would have been better to speak instead of sing those lines.  These lackluster parts are obviously included as a way to build into the next segment and theme, but still.  It feels awkward more often than not.For those of you that think this movie version is too violent or inappropriate.  Well, compared to most things on TV these days, not really.  Les Miserables is mild in comparison.  I imagine a general feeling when it comes to musicals is an expectation of good-hearted acting and singing, and that's the main reason people are making a big deal about the few sexual related segments.Les Miserables is still decent.  That's why it gets a 3-star rating.  Other than the above problems, it's adequate enough for musical lovers to feel satisfied with it.

reviewText: Why you shouldn't see it:You probably heard that Les Miserables is a musical. For the uninitiated, in this case, "musical" means nary a line is spoken. All dialog, internal or otherwise, is conveyed to the audience via song (and occasional dance). So if that sort of thing bothers you, I can't imagine that you'll get much of a kick out of this. But really, you've been fairly warned. I may be alone in this, but I think having an entirely musical movie is dangerous territory to tread, because of the difficult balancing act between having catchy tunes and songs that actually advance the plot. It seems like being catchy requires a hook, and most hooks are repetitive, and repetitive things don't really progress. Aside from that, the occasional downside of the musical format is partly inaudible dialog, which in turn stunts the progression of the plot for your mind if you didn't prepare for your film/play-watching by reading the Wikipedia article.Speaking of which, if you do happen to peruse the Wikipedia article, you may surmise that this film is in fact based on a stage musical, which in turn was based on a novel. And not just any novel. A five part, 1500 page, 530,000 word novel that spans nearly 20 years and appears on Wikipedia's list of longest novels, right alongside the likes of War and Peace and Atlas Shrugged. In an industry that typically struggles to compress 150 page novels into two hour movies, I'm wondering what brilliant individual saw this piece that was ten times longer as a two and a half hour trip to the theater.Apologies in advance, as I'm well aware that Les Mis is a wildly popular stage production... I guess the above is more of a gripe with the original musical mind that saw the novel and decided to turn it into a play. From a story standpoint, the heavily downsized movie version seems disjointed to me, with the main culprits being the two times the screen just flashed the words "Nine years later..." How is this all one story? It isn't. It's five stories with common characters. Everything - namely the characters and their relations to one another - just comes across as abrupt when they change.  I'm assuming these transitions are either more gradual or are presented in a manner more sensical in the novel, but in a shortened version, they only confused me. Really, I'm trying to figure out how the play became so popular, and I'm leaning toward the music being the key.While the music may have been the strength for the play, it was fairly hit or miss in the movie. The play had the benefit of being sung by professional singers in a fashion that was very friendly to pretty-sounding performances. In the movie, movie stars were used for the main roles, and the stylistic choices could be boiled down to the fact that the director wanted his actors to act their scenes, not merely sing them. The result is uneven at best, with Amanda Seyfried having a pretty yet limited voice, Russell Crowe having both an awkward and a limited voice, and people like Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen not even really attempting to sing.Why you should see it:This is apparently a highly controversial point, but the main reason I would recommend anyone to see this movie is really just for the moments with Anne Hathaway, and, specifically, her rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream." This was an instance where the director's desire to have his actors act really paid off in my opinion, and I couldn't avoid getting goosebumps when I saw it. Some people will point to other performances of said song as much prettier renditions, but this is a woman in complete despair... Why would she sing beautifully in this moment? Anyway, I thought that one scene alone was fantastic and deserving of Hathaway's Oscar nod (and probable win).Some of the other casting is also well-done, with Hugh Jackman (nominated), Samantha Barks (nominated for other awards) and Eddie Redmayne (nominated for other awards) as obvious examples. Each was able to properly portray their character with appropriate enough musical inclination to also sing their pieces well.Those songs happen to be, as with many things about this movie, hit or miss. Some are fun and catchy, and others appear to be mostly expository and had a harder time sticking with me, a first time viewer/listener. I also understand that the film took quite a few liberties with the original music, editing and remixing it so that it is definitely a different interpretation of the material.Otherwise, the production value for this movie is great. When the opening number started, I got pretty excited about the scale of it all. I'm also pretty fond of the movie poster (shown above), which did a great job at capturing my imagination with Cosette's almost haunting eyes. The strange thing about this big budget, large scale production is that the director spends a lot of time showing the audience very little other than the face of the person who is presently singing.In Short:My main complaint about Les Miserables is actually kind of strange, considering the fact that my favorite movie of the year may very well have been Cloud Atlas, but it seems like simply has too much plot to be boiled down into 2.5 hours. The only real reasons I would consider to be must-see for this particular fare would be if you're either a musical fan not familiar with the original stage production or a super fan who needs all things Les Mis. In light of that, I give it my first take-it-or-leave-it recommendation, and rated it a 6 out of 10 mostly for the efforts of Hathaway and Jackman (on whom I have a slight man crush), and the fact that having exposure to a culturally significant work such as this can do a person some good.Now for the awkward part. Since I gave a middle of the road recommendation, I suppose this portion needs both reasons to see and not to see the movie. Let's give it a shot. Exceptions to the recommendation:- If you would if you could live your life by breaking out into seemingly random song and dance without getting funny looks, see it.- If you're a Francophobe, don't see it.- If you're a Francophile, see it.- I could have those last two backward, since the movie title pretty well lays the groundwork for miserable French people... I guess it depends on how much you love or hate and/or identify with French people. (Random true story: after the movie, I heard one gentleman say to another: "I didn't know it was going to be such a sad movie.")- So if you really hate those cheese eating surrender monkeys and enjoy watching them suffer, reverse the second and third bullet points.- If the idea of all French people having English accents bothers you, don't see it.- If you can appreciate a movie due to one especially powerful scene, see it.- If Russell Crowe singing in one nasally note bothers you, don't see it.- If you just really enjoy large scale productions, see it.- If the idea of a large scale production with an inordinate number of prolonged close ups bothers you, don't see it.- If you like to take in stories by just skipping over large chunks of them and inserting "Nine years later..." exposition, see it.- If you think Anne Hathaway has beautiful hair, don't see it.- If you've somehow seen every other best picture nominee, and this is the only feather missing from your cap, you may as well bite the bullet and see it.

reviewText: I wanted to like this movie, I really did; but the vocals from lead cast members where painful to listen to. The only parts during which I stopped cringing were when the extras sang. While I admire the bravery of non-professional singers recording their lyrics live, I was begging for dubbing within the first five minutes. The female cast members sounded better, but the overall effect was not pleasant. While I also appreciate the realism of popular actors appearing to be visibly ravenged by poor diet and hard lives, the effect in HD is kind of gruesome. Overall, I found the combination of poor vocals with excessively realistic visuals and rapidly changing camera angles (close, far, stable, freehand, even off the actors faces onto random items...) to be a bit much. It was impossible to focus on the story. I hate to admit it, but I only made it about 45 minutes before I had to turn this movie off.

reviewText: I've seen the touring Les Miserables with the Broadway cast, and it's been on PBS, too.  I went to see this movie and was blown away by how much better it was to me. I know that some don't feel that way. But the movie medium is just so much better to show nuances in facial expression, pick up soft voices and whispers, and hear more clearly every word of a song. The Broadway version is made of singers who also act.  This movie version is made of actors who also sing. There's a difference. But there's no mistaking that the actors are also singers. Some people don't know that Hugh Jackman is, in fact, a singer and dancer. Ann Hathaway has a lovely voice and grew up seeing her mother in her role on tour, so Hathaway knows the part by heart. Crowe's voice - He's in a rock band and does sing. But his voice is more of a talking version of his songs. This is normal for movies (like My Fair Lady), but for some reason, people don't seem to give Crowe the credit for that. He was great. Lots of meaning in his voice as he sang his songs (because he's a good actor). The makeup and stage settings were awesome. The whole thing was as realistic as this play can be. I recognized the lead young actor from an odd but good movie he made years ago with Julianne Moore (it was a true story). You should see that movie. He's a good actor. Didn't know he could sing, but he can. Loved this movie.

reviewText: In 19th Century France, Jean Valjean is a man who stole a piece of bread to feed his sister's baby. He is imprisoned for twenty years. Valjean is released, but he breaks parole, and is haunted by Javert, the ruthless policeman. Valjean agrees to care for factory worker Fantine's daughter, Cosette. This begins a remarkable journey for them all...."It is nothing to die. It is frightful not  to live(Victor Hugo)". An enormous, loud, wrenching tale set in revolution-torn France, "Les Miserables" is Tom Hooper's cinema-splendor, based on the 1980 musical that is still being performed in London today. "Les Miserables" packed houses on Broadway from 1987 to 2003, and came back in 2006. It is the third longest-running musical in Broadway history. Victor Hugo's 1862 novel has been the subject of some 60 film and TV adaptions. Two American versions in the 1930's and 1950's starred Frederic March and Charles Laughton. Raymond Bernard's 1934 French version, in two parts, lasts 4 1/2 hours, and is classic. This new "LM" stars Hollywood actors Hugh Jackman, Russell Crowe(excellent) and Sacha Cohen(very funny), all singing for themselves. 25 minutes in, Anne Hathaway, as Fantine, delivers an up-close, one-take rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream", a 4 1/2 minute song rich in power and tragedy; power in song that has rarely split the cinema; not ever so hardly in song.Hardly. Like Baz Luhrmann's great 2001 "Moulin Rouge", "LM" has sweeping musical set-pieces mounted in CGI, rotoscope, miniatures, and matte paintings; filmed in France, and London's Pinewood Studios. The DVD is glorious, a two-disc blue-ray release, with commentaries, Victor Hugo features, and production shorts. Long and sad, "LM" captures the genius of Victor Hugo, and along the way, it captures us all. "To love another person is to see the face of God(V. Hugo)".
summary: "Those who do not weep, do not see......"

reviewText: I saw this movie in the theaters. This was the first time I saw Les Mis. I never saw the plays or other musicals. I remember seeing the trailers and seeing that this was going to be an epic movie. This movie makes me happy although it's very depressing. A lot of people die in the film. It's a great story that I love. The story fascinates me. I love the epic rivalry of Valjean and Javert. Valjean is Good and Javert is evil. Jackman's best role ever. Crowe and him were perfect to go one on one. I think everyone can relate to Valjean.Valjean is a good person who made a small mistake by stealing a loaf of bread and thus is treated like he was a bad criminal. Javert is ignorant and lives only by the law. He won't understand or be willing to look at it in any way but his own. Crowe actually plays Javert in an interesting way. Although he is very intense and scary at times there is a softness in his character that you sometimes see that make you not completely dislike him. In his final encounter with Valjean you feel it in his eyes and body. He realizes Valjean was a good man and he couldn't use the law to give him admittance to arrest Valjean. Valjean had saved Javert's life the night before. Javert slowly comes to terms with the fact his whole life has been a sham. He had done the wrong thing. What he did was terrible and the fact he couldn't live by the law anymore he takes his own life.Valjean is a great kind man who saves Cosette from the poor treatment from the innkeepers who are shady and sketchy characters. Borat as the lone person in the film with a French accent does a good job. Anne Hathaway gave a great performance but she was only in the film for a brief time. I was sad that Valjean died in the end. I would have preferred him to live to marry or just spend more time with Cosette and Marius.I love the character of Eponine I think every person in the world can relate to her. Everyone has had some growing up that they really liked but they didn't have the same feelings for us. She is the definition of unrequited love. I really wanted her character to end up with Marius. I thought it was terrible she died in the film. It's one of the major blows in the film. Samantha Barks did a great job as Eponine.I thought the acting was great in this film. I rate Jackman first, Hathaway second and Crowe third in best in film. I felt Jackman was the heart of the film as Hathaway was the soul. Crowe gave a great overlooked performance which is understandable giving Hathaway and Jackman's epic performances. I have seen the film so many times and it has inspired me so much.For a depressing film it gave me a lot of happiness. Seeing Valjean as a good man fighting against the evil man Javert while trying to live a noble and good life was awesome. It's a great story. It's a story that grows popular with every generation and it will live forever. From the start of the film it is just an adrenaline rush and it's quite an emotional ride you get taken on and in the end you may have run out of kleenex but it's a powerful film that will stick with you for many years after viewing it! Cheers and Enjoy!
summary: One Of The Greatest Films Of All Time!! Spoilers!!

reviewText: Finally got around to see the "Les Miserables" latest reincarnation. The beloved master piece comes alive with great visual, staging, costuming and talent. For the most part. The central premise of the story is that life isn't fair, and this movie brings it home. Some people can sing and some shouldn't. Now, going into it you already know that it is a musical, that the film is close to three hours in length and that there is a possibility that you won't stand it. I'm in the group of liking the movie albeit with reservations. Hugh Jackman's Valjean is lucky to be a strong man because "they" carry the brunt of the whole story from beginning to end. Mr. Jackman's performance is well rounded and he could actually sing. Anne Hathaway is Fantine, she's got down the emaciated and fragile persona down so well, you know where her career is going. Her rendition of the dream song was moving and full of emotion. So then we have Russell Crowe. Geez. He must have been very constipated during filming, worst Jalvert ever. He reminded me of Meatloaf sans the facial expressions. They could've tried harder, but I guess they needed star power. Really, it's not like musicals are that popular. Then there's Amanda Seyfried, her vibrating shrills were just abominable, we know she's there because she's eye candy, or trying to pull in a tween base. The other singing cast was so much better that you really feel sorry for her. It's an ok movie if you agree to all of that, if not you probably can find a better use for a few hours.

reviewText: Awesome. Brilliant. Many have been the cinematic adaptations of Victor Hugo's classic "Les Misérables," and for good reason. This is a powerful, moral story that needs to be kept alive for generations to come. But what it makes it much risky as a film, given the current trend in audiences' tastes, is to make it a musical. And that is precisely what director Tom Hooper did. The result is just fantastic, grandiose, unforgettable, and one for the ages.The story begins in 1815, where we are told that "twenty six years after the start of the French revolution, a king is once again on the throne of France." Right away we watch the now famous scene in which Jean Valjean (an unrecognizable Hugh Jackman) and hundreds of fellow prisoners are painfully pushing a gigantic ship into an empty dock, under the unmerciful surveillance of ruthless policeman Javert (Russell Crowe). Once the day is over and the huge task completed, Valjean is finally granted his freedom, being labeled "a dangerous man, on parole forever." His crime: stealing a loaf of bread years ago, to feed his sister's son. Fast forward to 1823, and we find Valjean as a successful business man, who owns a factory where they manufacture religious artifacts - he was helped by a priest during his days after release. Unbeknown to him, Fantine (Anne Hathaway), one of the workers at the factory, was fired because she was pregnant. Sadly, she became a prostitute afterward, under the eyes of lowlifes Thénardier (Sacha Baron Cohen) and Madame Thénardier (Helena Bonham Carter). While she works, the Thénardiers have her daughter Cosette (Isabelle Allen) also working as a slave under very unsanitary conditions. Sadly, Fantine dies, and Valjean, remorsefully, decides to take care of Cosette. Sadly, too, Javert shows up and finds out that Valjean is around, so he goes after him with a vengeance. We then move on to 1832, when a revolution is boiling in Paris, were the poor are fighting the rich. We now find Cosette grown up (this time played by Amanda Seyfried), and, while her father is trying to evade Javert during some turmoil, she catches the eye of Marius (Eddie Redmayne), a well-to-do young man who happens to be involved in the revolutionary movement, but in favor of the poor. Javert, meanwhile and more than ever, is trying to capture Valjean at any cost.Whether or not you like musicals - and I don't, for most part --, you'll surely embrace "Les Misérables," even though 95% of the dialogue is done by singing. Everything works: the acting, the cinematography, the music, the production design, and, of course, the unforgettable and timeless story. The Blu-ray + DVD + Digital copy edition is awesome as well, loaded with extras, with features about the stars, locations, music, production design, commentary by director Hooper, and more. Needles to say, the film was nominated for 8 Academy Awards, and won 3 Golden Globe Awards. (USA/UK, 2012, color, 158 mins plus additional materials).Reviewed on March 25, 2013 by Eric Gonzales for Universal Blu-ray

reviewText: Your like of this film is going to strictly depend on whether you like these Kinds of Broaday musicals and further,even if you do, if you can stand your cherished theater musical adapted to film.  It would be hard to imagine that anyone could do a better job than Tom Hooper has done for the film version.  I serisouly doubt any other filmmaker could do better.  We also have a dream cast.  Far from days when movie stars who couldn't sing were used in these movies, both Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway are known for their voices. (I don't know if anyone else can remember Elizabeth Taylor singing as the lead in the film musical adaptation of A LITTLE NIGHT MUSIC.  Putting a non singer in the lead ruined it and now no one will remake the film.)A critical deicision was made NOT to prerecord the music but to sing it live and in performance.  What you lose in purity of voice, you gain in the emotion of performance. But this probably means that if you buy the album, you will likely buy the Broadway one.I think Russell Crowe does fine. I was actually surprised how well he did but, remember, he didn't have to hit the notes Hugh Jackman did.I think one really nice aspect is that now worldwide people will know that Hugh Jackman is a triple threat talent, i.e. he can act, sing and dance.  This is very rare and it is ironic that most viewers still think of him as Wolverine.
summary: You have to be open to the experience.....
