reviewText: First off, I am a die hard Les Mis-a-holic and have waited with baited breathe for nearly 20 years for this film to see frutition, only to be HIGHLY let down...and here's why. While visually the film is great, the majority of the performances left me cold and I will break each one down; starting with...Hugh Jackman...The Tony Award winning Aussie wins the role of a lifetime as our hero Jean Valjean. I had such high hopes when I heard this casting, giving Jackman's background and left the theater with his performance getting the title of "Biggest Letdown." Vocally I feel this role was TOO big for even Jackman (just watch him attempt "Bring Him Home"). I will keep saying indefinitely that I feel he could have NAILED Javert instead, which leads me to...Russell Crowe...I actually give the man an A for Effort, given he had the least amount of musical experience of all the main cast. His "acting" makes up for his lack of singing experience.However, part of the strength of Javert in the musical IS his songs.Anne Hathaway...While she was the surprise performance of the film I DO have some issues of her portrayal of the doomed Fantine. I feel Tom Hopper completely wanted to make Fantine a victim the entire time she is on screen, far from who Fantine is in the stage show, and all culminating with "I Dreamed A Dream." This is a song sung by a women who has not quite reached the bottom and still holds out hope but when Anne Hathaway sings it; you feel Fantine has all but given up on herself and her reason for living-Cosette.Sasha Baron Cohan and Helena Bonham Carter...My vote for second biggest letdowns. These two CAN sing and had the chance to knock these parts out of the park-especially Helena. Listening to "Master Of The House" I couldn't believe what I was hearing (and seeing-i.e. the Santa scene). The song is supposed to be upbeat, bouncy, and yet I couldn't help but feel Sasha and Helena were held back and couldn't be who the characters are really like.Amanda Seyfried...First off, I don't get what is with the hate. When it was announced that this film WAS happening; she was one of two roles I saw cast early on. She may not have the best voice for this type of musical (she shined in Mamma Mia)but she epitomises what older Cosette is about-innocence and a young women coming into her own.Samantha Barks...She was hands down the best performance of the adult leads! I see nothing but good things for this young women who went from second runner up on a BBC talent show to West End star and now prepped to take on Hollywood.Eddie Redemyer...Another performance that went from really bad in the beginning (the vibrato) to very moving in the end (second best "Empty Chairs" I've heard).Die hard fans will notice the cuts in the songs or rearranging the songs (which HIGHLY annoyed me-especially key parts). Unnecessary scenes (again, the "Santa scene," if you've seen the movie you know the scene. If you aren't familiar with the show, then I would say that you'll enjoy this film.
summary: Les Mis fans will understand why only 3 stars....

reviewText: One hundred and fifty years ago, Victor Hugo wrote the novel for "Les Miserables" and it has been told and retold many ways and in many fashions. This film version has been in the works for almost as long as the story spans in years. That would be thirty. The sweeping scope and scale of its premise, I would guess are not the reason for the delay, but the method of story-telling was most likely polarizing and some movie studio finally said, "Oh, why not."This version is like no other. It is a reflection of the stage musical, in which everything is sung. Dialogue and songs are blended together. To make things even trickier, much of the movie was filmed and portrayed live. The music was played on set and the actors were saddled with singing the songs without cuts and bringing the required emotion to it, as actors. At times, this technique is brilliant and beautiful, and at times the risk of this technique rears its ugly head. One thing can be said, this is an incredibly gutsy attempt at filmmaking by director Tom Hooper and there are moments so gut-wrenching and emotional they leave you breathless.Anne Hathaway, Hugh Jackman and Amanda Seyfried are actors who are meant for the stage. The casting of these three actor/actress' is none short of brilliant. Anne Hathaway's portrayal of Fantine is perfect and her performance of the popular song, "I Dreamed a Dream" is so good, you hang on every word of it, feeling every drenching gasp of her emotions. Amanda Seyfried's portrayal of Cosette is simply defined by her method of singing. Her voice is full of a rare combination of soul, peace and beauty, exactly what Cosette should be.  Hugh Jackman plays Jean Valjean, a man who spent 19-years in prison for stealing bread for his dying sister. There is really nothing to be said about his performance, other than brilliant. He was meant for this.I would be amiss not to mention Eddie Redmayne as well for his performance as Marius Pontmercy. Much has been said publicly and nationally about the other three stars in this film, but Pontmercy holds his own along-side Hathaway, Jackman and Seyfried."Les Miserables" is gifted with beautiful voices, but at times, as an audience member, you become aware of the length of the movie. There are many songs that sound alike and much of the time when the actors are singing their dialogue, it all sounds the same and monotonous.  There are moments in this film that are absolutely epic in scale and simplicity and there are moments that will drag you down to snooze land."Les Miserables" is not for the moviegoer who thinks they would like to try and see if they like musicals. If you don't typically like musicals or musical theatre, you will most likely not enjoy it. Although if you do, you will want to trudge through some of the heavier and slower parts of this movie to get to the moments of greatness that occur. When movies are sung, especially ones like this where it is 100% sung, that means that every single emotion and plot point are fleshed out and explored to the hilt, for four or five minutes. Some of those plot points are less interesting or less vital than others. The ones that are vital though are worth wading through the others.
summary: MONOTONY mixed with BRILLIANCE makes for a wide range of opinions

reviewerName: Chris Swanson "I'm just this guy, you know?"
reviewText: This is the first time I've ever seen the musical version of Les Miserables. This is something of a surprise, because around 21 years ago I listened to the full soundtrack. I just never had the chance to actually see a performance. During that time, for personal reasons, it became a very important story to me. Now I've finally had the chance to watch this movie. Was it worth the 21 year wait?In a word, yes. This was absolutely everything that I'd hoped for in a movie version of the famed musical. Visually stunning, with such a memorable soundtrack and incredible performances, especially by Anne Hathaway who, goodness me, may well have sewn up an Oscar with her singing of "I Dreamed a Dream", something that put even the Susan Boyle version to shame.The story is by turns basic and complex. Hugh Jackman plays Jean Valjean, a man convicted and sentenced to five years in prison for stealing a loaf of bread. During that time, he tried to escape, but was caught, and ends up having fourteen years added to his sentence. Now after 19 years, he's released on a parole, but, as many released from prison discover even now, he can't find a job and can't find a place to live. He's taken in by a kindly bishop (Colm Wilkinson, who originated the Valjean role on stage), and then repays the bishop's kindness by stealing silver plates and the like. When he's caught, he claims the silver was a gift, and is astounded when the bishop not only backs him up, but offers him more. Valjean, who had been on the verge of turning into a villain, instead becomes a hero and sets out to return to being an honest man. Meantime, police inspector Javert (Russell Crowe, who really has an incredible singing voice), sets off in pursuit of Valjean, while around them France seethes with revolutionary fervor.That is, mind you, just scratching the surface. It doesn't touch on the romance, the comedy relief, the violence, the death, the other death, the many, many, many deaths. Some of these deaths are truly heart-wrenching, and I'm only half joking when I comment about hiding the razors before watching.The music is everything I'd expected and the sets are wonderful. But the real gem here are the performances. Jackman, Crowe, Sasha Baron Cohen and Helena Bohnam Carter are all exceptionally good in their roles, but it is Hathaway who walks off with the best performance on film. If you can sit through her final song and not want to start crying like a child, you might well need to have emotions.exe installed. In fact the only complaint I have about casting is that of Eddie Redmayne, a normally fine actor, but someone with a singing voice that sounds like what someone who wanted to parody a stage singing voice would sound like. It's not bad, really, but very stylized and odd.While I don't think this movie will or should win Best Picture at the Oscars, it still has a great deal to recommend it. I highly recommend it, the highlight soundtrack, currently available for fifteen bucks from Amazon, and even, if you feel brave enough, reading the original book. I don't think you'll be disappointed in any of the above.
summary: Hide the razor blades, it's time for some Les Mis!

reviewText: Let me preface this by saying, I never saw the stage-play in any form, at any time... So I went in, literally, with an open mind & a 'blank slate'. _ I tried my very, very hardest, to like this film/opera; but it is just horrible.Instead of selecting the best Voices, they selected the highest profile names they could cast, so long as they could sing well, to good... And the results speak for themselves. _ I loved "Phantom of the Opera"; and I even liked "Sweeney Todd" (as well as one, most viewing this film have likely never seen: "Repo! The Genetic Opera", which I also loved). _ H.B.Carter is the only thing that kept me from Loving "Todd" (vs. Liking it); and sadly, she's in this one as well, which drags to an unbearable degree at times.  (and I'm not even going to touch the story/script-problems, as that's a whole other icky ball of wax... and even if it's 'faithful' to the original story... there are still some pretty huge issues which weren't addressed, which desperately needed to be, to make the story more palatable to anyone older than 10, or with an IQ over 70).Even the actual songs were bad, unmemorable, etc., which means it completely fails as an Opera/Musical -- but since it was the only "Musical" of the year (barring perhaps, "step up 3" or other tween-drivel), it was nominated for several awards, even though it's horrid.  So, literally, "nominated by default", and yet they proudly proclaim everywhere they possibly can: "Nominated for .... Awards", LOL.Excluding the very first scene (slavery/ship scene), the Direction/Cinematography is almost completely non-existent, with the camera being constantly stationary during most songs... i.e., It's in a fixed position, and the Actor(s) stay on their mark, in close-up or semi-close-up, and sing, sometimes even looking straight into the camera (which is done purposefully)... even though it does nothing to add or enhance the scene/mood/etc.  If someone were to time the "stationary" shots, I bet it would amount to nearly 1/3rd of the film's run-time; and so you're constantly having to deal with the boring "shots" in conjunction with the boring songs... Not a good combination.  (watch "Phantom of the Opera" to see the proper way to Direct & Shoot a Film-Opera! -- Or watch Phantom if you want amazing singers, good songs, AND good acting, all at the same time... rather than, a sprinkle here, a sprinkle there, as it is in this "film".)I expected much, much more.Hugh Jackman & the YOUNG Cossette are the highlights, w/ little else to praise.Hathaway isn't in this movie long enough to be, genuinely, considered "best supporting" anything... but I guess the Awards people felt sorry for her since she let them 'shave' her head on screen.  (or because it was so "brave" of her to do it, LOL, as if it hasn't been done dozens of times before)If Hollyweird has ANY sense left, they'll put the Director (and the Cinematographer, if there even was one), on a "do not hire as" list... because they clearly are not capable of delivering anything of value... let alone, LASTING value.  (I'm sure there was a Cinematographer; but you have to wonder, with 1/3rd of the film being uninteresting, and LONG, stationary-shots!)
summary: Just Horrible! Expected so much more

reviewText: This could have been the greatest movie musical ever filmed if it werent for the bizarre choices the director and cinematographer made on how to shoot this. Jittery hand held shots, extreme close ups, weird fish eye lens shots and weird angles, make no sense at all, do not fit the material, and are a huge distraction. A more classical approach would have worked much better for this story.That said, great cast, costumes sets etc. Samantha Barks is the real sensation. And Russell Crowe didnt bother me as much as he did other people. Good film, but not great.

reviewText: I have always said that Hugh Jackman needs to accept roles that showcase his talents.  X-Men, Reel Steel, Wolverine...sorry, these were all fun movies - but he was playing it safe and having fun doing them.  Les Miserables is a venture that shows Jackman taking on his talents as an actor and a singer - his real talents.  [by the way he can dance too...yes he can.]  Jackman will win the best actor honors, the ensemble was magnificent and should earn the film best picture honors, and don't forget Anne Hathaway as a sure bet Oscar in her supporting role. What can I say?  Buy the movie, see the movie, love the movie...

reviewText: I saw this at the movies twice and purchased the DVD because I obviously was impressed by what i saw and heard.I've read Victor Hugo's novel upon which this story is based, seen a couple of non-musical film versions, and have seen the musical staged twice, i expected to enjoy this film, but was genuinely surprised by how much i really loved this film.To summarize it quickly, this film tells the story of Jean Valjean who is sent to prison for stealing a loaf of bread to feed his sister's son. Valjean endures unbelievable hardship as a shackled prisoner as he sees his youth wasting away. When he is finally released from prison, he finds a prison in his freedom as public pariah who is never truly free as his activities are to be monitored and there is no way to improve his lot in life. He disappears and reinvents himself and through a series of circumstances becomes a wealthy man. While he enjoys his new life and tries to share his improved circumstances with others, he always feels the shadow of his former guard a public official type named Joubert. The ensuing story covers Valjean's attempts to evade Joubert who is seemingly always just one step away from capturing him and returning him to prison. As side stories, there is the romance of  Valjean's adopted daughter Cosette and the well born Marius, the French Revolution, and the ill-fated mother of Cosette named Fantine.This movie was remarkable in a lot of ways. Musicals are normally not very popular as an art form when translated to film. I really don't have a good explanation for why there aren't more musicals made, but i suspect it has a lot to do with cost. In the case of this film, it was very expensively made. The sets were really exquisite and while there was a lot of computer wizardry present the effects were generally very realistic in appearance. The costuming was fantastic and varied from the lush gowns worn by women to the rags worn by Valjean and his fellow prisoners.The story in itself was powerful and the music complimented the story as unfolded. The dialogue was sung as it was interspersed with large and small scale musical numbers which advanced the story along. The characters were well developed and I found myself becoming invested in their story almost immediately. The acting was really good and I found it interesting how the actors were able to use the music to enhance their roles. Even though i knew the story and where it was heading, I didn't find it boring or for that matter even paticularly predictable. I just sort of invested myself in this spectacle of sight and sound.I bought the DVD not so much because I plan to watch it a lot, but because I just found this to be a really exceptional film that I will enjoy in the future.

reviewText: There are musicals, and then there are musicals.  This adaptation of the smash Broadway show, itself sourced from Victor Hugo's classic novel of the post French Revolution and the suffering plight of the populace has been transformed into an impressive film which will appeal to those open to its free flowing style of song and music.  Think of this type of musical as operatic narrative with hardly a spoken line of actual dialogue.  For the uninitiated and fans of traditional movie musicals, this may take some getting used to. If one can embrace the format, it is a well made, emotionally moving tale of love and hope.Spanning the years 1815-1832, in Paris, France, the years following the French Revolution have left the country divided with its common citizens in poverty and hard labor.  A prisoner, Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), is paroled under the watchful eye of policeman, Javert (Russell Crowe). Stigmatized by his record, Valjean flees his past and makes a new life for himself as an upstanding citizen until a chance encounter exposes his identity to Javert, and the hunt is on.  Meanwhile, in a related incident, a factory worker, Fantine (Anne Hathaway), has been unjustly fired and must struggle to survive and care for her young daughter, Cosette.  As Fantine must resort to desperate measures and all hope begins to fade, Valjean intercedes, and while Cosette grows into a woman (Amanda Seyfried), their lives intertwine with a movement to rekindle the Revolution as a growing revolt pits commoners against French soldiers even as Javert closes in on his quarry.Through these characters, we witness a wide range of behavior from treachery and betrayal to loyalty and unrequited love.  It's also about the secrets and the choices made especially by Valjean who comes to a series of crossroads in life. Jackman does a great job of conveying shame, guilt, desperation and anger, but those feelings give way to wanting to be a better man.  His Valjean is the conscience of the film.Hathaway owns her role as the doomed Fantine and has the chops to sing the signature song, "I Dreamed a Dream".  Her character's descent into hell is not unlike the doomed characters in The House of Mirth or Sister Carrie.  Crowe has the unsavory role of the obsessed Javert but proves an effective foil to Jackman.  The folks that made TV's The Fugitive must have modeled Inspector Gerard on Javert!The storyline has numerous supporting characters and subplots including one involving a pair of crooked innkeepers played with villainy by Sasha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter. (What's with these three name actors anyway?)  There is also a nice musical, montage sequence that alternates and merges several different settings and characters; it is directly reminiscent of the pre-rumble sequence in West Side Story.Production values are outstanding with the set designs realistically recreating 19th century Paris (with parallels to Dickens' London settings) befitted with costume designs of the period.  The camerawork relies heavily on handheld close-ups for realism.  Of note, this is one of the few musicals that did not loop the vocals in post-production. Rather, the actors actually sing on camera, and fortunately they all acquit themselves well with these terrific songs.  The effect is more akin to witnessing a live, stage production.The end is memorable as wishes and legacies are fulfilled.  When you figure the resources and talented cast directed by Tom Hooper (the King's Speech) that brought this to the screen, it is a remarkable achievement. Because of the theatrical source material, however, just be wary of the way it's all presented, narrative and all.  "Vive la France!"
summary: The Triumph of the Commoner in LES MISERABLES

reviewText: It's impossible to imagine that anyone would want to see or rate this movie based on their expectations of a great vocal performance from popular Hollywood actors. That being said, it wasn't a bad movie, and a lot of the singing from the principal stars was quite decent. It seemed pretty obvious that the cast was filled out with people with a musical theatre background as the unknowns were a notch above with their ability. Enjolras was extremely enjoyable as the leader of the revolutionaries. Hugh Jackman was nearly consistently good with his singing. Amanda Seyfried was ok, though I got the feeling sometimes she was channeling one of the Chipettes, Brittany perhaps? I saw Mamma Mia after this and was surprised that her singing there was so much better. The commentary, aside from the obligatory cast on cast sycophantic fluff mentioned Russel Crowe's background in musical theatre, which means that he doesn't deserve as delicate a review. Young Gavroche was a scene stealer, hopefully he has a prosperous career in the years ahead. The remaining members were passable, and since Les Mis has some of my favorite songs, as well as some that have wiggled their way into the public's collective consciousness it's sad to not walk away from seeing this with a new favorite version ringing in my ears. I'm sure this movie has converted a lot of new fans though for musicals, Les Mis, and possibly even the plethora of Victor Hugo's writings. That couldn't be a bad thing. Struggling against suffering and tyranny with a dispassionate ruling class makes for an unsettling movie or musical experience anyway. And lesson learned, 15 students versus an army, dissenting opinions not welcome.
summary: "A" for effort since this isn't music class.

reviewText: From the first trailer, showing Anne Hathaway singing 'I Dreamed a Dream', I had anticipated this film.  With a cast including Hugh Jackman, Russel Crowe, Anne Hathaway, Helena Bonham Carter, and Samantha Barks, I felt this project couldn't go wrong (with the exception of Amanda Seyfried, which I contend that she is always the worst part of any movie she's in).  Add Tom Hooper (director of The King's Speech, which I ADORED) and we are setup for Oscar territory.  Even more interesting was the innovative 'live singing' that they did--basically they sang live on set, instead of prerecording the tracks as all others filmed musical have done.THE GOODAnne Hathaway is the best part of this movie.  Every scene she was in had me in tears.  It will be a travesty if she doesn't win Best Supporting Actress for her performance.  Hugh Jackman gave the best performance of his life.  And of course Samantha Barks' Eponine was brilliant.The effects and many of the shots were quite brilliant.  The coloring, the costumes, and the lenses were all amazing.THE BADRegarding the cinematography: I could have done with more variety of camera shots and angles.  The camera focused almost exclusively on a close-up of the current singer's face.  It was very distracting to me and not effective.Russel Crowe is one of the great actors of our time, but Javere just might be one of his worst performances ever.  He CANNOT sing!  Whoever thought it was a good idea to cast him should be run out of Hollywood.Amanda Seyfried was less atrocious than I expected, but she had dramatically less screen time than I had anticipated.  It seems they got the memo that she is an awful actress during the editing process.  Her singing voice and its goat-like vibrato is almost unbearable to my ears.In the end, the 'live singing' was also a distraction for me.  It didn't feel like a musical to me, but like an entirely new genre.  Each individual performance was powerful (with the exception of Russel Crowe's and Amanda Seyfried's), however when they are strung together it just felt weird to me.  It didn't have the energy or breathing room that a musical normally does.  I felt the brakes being slammed between almost every number.  I also felt that it was too emotionally manipulative: I felt like there a figurative plunger behind the screen, trying to get as many tears as possible.CONCLUSIONI seem to be the only one of my acquaintances that didn't love this film.  As a result I recommend it to all except those who are critically-minded.  Also, it is NOT family-friendly.  Lots of sexual content, most of it unneeded.  My score: 2/5 stars.
summary: A bold feat that falls flat

reviewText: Victor Hugo's classic tale of an escaped prisoner from a French prison, sentenced many years for stealing a loaf of bread, is once again told to a new worldwide audience in a manner so intrinsic to the ambitions of the author that it manages again to more than entertain.  Les Miserable offers the complete view of a time in Europe, specifically France, when individual freedom and justice came to be the shield against inept and corrupt government.The protagonist, Jean Valjean's escape from prison symbolizes how those so unjustly accused and imprisoned can regain their lives even against the constant pursuit of a obsessed constable and the laws designed to further create injustices continued.  The law, symbolic by the pursuer of this former convict comes to terms of how low the inept and relentless laws continue to do greater harm than good.This film outdoes the many former interpretations of this great story.  The music, the live voice track and the performances of all involved brings Hugo and his imagination full circle.  This single effort by great film and musical directors cannot help but be enjoyed by audiences worldwide and should certainly become a part of any film collectors library.  The sheer beauty of the film, the magnificence of the music and the all around individual performances: magnifique.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The anticipation and buzz surrounding this adaptation of the beloved book and musical has been extremely high since the first trailer came out and we heard Anne Hathaway's beautiful and haunting voice for the first time. Since then, it's been on many critics lists as an Oscar favorite. While moving and emotional, for me, the movie fell a little flat.First of all, there's no denying the talent attached to this film. Tom Hooper, following up his critically acclaimed and brilliant film The King's Speech gives the film great direction and captures the look and feel of 19th-century France. Likewise, the cast is on the top of their game here; Jackman is great as Jean Valjean and utilizes his previous Broadway experience here very well. I was also impressed with Seyfried, as I didn't know she had such a lovely singing voice, as well as newcomer Samantha Barks, who is sure to benefit greatly from her breakout role here. The true standout however, at least for me, was Hathaway. Her performance of "I Dreamed a Dream" is truly moving and was my favorite song from the film. Though she isn't in the movie as much as I would have liked, I think her supporting role is more than deserving of an Oscar nomination. The one actor whom I felt was out of place was Russell Crowe. While he has a decent singing voice, it didn't blend with that of the other actors. I don't know if it was lack of stage performance or what but his performance just didn't do it for me.Perhaps the biggest caveat I have with the film is the length. I know this was adapted from one of the most critically acclaimed plays in history but with a running time of nearly three hours, it overstayed it's welcome. It may be that Hooper was scared to leave anything out for fear of upsetting the fan base, but surely there could have been some scenes that shouldn't have made the theatrical cut.Finally, there was a lot of buzz surrounding the fact that the actors sang their parts on camera instead of recording beforehand. Call me crazy but I actually prefer the prerecording method. Not to say it isn't impressive that this was done but there were a few lines I couldn't understand because the actor singing ran out of breath or was singing so softly. It may be nitpicking but there it is. I feel like touching up some of the songs could have added that much more to the film's power and majesty.
summary: Moving and Emotional with a Few Caveats
Title: N/A

reviewText: Les Miserables is very old fashioned entertainment. It's a series of crescendo moments with no build-up, no backstory, no pause. It's like eating just the topping of the pecan pie, and not bothering with the crust or filling. We were just ten minutes into the movie when I had to look at my watch and ask, okay, how long can they keep this up? Climax after climax, plot twist after plot twist, tearjerking scene after tearjerking scene. Oceans! Mountains! Punishment! Suffering! Religion! Redemption! Will there be a break for lunch? Will we be able to catch our breath?If you can watch this film without crying, I don't want to know you. The woman behind me was on the edge of her seat, not just because I smell good. The audience at the 10:40 a.m. matinee - the theater was packed - applauded at the end, and was very slow to leave the theater, even as the closing credits rolled.Typical of big, fat, nineteenth-century novels, there are numerous implausible coincidences that drive the plot. These coincidences took me out of the movie, but that was a good thing. The human suffering onscreen was overwhelming: suicide, enslavement, exploitation of living humans' body parts, prostitution, disease, spite, malice, child abuse, starvation, sadism, a dying man escaping through very graphic sewerage. I did have to repeat to myself, "This is only a movie" even as tears streamed down my cheeks.Jean Valjean is imprisoned for stealing a loaf of bread to feed his sister's starving children. He slaves for twenty years. He hauls a massive, capsized sailing ship. The scene does look like obviously fake CGI, but that doesn't make it any less gut wrenching. The workers sing, "You'll always be a slave. You are standing in your grave." They are the men we see in Sebastiao Salgado photographs of Third World laborers. They are Ilya Repin's "Barge Haulers on the Volga." Valjean's nemesis is the crazily obsessive policeman, Javert. They spar throughout the film, as Valjean's fate rises and falls and rises and falls and rises ... you get the idea.A story this big, this broad, and this implausible requires one hundred percent commitment from the performers. Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean is superb. He believes. He emotes. He is as big as the story itself. Jackman is the heart and soul of "Les Miserables." I loved him. Anne Hathaway, Eddie Redmayne, Samantha Barks, Helena Bonham Carter, Sacha Baron Cohen - they all had me convinced. Russell Crowe was a surprising disappointment. He's a brilliant actor and I kept waiting for him to bring some fire, some ice, some power, some insight to Javert, the obsessive and punitive policeman who mercilessly hounds Jean Valjean. I wanted a memorable moment that would make me feel that Crowe's performance brought Javert to intimate life for me. That moment did not arrive.I wondered while watching this movie whether it will be embraced by the political left or the political right. It is a deeply and unashamedly Christian film. A Catholic priest, emulating Jesus, is the catalyst. Valjean spends the rest of the film working to live up to the priest's Biblical example. "Les Miserable" is leftist in that it depicts the poor rising up, but then the poor fail their own putative saviors, and allow them to be massacred, alone. Javert, representing law and order, is a monster. The film's brief glimpse of heaven is like some limousine liberal's fantasy.I think "Les Miserables" is as popular as it is for the same reason that Cinderella is so popular. When "Les Miserable" was a stage play, tickets were a very expensive and difficult to acquire luxury. It is ironic that a play about the wretched of the earth would be such a luxury entertainment. Why do we enjoy watching people much poorer and more desperate than we will ever be? Why do we pay for the privilege? Because we all see ourselves in Cinderella, in Jean Valjean, no matter how lucky we are. I'll certainly never stand in cold sea water with iron shackles around my wrists and neck, overseen by a cold sadist like Javert. But, along with millions of others, I saw my own struggles in Valjean, and thanked God that I didn't have it as bad as he. If Jean Valjean can go on, I can, too!I wish the songs had been a tad better. There are a couple of good ones, "I dreamed a dream" and "Do you hear the people sing?" All the actors sing very well. Russell Crowe and Hugh Jackman sing especially well.
summary: Why We Pay to Watch Others Suffer
Title: N/A

reviewText: Both times that I have seen "Les Miserables" on stage, in 1990 in Boston, and then years later as a school play at my daughter's high school, several things have always perplexed me about the play - while the songs are beautiful, and the themes of poverty, crime, justice, struggle, love, hope, sacrifice, and redemption are gut-wrenchingly timeless, the play itself was always for me hard to understand.Singing every single line of dialogue in the play can be utterly confusing, especially when four or more people are singing/saying different things at the same time on stage.  And please don't laugh, it was not until the Internet matured and I was able to look up the story of the play that I finally understood the ending of the play.  Why are all those people who had died earlier gathered around and singing at the barricades again?  Because, you see, I had actually read "Les Miserables", the book, years earlier, and that was soooo not in the book.Tom Hooper could have made this movie any number of ways, and his directorial choices are outstanding.  As such, he should have been nominated for the Oscars for directing.The best choice of course, was the one to have the actors sing live during filming, rather than lip synching and recording separately.  The result is better than what could have been achieved with live singing onstage in a play - the singing in a theater play is still constrained in that the songs have to be sung with enough volume for the entire theater, which eliminates the ability to do the emotional soft whispers that add so much to songs such as "I Dreamed a Dream" or "Valjean's Soliloquy".Another great choice was to pick great actors for the main parts.  A lot of people nitpick about the singing voices of Russell Crowe or others in this movie, but first and foremost, for this movie to work, it was necessary that great actors who fit their roles be picked for their parts; thus a commanding figure such as Crowe needed to be present to balance the star power of Hugh Jackman in their opposing roles as Javert and Valjean.  I thought the choices for all of the actors were terrific.  Considering that die-hard Les Miz fans cannot agree on who they think is the best ever singing performance for the various audio CD editions of "Les Miserables", it is easy to discount such critics of the singing voices here in this movie as nit-pickers who have lost sight of the overall needs of this movie.  Ann Hathaway and Hugh Jackman are simply outstanding, and Daniel Huttlestone (Gavroche) and Aaron Tveit (Enjolras) nearly steal the show with their performances.  Isabelle Allen is adorable as the young waif Cosette, Amanda Seyfried is gorgeous as adult Cosette, and Samantha Barks makes for a fine adult Eponine.Finally, the best directorial choice was the combination of large, sweeping visuals together with tight closeups for solos, and sequential cutaways during the multiple-voice singing parts.  These technical choices take full advantage of the power of film over that of the stage - the ability to show the large and grande scenes of history while also bringing in up close and personal the emotions of the characters, and to tease out the complex singing parts into their individual voices.  It elevates the "Les Miserables" musical franchise into a far grander and more accessible, personal, and emotional experience than the stage version ever could.
summary: Wonderfully close and accessible, a walloping emotional punch, a tour de force of acting and singing

reviewText: Although I had heard of "Les Miserables", watching this movie was my first real exposure to it in any form. It was a big mix of good and no so good all around - the acting, the characters, and the story. By the end I definitely felt the movie was too long.The first third of the movie was great. Despite having high expectations after hearing about Anne Hathaway's performance, her scenes still managed to exceed them. "I Dreamed a Dream" was by far the highlight of the film. Her performance is really gut-wrenching. The early scenes with Hugh Jackman were very good as well. Perhaps the most entertaining scene was with Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter at the inn.The middle of the film has its moments such as Samantha Barks playing Éponine. However, this is also when I felt things go downhill. I didn't feel any connection to Cosette as an adult (Amanda Seyfried), so I never got overly concerned about her plight. Playing Marius, Eddie Redmayne seemed to have this dumbfounded look on his face most of the time. I didn't care for his character at all and the whole revolution felt more like grown-up kids acting out than anything noble to support. This isn't meant as a knock on the French Revolution, just the way it was portrayed here.When there were panoramic shots, the cinematography was breathtaking. Unfortunately, as many have noted, many of the film was shot with rather exaggerated close-ups. Yes, it's quite impressive that the cast were filmed doing the actually singing - but we don't need to see it up-close constantly as a reminder. I had heard negative things about Russell Crowe as Javert but felt his singing was good overall and had some really moving moments. All of the singing was good to great in fact. But long before the end I found myself looking at the clock wondering when the revolution was going to be finished already.

reviewText: First of all I'll make it clear that I'm a fan of the music; I have both the 10th and 25th Anniversary Concert Performances and have watched them many times. I had the good fortune to see Les Miserables performed on stage and have always found the music to be very stirring.For days after watching either of the two concert performances I found the music haunted my thoughts and drew me back to the story.Like most other fans I was looking forward to the time when the movie version would be released so I ordered the disc and had it delivered the first day it was available. Visually the movie is powerful and rather overwhelming and takes the viewer on a high impact journey through the streets of Paris in the first half of the 19th century.There were some points where the journey was almost too gritty and became rather hard to watch. From a strictly musical perspective I found the movie to be less satisfying than either the 10th or the 25th Anniversary Concert Performances. It almost appears that the drama of the story was given more priority than the drama of the music.That is not to say there were no grand moments in the musical performance, there were, but too often the drama of the music was eclipsed by the drama of the scenery and action and that was a slight disappointment to me as I watched.I will not make direct comparisons between the musical performances in the movie versus the same performances in the two concert performances; I suspect everyone will have their favorites.If one is a true fan of the musical, I suppose it could be expected that they would have recordings of all three and could select which one to hear depending on their mood at the time. The movie makes a powerful and convincing addition to the collection and along with the two concert performances provides rich entertainment regardless of the mood of the moment.This one is a must have for any fan of the musical. The quality of both video and audio is outstanding!

reviewText: This latest production of Les Miserables just wasn't very good.  It obviously has high production value.  It's visually fantastic, but it's an operetta with really substandard musical performances.  The music from Les Mis has always stood out as some of the most powerful and moving in musical theatre.  This latest version utterly fails to live up to that legacy.  Russel Crow's performance is especially bad.  If you love the music, you may want to give this one a miss.

reviewText: I'll be as generous as I can regarding this rushed effort. Compared to the more evenly and dramatically paced stage musical, I not only found the pacing to be hurried, but was a bit dismayed at how many stanzas were cut from its many iconic songs. I know there is some tradition of that being the case when musicals are transported from stage to screen, but here, it was a bit over done.Where Director Tom Hooper does receive points is in accurately capturing the griminess and dankness of the squalid areas of 19th century France.We do feel the grime and misery of the chain gang on a ship where we meet Victor Hugo's fabled protagonist Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman, who successfully captures his character's formidable strength) as he is given his parole after serving 19 years for stealing a loaf of bread to feed his starving nephew. The sentence was increased due to  Valjean's multiple attempts to escape.I would have chosen Will Theakston the actor who played the character, Marcus Flint in the "Harry Potter" films (or someone like him) to play the self-righteous police inspector, Javert, since  he more or less fits Hugo's description of that character. But Russell Crowe brings a firmness to the part. His experience in heading his own rock band serves him well here, despite much criticism. His rock tenor voice was suitable enough for the part. Javert hands Valjean his yellow parole pass. Valjean travels to the designated areas, but due to his pass can neither find shelter or work until he encounters the saintly Bishop of Digne (Colm Wilkinson, the musical's original Valjean, whose powerful vocalization initially sold this musical to all of us who have enjoyed it from its earliest years), who covers for Valjean when he steals the Bishop's  precious candle holders and is re-arrested by authorities. The Bishop gives him the holders and the candlesticks with the proviso that he become a better man, telling him he has purchased his soul for God.Although in violation of his parole, Valjean tears up his yellow parole pass and decides to begin life anew.Several years later, assuming the name Monsieur Madeline, he becomes the Mayor of Montreuil-Sur-Mer, and brings industry to the region, including a factory. The female workers endure sexual harassment  by the factory foreman(Michael Jibson, whose character, although not featured in Victor Hugo's novel, illustrates the plight of the working women of that time who had no rights, but endured unseemly treatment to be able to pay the bills), whose main target is the young Fantine.Having viewed this film in a theatre a week before Oscar Night, I felt that there would be no justice in Hollywood if Anne Hathaway did not win the Best Supporting Actress Award for her role as Valjean's ill-fated female counterpart, ousted from her job after being exposed as an unwed mother by malicious co-workers. Valjean was there, when that happened but failed to intervene. While in the past, I had hoped  that whoever directed the film version of this musical would cast someone with the fair-haired-blue-eyed looks with which Hugo ascribed his tragic heroine, since her coloring made her stand out among other French women and was the envy of her co-workers. But I appreciate the lengths to which Hathaway went to play her Oscar-winning role(which had once been played by her mother in a traveling stage production), starving herself to the point of emaciation, and receiving 2012's most-talked-about tonsure to reenact Fantine's sacrifices which pay for her daughter, Cosette's( Isabelle Allen, who would have more closely resembled her character if her naturally chestnut hair were not dyed blonde)lodging with an innkeeper, whom she fails to realize is extorting money from her. Fantine sells her teeth(in the book, her incisors), and finally begins to prostitute herself. Frances Ruffelle, The West End and Broadway's original Eponine, cameos as one of the ladies of the night. The scene of Fantine with her first client as the drugs she has taken to numb herself to his advances kick in is devastating.One can appreciate the symbolism in the difference in coloring between Fantine and her daughter in a way; a destitute mother embracing darkness so that her child may embrace light.Valjean still finds Javert in pursuit, as he has broken his parole, and an incident involving a man named Fauchelevant(Stephen Tate), who is rescued from being pinned beneath his cart by someone that the ever-vigilant Javert recognizes a former inmate with formidable strength. A man named Champmathieu(James Simmons) is arrested for Valjean's crime.In the meantime, Fantine is taunted by an idling dandy who pelts her with snow as she is working the street. Enraged, she attacks him. Javert shows up in time to apprehend her, and she pleads for mercy, as she has a child to support. Javert is unsympathetic, but Vajean, who saw the incident from the beginning, rescues the ailing, emaciated, and frightened young woman, and has her taken to the hospital, vowing to reunite her with her daughter upon learning of her wrongful dismissal from his factory.Valjean agonizes over the Champmathieu affair, but exonerates the wrongfully charged man. Then he visits the dying Fantine, reassuring her that he will find and raise her daughter. Javert shows up to arrest him and they duel before  Fantine's deathbed and the astonished nuns who had  nursed Fantine .Valjean escapes through a window and plunges into a river.The next scene is of the Thenardier's(an appropriately cast Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter)inn in the  village of Montfermeil. Amid the squalid splendor of Christmastide(which in the novel was nine months after Fantine's death), we meet the abused and forlorn Cosette, who has been enslaved by her guardians, wishing for a better life. The Thenardiers indulge their own daughter, Eponine( a dark little Natalya Angel Wallace, who bears a stronger resemblance to the Thenardier's other daughter, Azelma, who is excluded from the musical), filch their guests' possessions, raise prices for services unduly, and serve them a gruesome concoction of mystery meat.A frightened Cosette is sent to refill a bucket at a fountain in  the dark woods when Valjean encounters her and rescues her, informing her and the Thenardiers of her mother's death and that he is to take custody of her. The Thenardiers reluctantly relinquish her. But as Valjean and his little charge travel away, Javert is still in pursuit. Valjean makes a daring escape over a wall with Cosette in tow, and they arrive at a convent where Fauchelevant, the man rescued from his own fallen cart, works as a gardener. He helps Valjean secure a position there,and Cosette will be educated by the nuns. Javert remains determined to reincarcerate Valjean.By the 1830s, Paris simmers with political unrest. A cholera epidemic will soon claim the last Napoleanic general in the government, Maximillian Lamarque, the government's last champion of the poor. A group of idealistic college students who have formed an organization called Friends of the ABC(ABC being a play on the word "abaisess" or "abased"), feel that an uprising is on the horizon.We see young Gavroche(revealed in the book to be the Thenardier's son, here played very precociously by Daniel Huttlestone), mixing among the various social classes and crudely pushing his way into an upper class carriage in the crowded Parisian streets.We learn that ABC member, Marius Pontmercy(Eddie Redmayne), is estranged from his royalist grandfather, Monsieur Gillenormand(Patrick Godfrey), due to differing political ideologies.In the decade since leaving the Thenardiers, Cosette(Amanda Seyfried) had grown into a beautiful young woman, very devoted to Valjean. Despite an unsettling  encounter by a gang led by the Thenardiers, Valjean and Cosette live quietly in the city. Both Marius, and Eponine( Samantha Barks) spot Cosette, and while Eponine wistfully admires Cosette's change of fortune in contrast to her own dead-end situation in the underworld, Marius is smitten by the young beauty.While recruiting Eponine to go scout out Cosette's wherabouts, Marius must face a dilemma about love and war.A pensive Cosette wonders about Marius. Unaware of her attraction to a young man, Valjean acknowledges her lonliness, and that she is changing, but declines discussion of her past.After leading Marius to Cosette, Eponine laments that Marius could never love her, while watching the infatuated pair draw closer, and wards of her father's attempt to rob Valjean's house with his gang shortly thereafter. Hearing noise outside, Valjean assumes it's Javert, and  decides to flee with a reluctant Cosette.The song "One Day More"-highly reminiscent of "West Side Story's"  reprise of "Tonight" , provides the segway between the beginning and end of the story, presenting a summation of all the characters' anticipations during the coming uprising.While performers voices were allowed more subtlety and nuances than they  would have been onstage, where a singer really has to belt out to sell a tune to a live audience, the live-recorded voices had just the right amounts of  emotion, strength, or weakness when necessary.The film accurately depicts how the student uprising began as Lemarque's funeral cortege proceeded through the streets. The group leader, Enjorlas(Aaron Tveit, who seems a bit lightweight compared to the stage's Michael Maguire) leads the demonstration of solidarity with the poor that results in a volley by the National Guard. A barricade is quickly formed by the rebels and their supporters. Soon, Marius deals with a tragedy there, and sends Gavroche to deliver a message for Cosette.Valjean intercepts the letter and realizes there is another man in Cosette's life besides himself. He heads towards the barricades to find him, and at one point Jackman does solemn justice to the iconic showstopper, "Bring Him Home".After a volley, Marius is wounded and Valjean, after releasing  the captured Javert, whom Garvroche exposed as a police spy, flees through the sewers with the unconscious Marius. The other rebels don't fare so well. While Javert remains adamant in his determination to capture Valjean, Crowe's interpretation of Javert  gives him a brief moment of humanity when he places his medal on the corpse of a fallen street urchin(perhaps a gesture recommended by someone with two young boys of his own). Valjean's refusal to retaliate against his long-time pursuer leaves a scarring impression on the policeman, which literally sends him over the edge.Peasant women clean up the blood from the cobblestone streets, Marius recovers and mourns his losses, and there will be familial reconciliation, and a joyous union before our story concludes. The Thenardier's comical exit-- a far cry from the fates they meet in the novel- is reminiscent of the exit made by Fagin and the Artful Dodger in the musical, "Oliver!", which also preceded a dramatic and emotion-laden conclusion.But we are happy to know that Cosette has been ushered into a better life, justifying her mother's sacrifice, and while the grime of the streets is never far from view, nor the mantle of suffering far from our grasp, the demand for a better world from the spirits of those fallen on the barricades will long stay in our memories.

reviewText: Another movie version of a musical, like Phantom of the Opera, terribly miscast from a singing perspective.  Only the rebels at the barricade could sing.  Hugh Jackman's voice has range, but it is unpolished, and he screamed his high notes, Amanda Seyfried's voice also had range but was as thin as a rail, and Anne Hathaway's presentation of I Dreamed a Dream was dramatic rather than sung as it should be.  (It is the musical's signature tune.)  Forget Russell Crowe, who would have made a great Javert in a dramatic role but who should forgo future musical performances.  I immediately turned on the 25th Anniversary performance to hear the musical sung well (despite the gain-ridden sonics that ruin the recording, at least as presented on PBS.)  It's a MUSICAL guys.  Choose musicians for the roles.
summary: Great story, great acting, great sets, woeful singing

reviewText: I love this musical, as well as the original movie, but I saw, this one was in the form of an opera and I thought I would hate it because I wanted some really good acting as well in my favorite book and movie of all time.. I gave it a chance and it turned out I JUST loved it.PROS.......Great make-up....fabulous set.....wonderful costumes.....wonderful direction and fast paced editing.Cons.....Russel Crowe is almost awful in this film and can't sing, nor even act well in this movie and I'm a big fan of his. He was remarkable in "Gladiator". I think he's mis-cast it seems and fails to deliver anything of note. This is a film where it looks like he took the money can ran because he didn't even seem to show interest in his part.Way too many songs with too many missed notes all through this production. Why you wouldn't want good singers in an opera style film that is "ALL" singing........ is beyond belief to me.I think just listening to Ann Hathaway doing the one song, "I Dreamed a Dream" is so moving, it's worth the entire viewing of the film just for that alone. The other actors left Mr. Crowe in the dust here I'm sorry to say but the film is a solid winner to me and shows again that stars don't always make the film good.If you want to see acting as it's finest in this role...look at Geoffrey Rush performance with Liam Neeson in the 1998 version of this film.They're vastly different, but I loved both of these films.

reviewText: Les Miserables is now one of my all- time favorite musicals. I personally find it to be visually stunning. For example when Javert is singing Stars,in the background you see Notre Dame cathedral. And also when Valjean first gets out on parole you see snowy mountains behind him. Really impressive. The performances in this movie were outstanding. Especially Ann Hathaway. Her voice is incrediable and she sang I dreamed a dream with so much passion and raw emotion that I had tears in my eyes. I was really moved. She really captured Fantine as a character on screen perfectly. Huge Jackman also did a very knock out performance. Though in my poersonnal opinion I think his voice could have been better. He definately can sing and act very well. I was even surprized by Russel Crowe's performance as well. I don't think his voice was bad. Though the other cast members had better voices then him his voice fits Javert. The music is just... unbelieveable. It is superb. Though I do prefer the broadway cast album of the show. (Colm Wilkensen's voice is gorgeous to listen to.) The music here is just as good even though I feel as if it loses some of the way the music is supposed to sound. But still very well done. I could go on  forever about how good this movie is. My only regret is that I did not get a chance to see the play live on broadway. Maybe a revival will happen. Anywho, if you have not seen this film go see it right away. You won't be disappointed.*update* Saw the play today (5/17/14) and it was WAY better than the film. Though this film adaptation had greater sets the music was clearer and more beatifull live. There is no comparison than seeing a musical live especially this one.

reviewText: Right out of the gate I have to say I hated this movie.  I am a die hard fan of Les Mis but this just fell flat.  It's true turning a  Broadway musical into a movie allows for some interpretation but this interpretation just fell flat.  First off they took one of the greatest musical compositions ever but didn't worry about matching voices to the rich vocal parts.  Val Jean has so many beautiful songs that Huge Grant just couldn't hit.  It seemed the film makers were more intent on "acting" then actual concern over the ability to preform this beautiful score.  Star power does not mean quality performance.While each of the actors have proven their abilities in their own right it was not for their expansive musical talent.  I don't want this to sound like a criticism on any of the actors.  As actors I have liked them all in their various works.  However, it baffles me how everyone raved about how talented they are based on this performance.... as a musical ensemble it was lacking.  Anne Hathaway sounded like she was panting through her songs rather than singing.  She was just awful. Hugh Jackman, even though I have seen other musicals he has been in and other vocal performances, just didn't have the ability to support the Val Jean richness and breadth.  And Russel Crow (I have to admit I don't know much about his musical ability) was, sub par, at best.The Inn keeper and his wife were boring as opposed to roustabouts and comical, I didn't feel any relationship between Marius and Éponine,  And Enjolras did not inspire me in the slightest.Honestly, I feel I need to go watch the 50th anniversary (even with the little Jonas Brother) to get inspired about this great work again. Overall I was highly disappointed.
summary: Normally a Les Mis fan but this was just bad

reviewText: There were so many things wrong with this movie:-- The girl who played Cosette could not sing, period.-- Hugh Jackman overacted the entire movie, which was even more distracting because Russell Crowe *under*acted throughout the entire movie.-- Oddly enough, I actually liked Crowe's singing more than Jackman's; I thought he portrayed a unique, more masculine version of Javert that hadn't really been done before. Unfortunately, his rather stoic singing meant that it made zero sense when his character killed himself; who kills himself over a case he didn't really care about to begin with?-- Anne Hathaway was admittedly amazing.-- I thought Samantha Barks (as Eponine) was competent, but didn't possess the emotional capacity of her Broadway counterparts Lea Salonga & Frances Ruffelle. Also, cutting A Little Fall of Rain down that significantly + barely singing it (as much as they were whispering it) = NOT ok.-- The camera work was awful-- The film cut the scenes awkwardlyThere are strong points to the movie, but it definitely didn't live up to its potential.
summary: This movie did not live up to the story.

reviewText: Before watching this movie I had watched the TV productions of the concert version of Les Miz many times. I know most of the lyrics by heart after listening to the London Cast CD hundreds of times. I thought I was prepared for what was to come. I had no idea.I turned off the lights, started the instant video, and my husband and I began watching. Within a minute we had left our home and were in France watching one of the most compelling scenes we have ever witnessed. There was no going back.We watched and cried, recouped our forces, then cried some more. It was painful yet cathartic, in a strange way, and I was totally unprepared.I can't ever remember being swept into a movie before where I felt like I was actually there witnessing the events. I was cold and damp, in the rain, and warm and dry by the fire. I smelled the sweat, fear, sewer, and blood.It was totally awesome and I was watching it on a fairly small TV by today's standards. I can't even imagine what it is like to see it in a theater.After watching Les Miz, and the other Academy winners, I feel that this film was robbed by the academy. If they could have seen it through my Le Miz-vigin eyes, I think they would have given it far more awards. As it is, I think the movie was just a rehash, to them, of a stage play they had watched into the ground.As I said, I know the music by heart but I've never heard it sung with so much passion. I loved its imperfection and intimacy. It tore my heart into shreds and then put it all back together at the end.I want to thank everyone involved in the production for giving me the movie of a life-time. There is simply nothing more I could have asked of this film. It is simply the best movie I have ever had the privilege to watch.

reviewText: My wife had been waiting and hoping that the BD of Les Miserables would arrive before before her birthday. It arrived the day before.I have to tell you, I was suspicious of the enterprise, but my wife was excited about it.So we retired to our theater last night. My wife reminded me it was not opera.From the very beginning this film is a truly excruciating experience and I was wishing it was an opera I was watching.Not one of the principals can hold a tune, or get on pitch let alone stay on it. Anne Hathaway can briefly get on pitch in the softer passages, but as soon as she tries to swell her voice she if off pitch by a mile.Even the chorus can not sing on pitch!The musical standard is well below any high school performance I have attended, or any production I have ever been involved with. The sort of sub amateur performance on this disc I tried to listen to last night would not have seen the light of day and this production should not have either.About a third of the way through, as I was holding my piece, my wife said, " I just can't watch this any more."I said "every nerve I own is just raw". So off it went never to disgrace this theater again.This is a pity. I like Les Miserable. I have seen it on Broadway.This movie requires singing actors, and not famous actors who can't sing. This is what opera signers are. They can sing and in terms of acting are the equal of any cast members here. We now have an abundance of fine singing actors. I would have cast Barbara Hannigan soprano, in place of Anne Hathaway for a start.This production is a total disgrace and my advice is to pass up this disc, it is a total waste of money, in fact worse as you will be quickly climbing the walls if you try to watch it.

reviewText: Very seldom at the end of a film have I felt like standing up and applauding.  However Tom Hooper's version of the West End and Broadway smash hit left me begging for more. The central performances are just fantastic: Hugh Jackman is both appealing yet determined as Valjean, while Russell Crowe is just a revelation as Javert. Never have I seen Crowe better cast; the role could have been made for him as the ever-vigilant officer of the law, determined to pursue Valjean at all costs, yet finding himself unable to carry out his stated mission of killing the ex-convict off.  Crowe also possesses an attractive singing voice that reaches its apotheosis in two solo numbers.Anne Hathaway has a comparatively small role as Fantine, but she is likewise wonderfully cast, with an expressive singing voice.  She not only has two solo numbers, but she has a memorable death-scene, as Valjean cradles her head and she imagines her daughter Cosette appearing in front of her.The production also contains two comic cameos by Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen.  As she matures, Bonham Carter is becoming an accomplished character actor with a penchant for musicals (remember SWEENEY TODD); in this film she has a memorable number with Baron Cohen (who bears a startling resemblance to the late British satirist Peter Cook).For those who haven't seen the stage production, Hooper's film version tells the story crisply yet lucidly.  The orchestrations are just fantastic, while the ensemble cast (all of whom sung live on camera, rather than miming to playback) create great production numbers.  Add to that some memorable photography, and you have a film that is quite simply wonderful; the best musical I have seen for many a decade.
summary: A Wonderful Rendition of a Classic Stage Musical

reviewText: I don't like to write long reviews (or reviews in general), so don't expect a plot summary or detailed description.  The Broadway show was, by far, my favorite show of all time (saw it twice).  I was in awe.  I also loved the movie, even though I disagree with some choices.  They made some unnecessary changes to some major songs that I disagreed with.  They left out parts of Fontines' death song, made some word changes to the finale (I would have liked Eponine to join Fontine and come floating down as angels) and made other changes.  I would have left the songs as they were.  I was also a bit disappointed in Russell Crowe's performance - both his acting and singing.  In addition, though I loved the sets and photography, I would have held the long shots longer in "One Day More" and the "Finale" and done fewer rapid face shots.  These differences aside, I loved all of the other performances and was amazed that these famous actors could sing so well and do it while acting at the same time - all done live, not dubbed.  The performances were spectacular and I agree with the Oscar to Anne Hathaway.  She was brilliant.  I loved Hugh Jackman, as well, and Elizabeth Barks was terrific as Eponine.  I was totally moved by this motion picture and started an ovation at the end of the movie, joined by the others in the theater.  Even with my picking at certain differences, this was my favorite movie of the year (close with Argo and The Life of Pi) and I give it 5 stars.  I may have been a bit prejudiced by my love for the show in the first place.
summary: Not as good as the show, but still wonderful

reviewText: Victor Hugo's magnum opus "Les Miserables" has enjoyed a long life, first as a novel published in 1862, more recently as a musical, and now finally as a movie based on the musical.  Viewers be forewarned: if you like musicals, this movie is an excellent one; if you don't, it is a long movie with virtually every piece of dialogue done in song.The plot borrows from the novel.  The French thief and convict Valjean (Hugh Jackman) is paroled after a long sentence.  He has a life-changing experience after the kindness of a biship exposes him to the love of God.  Valjean will skip his parole and attempt to build a new life of good works.  In pursuit is the relentless police officer Javert (Russell Crowe), unshakeable in his sense of duty and in his conviction that Valjean can only ever be the thief he once was.  The two men will confront each other repeatedly over the years, as Valjean rescues Crossette,the orphaned child of the unfortunate prostitute Fantine (Anne Hathaway), raises the child (Amanda Seyfried as the adult Crossette) as his own, and later rescues her fiance Marius (Eddie Redmayne) after he is wounded in a revolution in Paris.  Along the way, Valjean will have also to suffer the mischief-making of the thief and con-man Thenardier and his wife (Sasha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter).The movie is incredibly well cast.  Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway are outstanding, carrying long pieces of the narrative with good voice and acting.  Russell Crowe adds depth and almost sympathy to the role of Javert, although he is the least accomplished singer in the cast.  And who knew that Amanda Seyfriend was such a good singer?The production values are absolutely first rate.  Many of the scenes are on location in England and France, and even the studio scenes are not necessarily obvious.  The special effects are kept to a minimum, but they pack a punch.  Perhaps the only obvious challenge was in delivering some of the expository songs in camera closeup, where the effect is different that it might be on stage.  On the other hand, the closing scene would have been less effective any other way, and should rightly have the viewer in tears.  "Les Miserables" the movie is very highly recommended.
summary: Les Miserables: at last the movie...

reviewText: The much anticipated movie adaptation of "Les Misérables " has arrived, and director Tom Hooper deserves praise for infusing Victor Hugo's iconic story of Jean Valjean with drama and profound emotion.  Hugh Jackman is superb as the former thief who is pursued relentlessly by his nemesis, Inspector Javert (a ruthless and bitter Russell Crowe), but Valjean focuses on redeeming himself by treating others with kindness.  Anne Hathaway is affecting as the desolate Fantine, forced into prostitution in order to support her child.  Valjean mercifully adopts Cosette, Fantine's daughter, after her mother's untimely death.Helena Bonham Carter and Sasha Baron Cohen are deliciously over-the-top as the Thénardiers, greedy innkeepers who steal from their customers and extort cash from Fantine for Cosette's upkeep while they keep the lonely girl in rags. Samantha Barks's show-stopping solo, "On My Own," is thrilling.  Eddie Redmayne and Amanda Seyfried are appealing as Marius and the adult Cosette.  Finally, the wonderful Colm Wilkinson lights up the screen in his brief appearance as the Bishop.Why see this film if you have already taken in the Broadway show?  First, Hooper distills the essence of the plot without getting bogged down in extraneous exposition.  He elicits terrific performances from actors whose faces and voices are beautifully expressive.  Since much of the dialogue is sung, it is worth pointing out that the sound quality is excellent and the performers take pains to speak and sing distinctly (not a given in today's films).  Claude-Michel Schönberg and Alain Boublil's score and Herbert Kretchmer's lyrics are often soaring, at other times tear-filled and poignant, and always unforgettable.The audience with whom we viewed "Les Miserables" was visibly moved by this tale of self-sacrifice, love, and salvation.  For an expensively mounted musical production, it is surprisingly intimate.  We grow to care about the characters and are transported from the darkened theater to the turbulence of nineteenth century France.  Vive "Les Misérables" and bravo to Tom Hooper and his exceptional cast.
summary: "There's a grief that can't be spoken."

reviewText: Les Miserables seems unsure if it's a musical or movie. I'm perfectly fine with musicals in the film medium.Mamma Mia! The Moviewas a great movie with quality singing, a well-paced story, and A-list actors who really delivered. However, even though I love Victor Hugo's novel and the Broadway musical, this film adaptation didn't work for me.The movie seems like it's a bunch of scenes strung together with Les Miserable music. I didn't get the sense that I was watching a movie with a coherent story. There are a lot of quick cuts from scene to scene that break up the storytelling a bit too much. Where in most musicals the camera tends to stay on a single scene or character, here it jumps around, breaking up the music.Another problem is the acting. With Russell Crowe, Hugh Jackman, and Anne Hathaway, this is an A-list cast. In fact, the producers seemed to go out of their way to get big names for this movie, even when they didn't fit. Unfortunately, it doesn't deliver an A-list performance. I never saw Valjean, Javert, or Fantine. Rather, I saw Crowe, Jackman, and Hathaway. They never really became their characters. That's one of the dangers of hiring celebrity actors for stories like Les Miserable with well established characters.Another problem is the singing. For a musical movie to work, the singing has to be good. If the movie had wanted to just tell the story in Victor Hugo's novel, it should have done so. But the director made a musical, which means the music is an important part. And again I think the A-list cast hurt the movie. I love the Les Miserable soundtrack, but I could never imagine listening to this movie's soundtrack. The actors mix emotional acting (e.g., loud sobbing) with the songs, which again suggests that it's not clear whether this movie wants to be a musical or traditional movie. I don't know if the movie should have avoided celebrity actors because Mamma Mia did it right, but maybe in this case that would have worked better.There is much to like about the movie. The sets and costumes are absolutely convincing. It looks like its set in early 19th century France. There are some nice creative choices, such as having the chain-gang at the beginning pull in a ship and dropping the French flag. So visually there's a lot that works. It just doesn't work for me as a musical movie.The movie also gets a LOT better after it reaches the 1832 part of the story. The revolutionary movement is portrayed really well. Great rendition of "Do You Hear the People..."  Really stirring. But again there are some uneven choices, with the musical portion and then a brief fight scene without any music. There's still a lot of "speaking-singing" rather than pure singing.Overall, I'd give this 3.25 stars. It's certainly not horrible and most fans of Les Miserable will at least enjoy it, even if they won't love it.

reviewText: When I first watched this movie, I really didn't like it. I didn't know that they were going to sing every line, so it seemed really weird to me. After watching it again, I can definitely say that this is one of my favorite musicals.The story is very good. The plot follows a man named Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), who is being hunted for breaking parol by a man named Javert (Russell Crowe). Through a series of events, Valjean is converted and becomes a successful mayor. However, Javert is persistent, and as soon as he learns where he is, he once again pursues the former criminal. It's a moving story, with very good characters. Although, it does run a little long. It's not too bad. In fact, the film doesn't get that good until about an hour into it.The songs are very memorable. Now as I said earlier, you have to understand that this is an opera. In other words, around five sentences are actually spoken. Everything else is sung. It may seem odd at first, but when you get used to it, it becomes okay. Whenever the song is actually well written (in other words, when it's not singing dialogue), the songs are excellent. Some of my favorites include "Do You Hear the People Sing?" and "One Day More." It's really neat to see all these big name actors show off their singing, even if some are sometimes a little shaky (*cough* Russell Crowe).Despite my original mixed reactions, I now really enjoy this movie. The story and characters are great, and the songs are excellent. If you want to see a good musical and understand that it's very much like an opera, this is one to you should definitely see.Final Score: 8.5/10

reviewText: I don't know who thought it was a good idea to gather a cast of people whose singing abilities are marginal at best for this masterpiece of a musical.  Let me start with Russel Crowe...absolutely fantastic actor.  But he cannot sing at all.  In the most impressive song of the musical "One Day More" his horrible non-melodic voice spoils the number. He can sing...but the role demands a much better voice than he can deliver.Eddie Redmayne as Marius looks frightfully weird in this production.  Why would Cosette go for this guy.  Another guy who can barely sing.  The styling is non-existent.Amanda Seyfried as Cosette looks great...but continues this movie's quest to make the songs as unremarkable as possible.Samantha Barks as Eponime does okay and looks great.  But if you've seen Lea Salonga sing this role, then you know how much better the character can be.I could go on and on, but you get the point.  This is a very mediocre production of what should have been a great movie.  The musical is my all time favorite and I've seen the live theater productions at least 5 times.My advice, is skip this one, and buy the 10th Anniversary concert of the musical with the "dream cast."  Once you hear that one, you'll want to toss this Blu Ray disc of the movie in the trash can.
