reviewText: I hate to disagree with so many fine reviews of this film, but disagree I must. Unfortunately for me at least, LES MISERABLES is a cinematic experience that might have been but fundamentally isn't.I think the fault for much of this lies in two decisions Tom Hooper made very early on in the process. First was the decision to, for the most part, rely upon actors rather than singers. I'm sure a sense of what constitutes good "box office" was a factor here, but, in the end, I think Mr. Hooper (and whoever else) should have had a bit more faith in the essential product. Sung well, with singers who can act, the production might have been truly memorable, even a classic of sorts, the product is that good. The final result, sadly, is rather less than it might have been.To Mr. Hooper's credit, Russell Crowe, as Javert, looks inspired. On paper. And I must admit I looked forward to his performance with great anticipation. Alas, despite Mr. Crowe's best efforts, he is not a confident singer, and most of his concentration seems focused on the vocal demands of the role - which are considerable - leaving little left over for the actor's projection of character. As a result, Javert seems flat, almost wooden. Alongside the performances of a few others in the cast - those who are singers first and actors second - the contrasting mix-and-match is unfortunate, sometimes painful. I thought Mr. Crowe deserved better.Mr. Crowe (and others), I think, were also undone by Mr. Hooper's second decision: recording and filming live. This is not unheard of, of course - for a particular character (Rex Harrison's Henry Higgins comes to mind) or a song here and there, but not an entire score. For a professional cast, three hours on stage is demanding enough. On the other hand, rehearsals and ten-hour shooting days, complete with retakes, must have been sheer torture, particularly for voices not sufficiently trained for it or accustomed to it. I know: dubbing and lip syncing the entire film would have been an arduous task, a task that probably would have produced uneven results at best. All the more reason, I would think, to opt for a cast of professional singers.By comparison, the other issues with the film seem almost nit-picking. Without question, film is a different medium than the stage. Even so, it's probably not a good idea to try to inject emotion into the proceedings by an unrelenting and almost terminal dependence on the close-up, to the point where the film, in places, suffers from a severe case of claustrophobia, a feeling entirely absent from the stage production. Then too, stage actors are supported emotionally by performing with a live orchestra. Singing - or attempting to sing - accompanied by an earpiece is just not the same. The adrenaline is missing, and, too often, the actors seem to be suffering from abandonment. Given all this, it is a wonder the cast was able to perform as well as it did.I guess the final question might well be whether it is possible to make LES MISERABLES into a successful film at all. Not any easy question, but one would have to guess that this particular attempt must have given a good many people serious pause. Yet I do think that, given the early decisions that were made, the film we got was as good as it COULD have been. It certainly never suffered from a lack of commitment or effort, and Mr. Hooper can certainly NOT be cited for a lack of courage. For me, however, the more satisfying and emotional performances are presented in either of the Anniversary Editions, both of which were taped live and both of which are still currently available. I think they more fairly represent what LES MISERABLES was meant to be.This is not to say DON'T BUY THE DVD OF THE FILM. They are simply very different experiences. For myself, I bought all three.

reviewText: It is worth noting that the French regard Victor Hugo as a poet and consider his novels, including the 1862 LES MISERABLES, minor works.  The novel became popular in America during the Civil War, when it was widely read by the Confederacy, who often refered to the book as "Lee's Miserables."  Thereafter, like many Victorian-era novels, it enjoyed cyclical popularity until 1980, when it was adapted into an operetta with lyrics by Alain Boublil and music by Claude-Michel Schonberg.  The original production played for three months in Paris.  It was subsequently further adapted by Herbert Kretzmer and James Fenton into the English language, and opened in London in 1985 and then in New York in 1987.  The London and New York versions were extremely popular at the box office and ran for years.  The original New York production alone ran for over six thousand performances.None of this has actually made critics like the show any better than they originally did, and it has been consistently described as manipulative, sentimental, and unoriginal.  The film version was an on-again, off-again affair, finally debuting in 2012.  Musicals generally have their musical numbers pre-recorded, and the cast lip-sychs during filming.  For LES MISERABLES, however, the singers performed live on set, and some publicity claims indicated this was the first time such had been done (not true; live on-set musical numbers go back at least as far to Doris Day in the 1957 THE PAJAMA GAME.)  Since most of the film cast were not trained singers, the result was somewhat hit or and miss, with Russell Crowe receiving significantly negative comments--but when it did work, it worked spectacularly, with Anne Hathaway giving a devastating performance and picking up an Oscar for her efforts.  But again, critics were not really any more enthusiastic about the film than they had been about the play.  Many noted that if you liked the play, you would probably like the film, but if you didn't like the play, nothing about the film would make you change your mind.  I didn't and it didn't.Although the movie is not noticeably like the book, it has much the same story, and a good many people have described it as "the show where everybody sings about how poor they are and then most of them die."  Although acid, this is actually a fairly straight forward comment, for the plot traces the troubles of Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), imprisoned for almost twenty years on a trivial charge and, when he breaks parole, relentlessly persued by the French law in the form of Javert (Russell Crowe.)  Ill-starred lovers and angry revolutionaries round out the tale.  Curiously, the film relies a great deal on CGI, which tended to undercut my belief in the story, but my primary dismissal of LES MISERABLES rests on the fact that it is two and a half hours of overwrought emotion, with every single character playing at the same hysterical pitch.  It does not help that the music is incredibly, incredibly repetitive; virtually every song echoes every other song (I began to feel I was a trapped in an endless loop of "At The End of the Day" and "Bring Him Home.")  Within thirty minutes I was exhausted and by the end of the film I was thoroughly over it.  Still, the occasional good performance (especially Hathaway) makes it worth the effort.  Depending on which version you get, the DVD comes with various bonuses, none of them particularly interesting.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviewText: I wanted to see this film in theaters and never made it.  Then I bought the Best Buy Exclusive Steelbook Blu-Ray.  Next I waited until my fiance' and her teenage daughter were both at home and finally settled in to watch what I was sure would be a great film filled with wondrous musical numbers; man was I ever disappointed.  Granted my expectations were high.  Still; from the opening scene I was sure the film was going to deliver.  Ultimately I wound up going back and forth between hating the film and liking it.  There are some truly standout performances; most notable among them being Anne Hathaway who really bared her soul to deliver the song "I Dreamed a Dream."Sadly that was the one true highlight in an otherwise tedious and long-winded film.  It carries with it the particular frustration that a lot of the songs that follow sound just like that song.  Hugh Jackman can act and does so well in the film; however, his singing is a particular annoyance that is only surpassed by how truly awful Russell Crowe sings.  That is something you must know going in...every single line is sung in this film.  I know it is a musical; however, this decision was really poorly conceived.  The high production values insure the film looks good and yet the story makes leaps that are simply not explained.  Only those forgiving enough or familiar with the novel, the musical and even the earliest film version will make the connections and fill in the blanks.  All in all the film was a painful experience for me and I regretted this being my fiance's and her daughter's first exposure to Les Miserables.
summary: Know this before you watch the film...

reviewText: The problem with this musical is that the characters sing 99% of time (and time they have). There is no tension, no dramatic force, no rhythm (or too much rhythm perhaps); you don't see the development of a story that has to be told in an specific way, with economy of means, to make an impression in the viewer; only an almost uninterrupted flow of songs not exactly great, sung by not very great singers, with great productions values and nothing else. The actors were not acting: they were singing, with facial expressions and a choreography very similar to the one that you find in a Leona Lewis video: not bad, but hardly an Oscar material. (The credibility of The Oscars is another issue.)
summary: A very long and expensive music video.

reviewText: Jackman did a better job than I expected going in. His voice is thin and tight on the high stuff, but he acts well. Hathaway is not as good as the pro reviewers say she is, but is passable. Most of the cast is adequate. None are great.The production is quite nice. Sets are very good, direction is good, costumes are good.I will single out Russel Crowe here as the reason for the removal of a star all by himself. He is mind-numbingly awful. I cannot express how terrible he is at this role and how blisteringly awful a singer he is. Just terrible. Pathetic. He does well in Gladiator because he can just stand there and look brooding and angry. None of that flies in this role. His acting here is his same schtick, and it doesn't fit. Now, his singing is even worse. His tone is like a foghorn in pain, he has no subtlety, no control, no support, no diction and no expression. Whomever the director of casting that thought he would be good in this role made the worst decision of his/her career.The movie with Liam Neeson  and the always excellent Jeffrey Rush (not a musical) is a better production. If you want the musical, there are plenty of much better options. Pick one with Philip Quast to wash the stink of of Russel Crowe's voice out of your ears.So, one star gone for being adequate but not great and one star gone just for the awfulness of Crowe.
summary: Surpirised by Jackman, but Crowe is the definition of awful

reviewText: Les Misérables Is an experience. Director Tom Hooper has realized this timeless and often repeated Victor Hugo novel that was transformed into a near operatic setting by Claude-Michel Schönberg, Alain Boublil and Herbert Kretzmer by opening up the story even more and utilizing genuinely creative musical enhancements. The result is an emotionally charged, breathtaking spectacle that while it is discussing the French Revolution and aftermath as a subject it remains a gently warm tale of love and commitment.The cast is extraordinary, down to the smallest role in the film. It is truly an Ensemble work and deserves recognition as such, but the individuals should also be honored individually.  Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean is completely immersed in this multifaceted and very difficult role: it is the zenith of his career both as a film and as a stage actor/singer. Equally impressive (and a surprise to those of us who knew nothing of this early career in musical theater) is Russell Crowe's Javert - very deserving of Best Supporting Actor at Oscar time for his powerful embodiment of misguided and tortured head of police, but for some reason he is being overlooked. Anne Hathaway gives us a Fantine that will be the benchmark for all others who sing this role. Amanda Seyfried handles Cosette's difficult soprano lines with relative ease and feels completely right in her approach to the role. Another major shock is Eddie Redmayne as Marius: we all are aware of his acting sills, but this young man has a splendid voice and makes his character one of the standouts of the story. Samantha Barks as Éponine is a star turn, combining screen presence with fine acting and a solid vocal ability.Each of the lads who spark the revolutionary barricade is outstanding; Aaron Tveit as Enjolras completely wins hearts with his handsome looks, his sensitive acting and his very fine voice and close behind him is performance quality are George Blagden, Killian Donnelly, Fra Fee, Gabriel Vick and for course Daniel Huttlestone as the young spunky Gavroche. Director Hooper has given us a different take on the Thénardiers - no silly slapstick here, but instead a smarmy, oily evil couple whose behavior at other people's expense make us laugh: Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen make them unforgettable. And it is a true bow to theatrical history to cast Colm Wilkinson (who originated the role of Jean Valjean in 1980) as the Bishop.In all this is a stunning success, visually, vocally, acting, directing, costuming, and large ensemble wise.  It is unforgettable.  Highly Recommended.  Grady Harp, December 12
summary: A deeply moving, masterfully crafted masterpiece

reviewText: AGAIN, the musical of a decade. This is the Les Mis crème de la crème. It has revolutionary action; heart felt romance; faith-forgiveness-retribution; aesthetic musical. Hugh Jackman as John Valjean, convict 24601, looks the ferocious revolutionary facially; sings fiercefully, romantically, and beautifully; and deserves his Oscar nomination. As does this film. My vote has changed from Spielberg's "Lincoln" to "Les Mis" after one viewing. I WILL go back, I will buy the DVD.Les Mis is a musical, it's about music, arguably the best ever written for the stage. This film version of the 18th century French chronicle has raised the bar for film musicals. This well known story and theatre hit has been upgraded via film. It takes the best of what theatre has to offer and adds close-up, a mega cast, and music perfection that makes this film-musical ever more magical.Close-ups allow the stunning singers to add powerful facial emotion to the well-known Les Mis lyrics, right down to nasal hairs, warts, moles, freckles on a comrade, tears flowing into snot, and the sweat of love. Fantine (Oscar nominated Anne Hathaway) is stellar in song, but I'd give an Oscar to her daughter Cosette (Amanda Seyfried- `Mama Mia!') with her voice, body, face, and acting performance.I didn't know Russell Crowe [Javert] could sing, and do it well, too.The young lad on the barricade, Gavroch, was Daniel Huttlestone in his first film role, but surely not his last. He also played Gavroch in Queen's Theatre performances. What a voice.Costumes & sets are spectacles all their own. You almost smell the 1700s.Les Mis theme comes from one of it's songs, "To love another person is to see the face of God."But the film ended and I had to leave, c'est la vie.IT'S THE FIRST TIME I HAVE EVER GIVEN ROLLING CREDITS ON A SCREEN A STANDING OVATION.The film was as alive as the theatre stage. A tour de force. C'est magnifique!
summary: Vive Les Mis, a MAGESTIC production, an EMERSING MUSICAL

reviewText: Last Monday I WENT TO THE gala opening tonight of LES MISERABLES with Gorm Gylterud and let me tell you that it is a epic drama spectacular proportions and production values!It is like Andrew Lloyd Webber(Evita 1996 and The Phantom of the Opera 2004) but WITH intelligence....The first and last half are certainly the best; the middle DOES outstay its welcome at times... but on the whole it is a beautiful cinematic transcription of the famous French musical....To my mind it will be a landmark in the genre of the musical film.The audience indeed applauded after various experiences of catharsis.....Anne Hathaway bring memories back to Falconetti as Joan of Arc 1928 and Marion Cotillard as Piaf in La Mome:-)Her artistry is indeed a treasure to behold.... as is Hugh Jackman in the first half..... it is a pending pain to see these two.. their involvement in their characters are complete.A major letdown are the Thenardiers.... On stage they are played with vigour, color and camp; Helena Bonham Carter and Sashca Baron Cohen let us totally down in their low key interpretations....They audience cheered and left silently and exhausted after an almost 3 hour run

reviewText: Christmas day, 11am, I was there.  I am a big fan of musicals, so I loved watching a movie with "live" singing.  I wasn't that familiar with the story going in, and fortunately it was very understandable on the big screen.  I instantly became enthralled.  The first scene with the prisoners dragging the massive ship was incredible.  Fantine was excellent, and she did have a significant role.  I felt she did have an adequate amount of screen time and her her scenes were packed with evocative acting.The singing was top notch, Eddie Redmayne in particular.  Some of the notes he hit were so high, pure and perfect.  Russell Crowe has gotten a bad rap for his singing, but I really thought it was fine given that he plays a character you're not supposed to like anyway.  Hugh Jackman was so handsome with his curly hair.  I didn't like the revolution part so much, but it was obviously part of the story and the second time I saw the movie it wasn't as long as it seemed on my first viewing.  Not to give anything away, there was a scene when there were tears galore.  Go and see it, see it, see it.
summary: if you're a musical person or not, a must see

reviewText: This was not a typical musical with talking and some singing (such as Dick van Dyke or Julie Andrews movies), but was singing all the way through.  The movie, based on a musical which itself is based on a book, was so-so, and should have been rated R.  It left many of us crying in the theater at the end.  I'm glad I read some of the book and know much of the original French concept album, so that I could actually understand what did NOT come through in this movie.  Thénadier and wife remind me of Bozo the Clown and what he'd have for a wife.  In the original French concept album but not the book, they actually WERE funny in their singing, but their inn was no whorehouse.  I think Hollywood overdid it with its typically dirty mind, and all in all, I was  rather disappointed.

reviewText: Les Miserables 2012 was a very ambitious production. The first half of the movie I would give four stars because there were a few scenes that I didn't completely like the way they were done, a few camera angles seem too close up, and a few other parts seemed rushed through, and maybe it's just me but I couldn't understand every word that was sung, and with 99 percent of it being sung when the 1 percent that's not sung it seems odd in hoping they would finally do some talking but they didn't. Although, it's understandable they wanted to pick up the pace to get to the rest of the story. There could have been a few more scenes to show the relationship between Valjean and Cosette. Isabelle Allen was very good as the young Cosette and she could have had a few more scenes as well. Samantha Barks as Eponine was amazing. Aaron Tveit as Enjolras was perfect in bringing the strong desire of the revolution to fight for freedom. Because Les Miserables 2012 was a musical it was phenomenal in expressing the strength of emotions of the revolution. This was similar to the Les Miserables Tenth Anniversary Concert dvd (with Ruthie Henshall, Lea Salonga, and others) that I give 10 Stars because the finale is epic. In Les Miserables 1998 Geoffrey Rush was excellent with ruthlessness, and Liam Neeson was great in showing mercy and being humble, but the 1998 version was not a musical. Les Miserables 2012 is a musical and the second half of the movie I give five stars and the ending scene is SPECTACULAR.
summary: The second half of Les Miserables 2012 is SPECTACULAR

reviewText: Life has not been easy for the people of France during this revolutionary period.  Many of the poor people were leading lives of slavery.Freedom, liberation was not something that they mustered much hope to receive.  Many took to the streets and lived lives of desperation, seeking food, medicine, shelter, clothing and money any way that they could find.  This led to alcoholism, stealing, prostitution and selling any earthly possessions, including their own being.Redemption is the living word of this story.The choice is always ours.

reviewText: The success of Les Miserables hinges on the chemistry and power of the two lead characters, Jean Valjean and Javier.  Miss that dynamic and the musical will spiral down a pit of unrecoverable failure.  This over hyped Hollywood blockbuster rendition broke the cardinal rule and ends up a flat, boring, directionless mess of a musical film.The obvious issue is Russell Crowe is abysmal in this performance.  It's not his fault.  He's a decent actor but should never have been in this role.  Javier needs to be an energetic, powerful man of convictions and hatred.  Not only could Crowe not sing up to the standards demanded of the role but he doesn't even act.  Most of his performances have him standing rigidly squeaking out his lines and not even coming close to anything of the stage variety.  Javier has probably the most powerful songs in the production yet Crowe couldn't take advantage of that.Then add in Jackman.  Jackman has stage experience but again this role doesn't seem quite right for him.  I blame direction for this.  Jackman has to move from spoken word to singing on several occasions and it just makes the whole experience seem awkward.  I felt Hugh could have sang better in this performance.  He is passable but I would rather have seen him in Javier's role as it would suit him better.  Perhaps the nail in the coffin for Jackman is his most pivotal scenes require him to go up against Russel Crowe.  Valjean needs to stand up to Javier and play off his power but the two are a close match.  Here in this production you can tell Jackman could easily overpower Crowe and so Hugh holds back.  It really makes for some awkward screen moments and wasted opportunity.That leads me to the biggest problem with this film.  It has no direction at all.  It feels as if the director just grabbed the biggest name actors he could get and just let them do whatever they wanted.  There is virtually no chemistry between any of the characters.  Its as if the scenes in the film are the first time the actors are actually working together.  This is all wrong.  All wrong entirely.  Carter and Cohen's roles of the crooked innkeepers are prime example.  Both of these actors are capable of crazy characters but they are completely flat here.  Carter was the biggest disappointment as I really thought she could bring something to that role.  When I read some reviews here about how marvelous they were I almost choked.  Cohen is a mess.  His lines are all out of sync and there is no chemistry between he and Carter which was a major shame.  The only duet that seems to have any chemistry is Marius and Cosette.  Beyond that all of the scenes just feel cold, broken, and bland.  Even the slam dunk bar scenes are a mess.  I just couldn't shake the constant feelings that these scenes were lackluster outtakes rather than finished product.  Real shame.The highlights of the film are decent cinematography although it is repetitive.  The score is virtually the same as the musical so little has changed there and the ensemble cast is as good as always.  The biggest irony is that out of all the star power in this film it is Samantha Barks (Eponine) that walks away with the best performance although Anne Hathaway did surprise me for how well she did considering what I expected from her.In the end I just think this movie had no direction.  It's truly the worst rendition of this masterpiece I have ever seen and I have seen this a lot on Broadway, off broadway, even high school productions were better than this.  The actors cast just were not up to par with the quality of what the roles demand and worse, the director is so poor he exposes their weakness even more by putting them in awkward scenes with broken cadences and strange spoken word segments.Les Mis is all about the chemistry of the roles.  Valjean v. Javier.  Eponine v. Cosette v. Marius.  The innkeeprs v. the world.  These dynamics are imperative to succeed with this production and the Director completely missed.  Better voices would have greatly improved this busted vision of a classic but I think a better director would have made significantly better choices even with poor acting.If you must rent this but skip it otherwise.  So many better productions of this story out there.  A big budget is not all it should take.  This isn't even a movie.  It's a collection of dress rehearsal lackluster outtakes roughly edited together to resemble something of video.

reviewText: I must have seen Les Miz live about 20 times so I was interested to catch up on the movie given all the hype. I also know at least a dozen musical nerds who love the stage version but their opinions were even divided on the film. I saw it and really enjoyed the whole thing much to the shock of my nerd friends who had the following issues.If you're a staunch fan of the live musical, you're not going to be happy about the abridgements made in some of the most popular songs. Additionally, there are deviations from the stage version that are apparently more faithful to the original novel but potentially a little unnerving. If you're a 'light fan' you may not even notice these changes and may frankly thank them for keeping the length manageable.I was personally blown away by Anne Hathaway and Hugh Jackman in both their singing and performance - clearly stand out, Oscar-winning performances if ever they were any. Nerds were not convinced that these were the best Fantine and Valjean compared to the London and New York stage versions to which I shake my head in disbelief. Seriously, both actors give everything to their parts here and carry the 'emotional necessity' of the roles perfectly. Actually, a big thumbs up to the make up for both characters too - they look truly beaten down.I'd heard that Russell Crowe was a disaster and he was - partly because the other singers are in a different league. Since the entire film was performed live to camera (rather than recorded and lip-sync'd), he clearly struggles and there's no post production on the sound to hide it. But the big shocker is Amanda Seyfried who sings her little heart out in Mamma Mia but crashes and burns with a warbly, kind-of-operatic Cosette.On a technical note, although the sets were excellent, the connecting CGI was dreadful - watching the opening scene with 50 real people in real water tugging a large fake boat wasn't a great way to open. It's a shame since the rest of the scene was really great. Additionally, the camerawork is fairly sloppy throughout - the actors were allowed perform without hitting marks so occasionally the camera operators go out of their way to get them back in the frame and the focus puller is working overtime. Similarly, this causes problems with the lighting so some of the singing scenes are very dark as the camera catches up with the actor.Overall, it's a very good adaptation with a couple of flaws but nevertheless was better than most films in 2012. It's easily accessible to those who haven't seen it before all the way up the musical groupies who critique every line of dialog.

reviewText: I have been in love with this musical since I first saw it in Philadelphia in the late-1980s, and had been eagerly anticipating the movie for months. It did not disappoint! The live recording (rather than lip-synch) works marvelously. Every note, emotion, and tone is perfect. I particularly appreciated the director's comments, which helped me understand how Tom Hooper cut portions of some songs, reordered songs or scenes, and overall improved the flow of the story from the stage version, while retaining the full impact of the musical. This appears to be a "love-it-or-hate-it" movie. My wife and I loved it, but that does not mean it's for everyone. For my money, Les Miz should have won the Oscar for Best Picture, and Hugh Jackman for Best Actor.
summary: Absolutely fabulous! (But you probably would have first needed to see the Broadway production)

reviewText: The first time I saw the stage production of Les Miserables, I was blown away. I had never loved a musical before and I didn't expect this one to be any different. But it WAS different. Almost every line was sung making it almost more like an opera, which I had never been a huge fan of either, but something about Les Miserables grabbed me and wouldn't let go. I have been a huge fan of it ever since, right down to owning 2 different versions of the soundtrack, the London Cast recording AND the Broadway Cast recording, both of which have areas and performances that exceed the other (hence the reason for owning both).So I was very hesitantly excited about this movie version. It had some great actors attached, but could those actors sing? It was rumored to be faithful to the stage version, including the long running time, but how well would that transfer to film?After having finally seen it in it's last week in theaters, I can say with some relief that I very much enjoyed it, but I didn't quite love it as much as I hoped I would (although I suspect my admiration will increase slightly upon repeated viewings now that I've read some interviews and watched some "making of" videos). There were some things that held it back from greatness, but still managed to allow it to meet my expectations in certain areas and even exceed them in others.The stage production is really fundamentally about the singing. I mean, the sets and costumes are great, but not everyone is close enough to see the emotion through facial expressions so it has to be conveyed in the song. But a movie is full of close ups and expressions become very important, and a movie would get boring very quickly if the only expression on the actors face in every scene is "eyes closed, mouth wide open". So there has to be a little give and take in translating this to film.The acting is uniformly excellent, no complaints. The power and emotion of various scenes are easily conveyed by the strength and skill of the actors, but not always by the strength and conviction of their singing. Hugh Jackman is an excellent example of this. His performance is fantastic, he plays the role extremely well and is able to make you feel both his suffering and his joy by his ability as an actor, but his singing, while commendable, is far from overwhelming. The fact that the songs were recorded live during filming so the actors could set the tone of the scene, as opposed to being recorded in a sound booth and dubbed into the film later, adds to the power of the scene but detracts from the power of the song. Give and take.Anne Hathaway has received a lot of attention for her portrayal of Fantine, all of which is very much deserved. She truly earned each and every award she's won. But I also have to give special accolades to Eddie Redmayne for his performance of "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables", which is my absolute favorite song in Les Miserables, and in my opinion is the 2nd strongest performance after Anne's "I Dreamed a Dream".I've listened to the London and Broadway recordings dozens of times each, but I don't think the soundtrack to this movie will hold up as well without the added visuals since so much of the actual power behind the scenes lies in the actors "physical" performance and presence, although I will probably still buy it even if just for a few certain songs.Overall the review on Blu-ray.com sums up my feelings about the film almost perfectly. All those things I couldn't quite put my finger on are explained very well there, but in the end I also agree with the reviewer that this film largely succeeds in spite of these things and I have every intention of buying it and watching it over and over again because a few key scenes are absolutely amazing enough to justify it.
summary: There's a give and take involved in translating this production to film...

reviewText: "Do You Hear the People Sing?" Yes, we do! And the Oscar buzz has become a roar, with American Anne Hathaway's name on the tip of everyone's tongue! British director Tom Hooper ("The King's Speech") takes a legendary story and brings the (stage) musical version to the screen for the first time. He has a massive cast of talented performers and neither time nor space allow me to dwell on more than a few. Let me warn you however: if you don't like musicals, there are only one or two words actually spoken, everything else is sung.The battles in this PG-13 story are no more than minor skirmishes in the all-over scheme of the French Revolution, but the fatalities are just as dead, nonetheless.A couple of doughty actors from Down Under head this cast:* Hugh Jackman ("Real Steel") is Jean Valjean, the fellow who stole a loaf of bread for his starving little sister and as a result, spent many years behind bars. (Victor Hugo, like his contemporary Charles Dickens, born 10 years later, was a social reformer.) Mr. Jackman has been embraced by the Broadway crowd and is an established musical star. When he rescues little Cosette from the rapacious couple who have been her caretakers, he sings "Suddenly," the only original song written for this movie.* Russell Crowe ("A Beautiful Mind") is Javert, the steadfast policeman determined to uphold the law after Valjean breaks parole. Until recently Mr. Crowe had his own musical group, "30 Odd Foot of Grunts" with which he performed when not acting or living on his cattle station in the Outback. Usually Javert is played by a powerful baritone and although Crowe gives it his all, this just isn't his type of music.* Anne Hathaway ("The Dark Knight Rises") is Fantine, the desperate woman who sells her hair to wig-makers in order to feed her daughter Cosette. We've never known Ms. Hathaway to sing professionally before, but she doesn't embarrass herself; "I Dreamed a Dream" is filmed "live" and is heartfelt and personal.* Samantha Barks ("Les Misérables in Concert: the 25th Anniversary") is the adult version of Éponine, the heartbreakingly loyal young woman who loves the rebel Marius. It is immediately obvious that Barks is a stage-trained musical performer however her death-scene "A Little Fall of Rain" is poignant but almost whispered.* Amanda Seyfreid ("Gone") is the young adult Cosette, taken under Jean Valjean's powerful wing with no hint remaining of her mother's sacrifice. Seyfreid was formerly in "Mamma Mia!" Enough said about her.* Eddie Redmayne ("My Week With Marilyn") is the rebel Marius, who is head-over-heels in love with Cosette. Redmayne's work has been (mostly) with BBC-type miniseries ("The Pillars of the Earth" and "Tess of the D'Urbervilles") but no musicals. He sings "Red and Black," remember that one?* Colm Wilkinson ("Evita" on stage) is the priest who saves Valjean when he steals the silver at the beginning, and he is there to usher him into Heaven at the end. I loved this perfect touch, as he was the ultimate Jean Valjean on stage. I got the 25th Anniversary Concert DVD from Amazon, and he is thrilling! I'm glad they asked him to appear here.This story covers a generation and has so many layers you may be tempted to see it again just to master the wonderful plot. Unless, of course, you read Victor Hugo's book, first published in 1862. I know I did...about a century later...smile...I'm sorry the production design people chose to ramp up the disgusting bits and the fright wigs. There really is no need for this over-the-top assault, the story can stand on its own without sensationalism. Tsk, tsk....

reviewText: I don't often review films, but after seeing Les Misérables on the big screen a couple of days ago, I wanted to express my thoughts. The film is a cinematic tour de force of Victor Hugo's classic nineteenth century novel, but based much more closely on the musical drama that was first produced onstage in 1985. My tattered old Signet Classic paperback is almost 1,500 pages. The film is just over 2 hours, so there were a lot of details and subplots that were cut from the book, but in the end, the filmmakers did a nice job of preserving the essence of the story.A couple of weeks before seeing the movie, my wife and I saw a short "making of" feature about the movie. The really fascinating detail of the movie was that director Tom Hooper chose the most unusual method of recording vocals live on the set instead of the traditional method of pre-recording the vocals in a studio months in advance. Both Hooper and the actors believed that this choice of production method would make the film feel much more emotional, raw, and real. In my opinion, their approach was very successful.That was one big difference between Les Misérables and virtually every other film version of a stage musical. The other big difference was that there was almost no dialogue - every utterance by the actors was in song, making the movie come across more like grand opera than the traditional American and British musical format. And the actors delivered in a big way. I knew that Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway could sing, but who knew that Russell Crowe could?The bottom line: A great story translated into a great musical film, with one of the finest performances in years from Ms. Hathaway in her rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream," a mournful lament, sung by the anguished and impoverished Fantine, who reminisced about happier times and wondered at all that has gone wrong in her life. It's a beautiful song that wrings a lot of emotion from the audience. By the way, the song that Anne Hathaway sings in the trailer for Les Misérables is not the same version that she sings in the movie. The trailer version sounds more like a concert performance taken out of context from the story, and it's only about 1:20 long. The movie version is 4:38 and really delivers the full power and pathos of the song.
summary: A cinematic tour de force of Hugo's classic novel

reviewText: I saw this film at a theater on the big screen. I went alone and found myself emotionally overwhelmed. Sitting alone I cried for the fallen angel, Fantine played by Anne Hathaway. As I watched I found myself identifying with her character and her character's suffering, disappointment and despair. Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean found the essence of his character whether he was hating, stealing or later kind and charitable. His emotion was always right there and I didn't have to guess at what he was feeling as Valjean at any time during the film. Russell Crowe, on the other hand, played the part just as he played Gladiator. He was Russell Crowe singing. I was taken with Amanda Siefried as Cosette. Her performance showed a depth of emotion that I haven't seen in her before. Her flute-like voice was perfect and totally complemented the company of stronger voices that could have overwhelmed but didn't. Eddie Redmayne as Marius was a wonderful surprise. I saw him in Elizabeth the Golden Years as the assassin and while he was convincing in that role he was exceptional as Marius. His performance could be light and sweet or painfully sad and suffering as required. His was a performance that sent me into tears. The young men of the Revolution were wonderful. Not one slacked off because they were in a chorus. Each stood out as his own memorable person. There's nothing to say about the young boy who played Gavroche. He took the street urchin role to a whole new level and never missed a beat. Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonhomme Carter were perfect as innkeeper and wife. The customers of the inn (the dissolutes) were truly gross, but that was the point. This film is even more amazing when you realize the actors were singing their roles in real time. I've watched this film at least ten times since it was delivered and it didn't lose any impact going from the big screen to my old 32 inch 17 year-old Sony. I still cry.

reviewText: As someone who has never read this book or seen the play I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised.  I was wary of watching it because I usually stick to action/sci-fi or horror movies.  I do love musicals, but I was under the impression for some reason that this was boring and sad.  While it is sad (I cried through much of the second half of it), it was anything but boring.  I loved every minute of it.  The casting was perfect.  The actors all had beautiful voices.  I was most surprised by Russell Crowe.  His voice has a really pleasant, warm tone to it.  Anne Hathaway surprised me as well.  She has a beautiful, very high voice that can also reach down deep.  I was disappointed that she didn't have more songs.  I also really loved the girl who played Eponine, Samantha Barks.  She definitely had the most professional sounding voice, and I hope to see her in many more films.  Eddie Redmayne was awesome too.  He has a really beautiful voice.  Besides the acting and singing, the story itself is incredibly exciting.  By the end of the movie you feel as though you have lived Jean Valjean's entire adult life with him.  I really can't picture anyone else but Hugh Jackman in the role, and I really don't think I would ever want to see the play because I just don't think anyone could compare to him, in both emotion and acting.  Believe me, if you like musicals at all you will like this one.  It's brilliant and beautiful.
summary: "To love another person is to see the face of God"

reviewText: What a splendid film adaptation of the beloved musical!To my (very moist) eyes, it works as well -- and perhaps even better -- on a small screen than it did in theaters, thanks to the abundant closeups on the actors.And what a moving experience...  Anne Hathaway certainly deserved her Best Supporting Actress Oscar for her work as Fantine.  If there was another performance last year as impacting, considering the brevity of her appearance onscreen here, I would like to know what it was.Other standouts in the cast include Hugh Jackman, of course, as Jean Valjean, plus fresh faces Eddie Redmayne and Samantha Barks from the London theater cast as Eponine.Then there is Russell Crowe as Javert.  His singing is rather painful, but then I suppose gendarmes are not known for their way with a melody.  Crowe is otherwise well cast as the resolute policeman.The only slight negative I might cite with this production is the sonic flatness of the musical score.  This is not a problem with the DVD; I noticed it as well in the theater.  For some reason, the orchestra doesn't sound rich and full; it sounds rather thin and compressed.  I don't know if the sound engineer was going for a restrained effect to match the miseries of the characters, but fans of this glorious music may be underwhelmed.Otherwise I'm happy to report that despite the length of the movie, the DVD includes some fine extras, including features on the cast, the sets, Victor Hugo and the novel, plus director's commentary with Tom Hooper.So vive la revolution -- and this classic adaptation of Les Mis.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hugh Jackman opens his mouth to sing. Or rather scream.The camera moves steadily to his dirt-grimed face, his pop-eyed reddened eyes, his bulging veins,  that open, trembling mouth.We're within an inch of his quivering lips and can even see the back of his exhausted throat.I was hoping that the use of CGI could keep moving the camera until we were traveling down into the interior of the actor's body to show us how it must look before someone has a heart attack.Director Tom Hooper made much internet buzz when he gleefully announced that instead of using pre-recorded singing, all his cast would sing ALIVE!Bad mistake.It was even bad back in the early talkies when movie makers discovered that singers would look, and sound much better, when they lip-synced to their vocals.Watching all the performers straining to perform live vocals for the cameras was a nerve-wracking experience for this viewer.I kept thinking of the endless takes it must have taken to get the perfect one.Worse, none of the performers sounded any better for being forced to sing live for the cameras.Russell Crowe was so miscast that I winced every time he opened his mouth emit sounds that were supposed to be singing.Anne Hathaway, covered with grime, dirt, her hair shorn, resembled the inmate of a Nazi concentration camp.Her bony face, bulging eyes and hideously bedraggled attire repulsed, rather than engendered pity.Yet, I've read that when she gabbled the famous, "I Dream a Dream," many female viewers sobbed hysterically and had to leave the theater.Okay, call me old-fashioned. I like my musicals to exude vibrant, beautiful costumes, color, talent and story line. Like "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers," "Westside Story" and yes, even "Mama Mia." Yes, we all know the singers would be mouthing the words to an already recorded track, but that didn't mar our delight to hear sometimes unforgettable vocalizing.For me, trying to enjoy a nearly three hour long movie that looks like it was filmed through a pile of mud and dirt, where everybody resembles someone whose been dipped in a coal mine, and thin, wavering voices that made me close my eyes in pain, I'll take those glorious musicals of the olden days!
summary: How to Recognize a Heart Attack: Watch La Miz

reviewText: Take any 15 minutes from this musical film and compare it to any entire film or Broadway adaption of Les Miserables and this musical blows them all away! I had the pleasure of comparing the Broadway CD (I picked up recently at goodwill) and these performances are leagues above the broadway production. There may be better singing voices in the Broadway performances, but they are too artificial and polished. What this musical does in spades is grab you with so much heartfelt emotion. Many songs the performers do while they are crying! They pause and get choked up while the music waits for them! I personally have never seen so much drama in a musical. Annne Hathway's song has to be the most dramatic song in musical history. Those gut wrenching 4 minutes gave her an academy award. Jackman and Hathway both lost their weight and hair just for their roles! This cast is amazing!The production, photography and basically everything are excellent! My only complaint is as a follower of Jesus, I am uncomfortable watching the foulness during the song by Sacha Bara Coen. I skip that part for it does nothing to advance the story anyways.
summary: I personally have never seen so much drama in a musical

reviewText: The cinematography was superb, the production values were first rate, the acting was, for the most part, very good (Russell Crowe being the glaring exception), but the director's decision to use this particular cast to sing these songs is an abomination. What was he thinking? Is he tone deaf?, Or, does he just hate the musical and this was his way of getting back at it. While Amanda Seyfried as Cossette, Eddie Redmayne as Marius and Samantha Barks as Eponine did credible jobs on their songs, it could not make up for the awful caterwauling of Crowe, Jackman and Hathaway. I'm only giving it three stars because my wife said I was being too harsh giving only two. I disagree, but sometimes discretion is the better part of valor, and she is, after all, my wife and I love her.

reviewText: I have seen the stage musical 8 times as this is my all time favorite musical. I could not wait for the movie to be released and I was not disappointed. Hugh Jackman, who I saw on Broadway in "The Boy From Oz", was superb and has a great voice, as was Anne Hathaway. Russel Crowe is not the best singer, but was excellent in his role. I think the critics made up their mind before they saw the movie that they were going to find fault. And who are these idiots? They are strangers to me. Why should I take the word of someone I don't know who tells me what I should see and not see. These are the people who raved about "The Book of Mormon" which is the single worst musical I have ever seen in my life.So ignore the so called critics. Be your own voice. Word of mouth is strong. This movie is magnificent. I cannot wait for the Blu-Ray to come out. In the meantime, I'm going back to the theatre to see it again.So now I have the Blu-Ray and what a magnificent picture and sound on this disc. I'd give it 10 stars if I could. Highly recommended. reviewText: A long time ago Hollywood had actors who were also more than competent singers and dancers, I am thinking of course of Judy Garland, Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly and Liza Minnelli. When they decided to use movie stars in musicals, like Deborah Kerr in the King and I, Natalie Wood in West Side Story or Audrey Hepburn in My Fair Lady they at least had the decency of using a good singer for the musical numbers, like the much missed (and needed) Marni Nixon, who dubbed Kerr, Wood and Hepburn. But recently something really outrageous is happening, they are asking Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter to sing Sweeney Todd (an aberration), and now Hugh Jackman and Russsell Crowe embarrass themselves in Les Misérables. The vocal demands in this musical are greater than average, and I can't possibly agree with Amazon who says:  <Crowe seems an odd choice for Javert and is definitely outsung by the other members of the cast, he holds his own when it really counts with solos that are on-pitch and arguably even more powerful for their imperfections.> No, his solos are not on pitch, not even by American Idol standards, he quite simply does NOT have a professional singing voice, his singing is pure comedy. I can understand though why Hugh Jackman was cast as Jean Valjean, he is a very likable and charismatic fellow, but the vocal demands put on him are quite simply not met, his singing in "Bring him home" is effortful and painful to hear. And why his hair is not completely white? Let's not forget that Marius'friends nicknamed him Monsieur Leblanc because of his white hair.Ann Hathaway too delivers an extremely poor "I dreamed a dream", it is true that the woman is dying, but she doesn't have to sound like it at the expense of the vocal line, like any soprano who has sung La Traviata will tell you.I think it was a good idea of Tom Hooper to film the actors live while singing, but to do that he should have used extremely good singers, like Roberto Alagna for Jean Valjean, Bryn Terfel for Javert (what an improvement on Crowe he might have been!!!!) and Diana Damrau as Fantine. The most successful musical number by far is "Do you hear the people singing" where at least Marius and Enjolras do sing in tune and in high spirits.In spite of my disappointment with the singing, the film still makes an impression, no doubt thanks to Hooper's ability to tell a story, it's just that it could and should have been much better, one can only wonder what Vincent Minnelli would have thought of this.

reviewText: Its a little too dirty for me. I don't mean morally, nor am I referring to the use of language, though there are a handful of scenes that are inappropriate for modern children (and adults who like to keep a pure mind). I am referring to the actual grittiness of the film. It is a dingy set filled with dirty people (who literally need to take a bath). This does, of course, add to the depth of the angst you feel throughout the story as the dirt of the cinematography matches the dirty souls of a corrupt system. The story, is marvelous. Truly marvelous. The singing, while immersive, is by no means beautiful (or perhaps tuneful is the word). If they had removed the dingy-filter from the camera lens, cleaned up the actors, and included studio-mastered recordings, I would have much preferred it. I understand that this goes against the spirit of the director. It simply is not my preference.
summary: A few gems among a heap of ash.

reviewText: After seeing this, my husband remarked, "So...'Les Miserables' refers to EVERYBODY."I have doubts about the wisdom of adapting successful musicals to the big screen.  IMO, the artificiality of the musical form is better suited to the artificiality of the stage.  There are exceptions, of course.  Les Miserables is one, though I must confess there were a couple of times I found myself wishing for a non-musical version with the same cast. The sheer intensity of the acting carries this movie.  Hugh Jackman's Jean Valjean and Anne Hathaway's Fantine are simply stunning.  The steely integrity of Russell Crowe's underplayed Javert rings true as he pursues Jean Valjean to uphold the letter of the law. Lesser acting would have made this movie cringe-worthy. As it is, it's a must-see.  Tissues required.  It's been a long time since I've seen a finale as rousing and awesome as this.Others can debate the various merits of voices, range, musicality and production values. I'd say see this. It's one of the world's greatest stories.
summary: A must see, even for haters of musicals

reviewText: Director Tom Hooper has literally rewritten the book with regards to filming critically and popularly acclaimed musicals like "Les Miserables" in his riveting, excellent cinematic adaptation of one of the world's most beloved musicals, while hewing more closely to the original text of Victor Hugo's novel; it is both a fantastic and magnificent cinematic adaptation of the musical. Hooper gambled that he could film "Les Miserables" by having the actors singing their roles during the actual filming without having them dubbed later in post-production, and not only has it succeeded beyond the expectations of many, it truly feels as though you are hearing a live outdoor performance of "Les Miserables". The cast is superlative starting with Hugh Jackman's compelling portrayal of Jean Valjean, as a conflicted soul trying to escape from his penal past; his singing is exceptional, most notably in his soliloquy "Bring Him Home", hoping the young revolutionary Marais (Eddie Redmayne) escapes from the Paris 1832 student-led uprising, so he can be united with his adopted daughter Cosette (Amanda Seyfried); so too are Anne Hathaway (Fantine) and Russell Crowe (Javert), with Hathaway giving an especially poignant rendition of "I Dreamed A Dream", widely regarded by many as the unofficial "anthem" of "Les Miserables". (Crowe has been condemned by some critics for his singing, but he shows his ability to sing nearly as well as his co-stars, especially towards the end, and offers viewers an emotionally complex portrayal of Javert that remains true to Hugo's depiction of him as a loyal civil servant intent on upholding French law.) Both Sacha Baron Cohen (Thenardier) and Helena Bonham Carter (Madame Thenardier) are especially memorable as the hustlers who are the guardians of the young Cosette (Isabelle Allen) until Valjean steps in, appearing later towards the end of the film, and so too, Colm Wilkinson - the original Jean Valjean in the London and Broadway stage productions - as the Bishop. Along with the excellent cast of actors, the movie features excellent musicianship from the likes of harpist Skaila Kanga and composer/arranger/pianist Anne Dudley, who has contributed additional music to the film score. "Les Miserables" is one of the best cinematic adaptations of a musical I have seen and will be remembered as such for years to come; without question, it is among the best films of 2012.
summary: Les Miserables, C'est Fantastique, C'est Magnifique

reviewText: I remember reading this book back in high school.  It's one of those experiences you never forget.  It touched my heart and certainly showed an incredible viewpoint.  I remember thinking how difficult the characters had it; not knowing how real it actually was for the times.  I recommended it to my brother Jim, and he reluctantly read it.  A week later he went on and on about how great it was( for some reason forgetting I had recommended he read it in the firstplace)Hugh Jackman-playing a perfect Jean Valjean- was quite frankly stunning with extraordinary depth and fearlessness.  He tugs at the heart-strings with the horrible fear filled life he had to live.  His humanity shines thru brilliantly in every scene.Russell Crowe was great behind the eyes-he sold it-but his voice was not as honest and booming as the other actors.  Even thou, his presence was strong and convincing.Now Anne Hathaway( for how briefly she's in the movie) was absolutly incredible playing the factory worker turned prostitute Fantine.  The downward spiral of her character, was like a surge of fire from a gun barrel.  A passionate gut-wrenching portrayal of an  abysmal life.  One scene in particular where she sells her hair, then later her teeth, was a gripping depiction of how far we can fall. Anne deserved all the appropriate accolades she received.  Her singing voice was as beautiful and passionate as any you'll hear.  She got as bare and real as can be gotten; even dispersing her beauty for realism and art(something to see, even if only once)The all familar ache of Jean Valjean doing the right thing; was just as agonizing as it was in the book, as well as in earlier movie versions.  The backdrop of the French revolution later in the film; has the inertia of a avalanche( even if you don't like musicals) racing towards the end.I felt the setting and grimness were overpowering; the raw reality of a bygone and violent era were easily felt.  You'll find the supporting cast a bit off, but the direction makes up for it.  The score is as much a character in the movie as anyone-soaring over sorrow and loss-as it moves along the narrative.It takes a bit to get used to the lack of very much dialog; especially if you saw the earlier movie,but the power of those melodies certainly makes up for it.  At 2 and a half hours the film made sense;however 3 hours certainly would have been pretentious and too ambitious.  It takes the grey pain of life: reasons it out in different landscapes, dishes out the fear of poverty convincingly and illuminates the reality of life's hard bargains with thyself.I enjoyed this film immensely; and the summation of the performances were well worth it!  I recommend it highly!
summary: The Miserables are all right!  Stellar performances!

reviewText: I am actually surprised to find myself having to admit that I found this dramatized, detailed cinematic version of one of the great musicals of the later twentieth century to be virtually unwatchable.No, there was nothing wrong with it, per se. The performances are powerful, the look and feel detailed and dramatically sharp. Had it been done as an adaptation of the original Victor Hugo novel rather than the musical, I would probably have considered it a major dramatic accomplishment. The sheer power of it would have been startling.But somewhere along the path of converting the stage musical to this screen version, the entire soul and point of the original was completely tossed away, seemingly without a second thought, and what remains is a disquieting combination of the grimmest "reality" video imaginable and a strange, fumbling amature night by seasoned professional performers. Even Hugh Jackman, himself an experienced musical stage performer, seems to toss away his understanding of why a story is in musical form and the vast differences between telling a story with merely dialogue, and telling it with music and melody.That is really the primary question that seems to have been ignored in this film adaptation: Why tell a story in musical form instead of through acted, spoken dialogue?As an actor, with extensive experience in film, tv and staged musicals, the answer that gets drummed into you is that the author's intent is to have the emotional force and power carried primarily through the melody, harmony, orchestral arrangement and lyrics of the music instead of the actual performance.But there is another consideration that most people don't think about. Musicals are almost always written with the intention that they be performed live from a stage in front of a physically present audience. This means that each note and lyric must be performed with a certain minimum level of technical proficiency and clear enough to be understood at the very back of the theatre. The performer, no matter how emotionally involved in the moment, must make their primary job the skillful performance of the notes, rhythm, timing and mood of the song, over and above whatever emotions that performer might be experiencing as they sing it. The author almost never intends for their melody and lyrics to be lost and unintelligable beneath the blubbering noises of a performer totally drowned in a wave of emotion.In other words, the intent of writing a musical is for the sweeping, overpowering emotional impact to be borne by the songs themselves, not in the performance.But there is yet one more element that impacts this production. Les Miserables is not, strictly speaking, a musical. It is an opera. There is very little dialogue (considerably more than in the original staged version), with most of the exposition being communicated through sections, not of spoken dialogue, but of musical resetitive. Even those sections are intended by the author to be sung with a main focus on technical musical proficiency, rather than being "acted".The ultimate result in this version of Les Miz is that some of the key, emotionally most powerful musical moments are utterly wrecked because the actors are "acting" the songs rather than "singing" them. One glaring example is Fontine's heartbreaking "I Dreamed a Dream", where the major climax resolution of the final motif ("I had a dream my life would so different from this hell I'm living") doesn't soar on that quick burst of agonized notes that stab straight through the heart. Instead it is replaced by a sobbing blubber of muttered words that kill that musical moment. Another is Hugh Jackman's Act One epiphany, after stealing from the priest, when he at last devotes himself to serving goodness and God. Jackman also dissolves into a wailing, sloppy mess of words, entirely wrecking the music which was originally intended to carry that emotional moment.It appears the actors based their performances on being in the intimate, close-up environment of film rather than the strict, cooperative, technically proficient media of a musical.And considering the actions involved, the pain, horror, and depressing nature of the story and environment in which it is set, the entire production becomes grim almost beyond belief. If they'd concentrated instead on attempting to sing the songs properly, serving the music rather than working entirely against it, it might have made those emotionally devastating moments more palatable. As it is, by the time Jackman's Valjean confesses in open court in order to prevent the miscarriage of justice of letting an innocent man take the fall on his behalf, the entire piece has all the emotional richness of watching an unending documentary of Holocaust footage. It crams the "misery" into such high gear it becomes difficult to continue watching.The same thing happened to a somewhat lesser extent with the film version of Stephen Sondheim's "Sweeney Todd", where the actors were allowed, or perhaps deliberately encouraged, to "act" rather than "sing" the songs, rendering the songs superfluous.This is a continuing problem when attempting to take something created to be performed in a strict, stylized, highly defined standard such as a musical performed on a stage before a live audience, and convert it to the highly intimate environment of film. The two don't mesh well. If you focus on doing the songs properly, as intended, the result on film looks somewhat stilted. If you focus instead on the "acting" of the emotionally powerful moments, the music never meshes with the performance, sounding almost like an added and almost interfering background.In this case it turns what could have been a sweeping, grand and powerful musical statement about mankind's pain and hopes into a bit of a sloppy mess of noise and sound and overblown performances that never entirely gel.I won't be attempting to watch this again any time soon. Instead I will pull out the Les Miserables concert performance of the entire score, where the entire point of doing the story as a musical is vibrantly presented as it was intended. that version allows the heart to soar with the music, not shift uncomfortably while watching a seemingly endless and pointless barrage of human suffering.

reviewText: As the Les Miz story line is so familiar, I assume that a plot review will not be seen as a "spoiler."  But if you are so inclined, please read no further....One author recently provided this contrast: "If the American Revolution was a success because the leaders who went on to build the country had a proper understanding of human nature, the French Revolution was a failure because the rebels got it wrong from the get-go....the result was the creation of the most despotic regime to date" (Why Catholicism Matters, p. 20).  Quoting from# 407 of the Catechism of the Catholic Church, the author maintains the American framers' understanding to be more consistent with the Catholic: "Ignorance of the fact that man has a wounded nature inclined to evil gives rise to serious errors in the areas of education, politics, social action, and morals" (p. 21).Les Miserables opens in a destitute, "miserable," early 19th century, post-revolution France.  It is the familiar tale of Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), who has been released from two decades of torturous prison after stealing a loaf of bread to feed his sister's family.Shortly after his release, Valjean steals silver from a cleric and appears headed back to prison.  Instead, the priest intervenes and starts Valjean on a road of redemption.  I found the religious elements (which are everywhere!) to be exceedingly more clear, than I found several years ago in the Broadway rendition.To become a new man, Valjean decides that he must break free of the conditions of parole for prisoner "24601" and take a new identity.  In spite of subsequent success in business and in developing an admirable moral character, Valjean's life will continue to cross paths with the relentless Inspector Javert (Russell Crowe) - who is hell bent on returning Valjean to prison.Valjean's life also crosses paths with Fantine (Ann Hathaway), a single mom who has been economically raped, in her desperate efforts to support her beloved Cosette. Hathaway's rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream" is even better than that of Susan Boyle and certainly more heartbreaking:"I had a dream my life would beSo different from this hell I'm livingSo different now from what it seemedNow life has killed the dream I dreamed."On Fantine's deathbed, Valjean assures her that he will find and care for Cosette.  He then rescues Cosette from the "care" of the Thénardier innkeeper family (Helen Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen).  "Borat" certainly portrays the despicable nature of M. Thénardier's character.  Yet, the Thénardiers' appearances are over the top and provide a gratuitous crudeness that detracts from this otherwise wonderful film.Fast forward to 1832 and another revolution - young Cosette has fallen in love with the idealistic revolutionary student, Marius.  It is sacrificial love from both the Thénardier's daughter Eponine and Valjean, which ultimately saves Marius from himself.  United in marriage, the love of Fantine, Eponine, and Valjean has set the stage for Marius and Cosette to live "happily ever after."This is a a wonderful film, ultimately filled with the hopefulness of redemption and eternal life.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never expected to fall head over heels with this film but I did.  Having seen the original and subsequent stage versions many times over the years, I was both terrified and energized by the prospect of the film.  But I was simply unprepared for the film's eloquence or depth, which for me at least, made the material feel fresh and contemporary even though the words are hundreds of years old.  I practically steeled myself when The DVD arrived thinking I would need to set aside plenty of time for it, though not really knowing why.Over the course of several days, I watched in spurts and starts, at first unable to get thru Anne Hathaway's heartbreaking death sequence.  Nothing I'd heard or read prepared me fully for Hathaway's brilliant turn.  No wonder she won an Oscar.  Well.  Duh. For me, the movie transformed itself into a great film at the 33 minute mark.  By the time Fantine had sung her last note (in this act, anyway) I was a wreck, had tears streaming down my grown men's beard-stubbly face and was practically gasping for air.  Anne Hathaway gives unquestionably one of THE towering film performances ever and earns her place in the cinema hall of fame, no doubt.  Her performance is THAT good and worth the price of admission in and of itself.  She knocked the wind out of me, so I paused, and took a day off before trying a second and third time, but each and every time, Fantine's scenes devastated me to the point where I couldn't fathom getting thru the rest of it!About a week later, I finally succumbed to its magical pull and watched Les Miz from start to finish.  And I came away seeing the film as an incredibly well-realized adaptation of a beloved stage musical.  As a film, it is one for the ages.  Hugh Jackman is the ultimate Jean Valjean in terms of combining sheer brute presence and a powerful made for Broadway voice.  I saw Jackman as Peter Allen on Broadway in his Tony winning turn as The Boy From Oz, so I expected great things from this ace of actors, someone who can do anything!  And Hugh did not disappoint!  With the one exception of "Bring Him Home" which is simply too high for Jackman - or almost any man other than maybe Adam Levine - to sing perfectly, I felt he nailed the richness and sublime instincts of his character. Jackmans Valjean is desperate in his rebellion and earnest in his redemption, but always willing to take the risks that make him - and all of us - human,  No actor has come close to capturing Valjean in as 3-dimensional a way as Hugh Jackman, and in any other year without Daniel Day Lewis, Jackman would have easily won an Oscar for this portrayal.The supporting cast is equally solid, even Helena Bonham Carter and Sasha Baron Cohen as the dingbat Masters of the House.  Amanda Syfrid and Samantha Barks were stunningly lovely, while Aaron Tvitt (a remarkable young singer I saw in the heartbreaking and real "Next to Normal") makes an indelible impression again as he does on stage.  Watch this kid...he will be huge!  Lastly, Eddie Redmayne is a superstar in the making and will be a serious Oscar contender in the future!Much has been said about this movie, good and bad.  I get it.  It's a film that's wrapped in heated debate because so many millions of people have been touched by its sorrowful tale of redemption and honor and love.  At the end of the day, its a movie.  And it happens to be a GREAT one once you get all those critical voices - both pro and con - out of your head.  Watch it and see if it doesn't move you and touch your heart.  That's what a great movie is about, and that's my experience with Lez Miz..A wonderful surprise!
summary: Shocked and Amazed by How Much I Loved It!

reviewText: Les Miserables Surprised me. I DID NOT expect to Like this movie because I DO NOT like musicals. I dont know why but for some reason, i find musicals to be boring and uninteresting. But After 158 minutes of the musical numbers this movie gave the audience, I was blown away completely. Hugh Jackman Portrays Jean Valjean (who is a rags to riches type of character) and he gives us a oscar worthy performance. Anne Hathaway won the 2013 Best Supporting Actress Oscar and rightfully so. My god, she was Amazing as Fantine (her character will cause you to shed a few tears). The other supporting cast which consists of: Helena Bonham Carter, Amanda Seyfried, Sacha Baron Cohen, and  Russell Crowe all did wonderful jobs in this movie. But I do want to point out two other details. One, there is another supporting cast member who goes by the name of Samantha Barks(she plays Eponnie in the movie) did a really great job; I honestly feel her performance was overlooked/underrated. Two, Russell Crowe's performance was heavily criticized by audiences and critics alike but personally, he was my favorite character in the movie. The Scenes he and Hugh Jackman share are really memorable. The story line is set in the 19th century of France and I will say the atmosphere, the set pieces, the grand scale, the whole nine yards of this movie are insanely terrific. You DO actually feel you are in France during these times. As for the movie itself, well, it just proved that even I now like and have a new appreciation for the musical movie genre. I will always be a fan of this movie which (does not have a lot of dialogue) but is guaranteed to leave an profound impact on anyone. Watch this movie and I promise you will not regret it. Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, Les Miserables is Spectacular.5 Stars
summary: More Meaningful than I have words to describe

reviewText: I had been hoping for a movie musical version of Les Miserables since I first heard the original Broadway soundtrack soon after it hit the stage.  I have also had the opportunity to see it on stage three times, and I was moved each time.  I was afraid that I was going to be disappointed in the movie that I had been anticipating for so long.I am happy to say that I thought the movie was very good over-all.  Hugh Jackman was great as Jean Valjean. He developed a character that was powerful and real and kept it throughout the whole movie.The three actors I was most impressed with were Anne Hathaway, Eddie Redmayne, and Samantha Barks. All three gave such raw and powerful performances that I was in tears at least once during each of their songs. "I Dreamed a Dream," "On My Own," and "Empty Chairs..." are fantastic.The first time I saw the movie, I was not as impressed with Russel Crowe as Javert as I hoped, but after watching it a second time, I focused more on the acting than the singing.  Crowe has a nice voice, but I think there might have been other actors with more powerful voices to fill that role (Brian Stokes Mitchell comes to mind.)  However, Crowe does an excellent job in portraying a man who is more and more conflicted about his beliefs as the movie progressed.I was also a bit disappointed in Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter as the Thenardiers.  Maybe it was because I have seen stage versions where these characters were so vocally powerful that the less powerful voices of these two actors seemed anti-climatic.  I also thought that Carter's performance was a bit too close to her performance in Sweeney Todd. However, they both were able to show the comedic elements of the characters.Finally, I was blown away by the cinematography. Director Tom Hooper and Production designer Eve Stewart created a world which was breathtakingly real.  I thought the opening and closing sequences were especially powerful.Just a note: I showed the movie to my high school drama class.  A number of the students are not big musical theatre fans, and a few are not theatre fans, but were put in the class anyway.  It took three days to finish the movie, and each time I had to stop it, there were complaints from the class.  I could tell that they were not just watching it, but watching it with interest.  Two boys actually liked the beginning so much that they went out and bought the DVD so they could watch it at home.  To me, that is the best "review" of them all.

reviewText: Taking a much loved stage play to the screen is always a daunting task. Making it come alive on the silver screen as it does on the stage  is fraught with perils. Can you make the beloved characters meet a critical public's expectations? Having seen this show on stage many times, I entered the theatre not knowing exactly what to expect. After all of the hype, would it really capture the heart of this multifaceted musical? I am happy to say that it did. I loved that, when in doubt, they went to the novel for answers. This captures the book  better than the stage play was able. I loved the immediacy of the vocals filmed live. Yes, they could have made a 'prettier' version had they used a studio recording. But this is supposed to depict life at its barest. Capturing the realities of a life hard fought. I am delighted that they chose actors who sing over singers who (try to) act. I thought Hugh Jackman captured the soul and essence of Jean Valjean. Not at all an easy thing to do. And I found Russell Crowe's obsessed Javert a perfect foil. No, he doesn't have the vocal range of the Javert's I'm  used to. He has a rock singer's rough hewn voice. Perfect for this adaptation. Anne Hathaway's fragile Fantine, broke my heart. If anyone was the weak link, it was Amanda Seyfried (older Cosette). Her quivering soprano didn't match the mostly stage actors' strong vocalizations. Samantha Barks as Eponine was spectacular. As were Eddie Redmayne (Marius) and  Aaron Tveit (Enjolras). I think Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter were miscast. What an inspired choice to tap the original stage JVJ, Colm Wilkinson, as the Bishop of Digne. It was fun to see so many past and  at the time of filming, West End cast members in cameo roles.
