reviewText: "Les Miserables" is great! This is how the story goes: Ex-prisoner Jean Valjean is hunted for decades by the ruthless policeman Javert after he breaks parole. When Valjean agrees to care for factory worker Fantine's young daughter, Cosette, their lives change forever.The cast led by Hugh Jackman (superb as Jean Valjean), Russell Crowe (solid as Javert), Anne Hathaway (Oscar-worthy / winning excellence as Fantine), Amanda Seyfried (solid as Cosette), Sacha Baron Cohen (as Thenardier), Helena Bonham Carter (as Madame Thenardier) & Eddie Redmayne (as Marius) is great. The directing by Tom Hooper is great. The screenplay (based on the novel by Victor Hugo & the musical play by Claude-Michel Schonberg & Alain Boublil) by William Nicholson is great.The cinematography by Danny Cohen is great. The film editing by Chris Dickens & Melanie Oliver is great. The casting by Nina Gold is great. The production design by Eve Stewart is great. The art direction by Grant Armstrong, Gary Jopling, Hannah Moseley & Su Whitaker is great. The set decoration by John Botton, Leigh Bryant, Stephen Doyle (also did the set dressings), Billy Edwards, Carrie Garner, James Hendy, Anna Lynch-Robinson, Sarah Whittle & Matt Wyles is great. The costume design by Paco Delgado is great. The special effects supervised by Mark Holt is great. The visual effects supervised by Richard Bain, Sara Bennett, John Lockwood, Sean Mathiesen, Nathan McGuinness & Steve Street, coordinated by Kingsley Cook, Izzy Field, Alex Fitzgerald, Ali Ingham, Allison Paul, Natalie Reid & Adrian Steel is great. The stunts coordinated by Paul Herbert is great.This is a well-acted and well-done adaptation that is entertaining and well-crafted. The cast is terrific in singing their songs, well-sung and well-crafted. Tom Hooper has done a terrific follow-up movie to his Oscar-winning masterpiece, "The King's Speech" (2010), that is definitely a different movie and also an interesting movie to do, in terms of, Oscar-winning follow-up films. Hugh Jackman is in a definitely superb performance as Jean Valjean, his first time singing in a movie or movie musical adaptation, among the Oscar-worthy/winning excellence of Anne Hathaway's performance as Fantine & Russell Crowe's solidly-crafted work as Javert, both Hathaway & Crowe also singing for the first time on screen in a movie musical adaptation. This is one of the best films of last year and also of the recently-done holiday season, which was also, definitely, one of the most anticipated films of last year. This is also one of the better movie musicals done in recent memory.

reviewText: Wow--really, wow. I'm a big fan of musicals and was somewhat familiar with the music from Les Miserables (Bring Him Home sung by Colm Wilkinson is on my top five favorite songs/performances of all time), I still wasn't prepared for what I saw. I knew beforehand that the performers were singing at the time of filming, and that is what we saw, so I expected some loss of song quality for the sake of acting, which was the case some of the time. Hugh Jackman has experience on Broadway, but I knew stepping into the shoes of Colm Wilkinson would be difficult for him to do. I was still very pleased with his voice and thrilled by his acting. I loved the fact that Colm did get a part in the movie--he plays the monsignior perfectly. Anne Hathaway was the breakout star of the movie, her performance was so powerful that it was obvious an Oscar was headed her way. Her singing was as good if not better than any recordings I've heard from the musical. She was simply breathtaking. The actor playing Marius was a little hard on the eyes and his voice a tad dated, but he gave a solid performance as did the rest of the lesser-known cast. Two wonderful, scene stealing hams, Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter, gave us a needed break from the intensity of the film. My biggest problem was with Russell Crowe. I didn't mind his voice; I rather liked his style, even though it was not anywhere near the quality of the other players. However, as the movie progressed, his portrayal definitely dimmed in comparison to the other actors. Everyone was out-acting him, and he was the weak link of the production. Amanda Seyfried was another weak link for me--her thin, high, trillish voice wasn't always pleasing, even though she was suited for the part. Despite these faults, the power of the production and the overall quality of the movie is so high that I can still give it a five star review.

reviewText: I have waited with bated breath for my favorite broadway show to become a movie.  It was done very well with only a few difficulties. Anne Hathaway was fabulous in acting and singing. Hugh Jackman who played Val Jean did an adequate job singing but I felt that he did not have the pipes for some of the songs (especially "Bring Him Home").  For some reason, he chose to "talk/sing" in some areas. Russell Crowe who played Javair (sic) did a much better job. (who knew he could sing?) Marius who was played by Eddie Redmayne was very good and the rest of the cast was memorable. I was disappointed w/ Sasha Baron Cohen's and Helena Bonham Carter's portrayal of the Thedinaires (sic). On broadway, it was much funnier. Interesting side note: the role of Jean Val Jean and music he sang was written for Colm Wilkinson who was the first one on Broadway in London. In the movie, he portrayed the Bishop. This movie is well worth your time and is suitable for family viewing (might be too intense for wee ones). If you have never seen a broadway show, this is a good introduction.

reviewText: Let me preface this by saying that I have loved Les Miserables since I first saw the musical on Broadway about 20 years ago, as a child.  I have seen it twice more since on Broadway and I own both the original Broadway and London cast albums.  I know the entire score by heart.The good:- The scenery is simply beautiful and gritty and raw.  There are certain things that are captured better on screen than the stage.- Anne Hathaway's performance of "I Dreamed a Dream" was brilliant.- Casting of Marius and Eponine.  "On My Own" was beautifully sung.- Cosette (both child and adult) and Gavroche were great.- Hugh Jackman sung his heart out (but...as you will see in "The Bad," he just wasn't quote good enough - especially "What Have I Done").- I enjoyed Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen as the Thenardiers.- The new "Suddenly" song fit in beautifully.- Colm Wilkinson's cameo as the priestThe bad:- Hugh Jackman did not have the vocal chops to be Jean Valjean, even though he tried very hard.  I have to admit though that his rendition of "Bring Him Home" was particularly moving, perhaps his best song in the movie.- Russell Crowe.  Not only is he a mediocre singer, he was a very wooden Javert.Overall, the movie was good, but I was disappointed that they did not have a professional singer do the singing for Hugh Jackman and find a better Javert.
summary: Mixed feelings about this one - the visual images are stunning, some amazing performances, but key roles were miscast.

reviewText: Les Miserables is by no means a pefect film, the performances, in some portions are lacking, and at times the close ups do make the film stagnate slightly, but it is never lacking an emotional 2x4, and hits you right in the gut everytime.  Despite all of it's flaws, it is an exciting and emotional journey that never lets go.Having not read "Les Miserables" yet, I cannot compare it to the book, nor can I compare it to the stage show, I have not seen that either, I however, listened to the "Original London Cast" soundtrack for hours at a time as a child and memorized most of the songs.  Up until this film version, I felt Patti Lupone's version of "I Dreamed a Dream" was definitive, but I have now changed my mind (more on that later).  In terms of the music and singing, they definitely did a fantastic job, and while the live "singing" has been done before (opposed to what the Director espouses), and is jarring at first, it proves most effective in a few of the performances primarily in Fantine's songs, a couple of Jean Valjean's (especially the last couple songs he sings), and Eponine's solo.  It does feel a little odd to listen to in the group numbers at times, but once adjusted to, everything sounds just fine.The story being about so much pain and despair, gives it a lot of emotional punch, and not just for the part's Fantine is in, in the theater I was in, I had people crying all around me in various scenes, especially one of the battle scenes during the French Revolution involving a young boy.  This is what gets audiences, not perfect direction or sound or even perfect singing, but heart and an emotional connection, which is why some critics hate this film.  The direction is at times sloppy, the camera work is surprisingly shaky (which is definitely on purpose, but can make the film sloppy), there is close up upon close up, which is always something critics like to rail about, but in this film, they actually do work.The one thing about the camera work which was obnoxious, was the constant same shot, and lack of changing angles, but that's not a huge complaint, as that is fairly normal in older films, and this is a movie which, in a way, harkens back to early silent melodramas, the constant closeups, in a way, remind me of "The Passion of Joan of Ark (1928)", I am in no way comparing the quality of both films, but the technique of the shots used in this film, they are used for similar effect, as they were in Joan of Ark.  Keeping that in mind, the closeups didn't seem quite as meaningless, but they did actually serve a purpose, and for audiences at least, the trick seemed to work.As a musical, it works well, music is all fantastic and the big musical numbers are exciting and fun, and for a nearly 3hr film, the pace is kept brisk, while at times, it was hard to discern what the point of the story really was, interest was never lost in th3e characters, and never stopped caring about them, especially Jean Valjean and Fantine.  Even by the end i did care about Javert, no Russel Crowe's singing isn't perfect, and as a singer and voice teacher, his lack of vibrato and zero usage of the diaphragm to sing was slightly irritating, but he conveyed the emotions in the songs, especially his last song "Javert's Suicide.  Unfortunately Amanda Seyfreid keeps getting type cast in to the ingenue-type roles, which are easy to criticize her for, but she plays the role effectively, and technically, has some of the best singing in the lot besides Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway, but she does at time, seem slightly disconnected emotionally while singing.Anne Hathaway, some may remember, was actually originally considered to play Christine in the "Phantom of the Opera" film, but that ended up going to Emmy Russom instead.  Though Hathaway did sing in "Ella Enchanted", and is, I believe classically trained, with that in mind, her fantastic singing in this came as no surprise, however, the range of emotion she has while singing is more than impressive, and as priorly mentioned, her rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream" exceeds far and above all other renditions to date.  The way she doesn't just sing the words, but feels them is what a musical should be like, and it is the best section of the film by far.The film as flawed as it may be, knows its core audience, and has reached far beyond it well to connect with many people, and not just musical lovers.  There were people crying all around me in the theater I was in as I allready have said, but they were also gasping and even screaming in some parts.  People felt what was on the screen in this film more than any other film I have seen, and it just goes to show, a film does not have to be perfect to connect with an audience, it just has to have a heart.God Bless ~Amy

reviewText: I thought the movie had an interesting look and feel to it right from the beginning and it involved me right away. The acting of Anne Hathaway and Hugh Jackman was absolutely amazing. They both gave powerful performances and looked sincere and genuine at every moment. I think the live singing made the film much better than most musicals and (hopefully) set a new standard.  I loved the quality and naturalness of the sound.I'm generally not a big fan of this sort of epic-level drama, but the actors pulled off the dramatic ending well, and I found it very moving. I think this movie, overall, is precedent setting and an artistic success.
summary: Well done, with great performances from Jackman and Hathaway

reviewText: When I first heard that Les Misérables was going to be made into a movie musical, I was really excited.  The only thing I wasn't sure about was the cast...this was before I knew who was going to play each part.  I was basically ecstatic when I learned who would be in the movie...He's no Colm Wilkinson, but Hugh Jackman, in my opinion was incredible as Jean Valjean.  I knew he could sing since I had seen the video of him in "Oklahoma!" several years ago.  He's also been on stage several times.  He made the part his own and did a wonderful job.Anne Hathaway surprised me.  I knew she had a nice singing voice, but I had no idea that she had a *beautiful* singing voice.  Besides the fact that during 'I Dreamed a Dream' the camera was way too close to her face, her voice is beautiful and you really feel Fantine's pain.  I just wish that the camera wasn't so in her face...literally.  Other than that, watching her get her hair cut on screen (yes they really cut it there so it had to be done in only one take!) was really brave of her.  Her 'Come to Me' brought me to tears.Russell Crowe....well he tried!  I thought he actually did a pretty good job, but looking at the cast as a whole, he was one of the weakest voices.  His acting was spot on as always, but his voice needed a little work; however, if you look at it from the point of view that Javert is not a nice person and is actually the 'bad guy' of the film/show, then his voice was perfect.  Prior to seeing the movie, I had no idea that Crowe had any musical training.  I then learned that he did have a few months of training for the movie and that he has sung before (I think in a band, but I'm not sure).Amanda Seyfried as Cosette... While she does have a beautiful voice (as we heard in "Mamma Mia!"), I'm not sure that she was the best actress for this role.  She was perfectly fine with the acting.  It was the singing.  Whenever she sang with Eddie Redmayne (Marius) and Samantha Barks (Eponine), she was literally drowned out.  Plus her high notes are rather shrill.  She was never off pitch or out of tune, but those high notes did bother me a bit.  Also, I'm not sure how many others noticed this, but her vibrato was very fast.  I don't know the musical term for that, but it didn't sound very controlled.  Her voice seemed different in "Mamma Mia!".  Looking beyond that though, I did enjoy her scenes.Eddie Redmayne as Marius was absolutely perfect.  He has a beautiful voice.  I had never heard of him before this and I hope he continues to do musical theatre.  Everything about his character simply fit like a glove.  My favorite Marius will always be Michael Ball, but he's too old to play the part now.  However I am glad that they found Eddie.Samantha Barks was also perfect as Eponine. She had previously been in the West End production of the show including the 25th anniversary concert so I knew she'd be great.  I just wish the character had more on screen time!And then of course you have Sacha Baron Cohen as Thénardier and Helena Bonham Carter as Madame Thénardier were great.  They didn't have the strongest singing voices, but their acting helped to cover that.  I just wish that their whole song at the wedding was in the movie.The rest of the cast was wonderful as well.  I especially loved that Colm Wilkinson himself made an appearance as the Bishop who takes Valjean in at the beginning of the movie.  His voice still sounds like that of an angel.  Having Aaron Tveit play Enjolras was great, seeing as he has been in several Broadway shows.From a cinematic point of view, this movie was brilliant.  It really felt like you were in 1800s Paris.  One of the things that I also found very interesting was having the cast sing live as opposed to lip-syncing to previously recorded singing.  I thought at first that we weren't going to be able to hear some of the characters in certain scenes since there is a lot of noise in the background, but it worked.  Future filmmakers should think about doing this when the next movie musical is made.  I applaud Tom Hooper for doing such a wonderful job with this movie.  It is not easy to turn a beloved stage musical into a movie, but this really worked.If you're a fan of the show and don't mind a new song (Suddenly) and a few music changes here and there (changes in the order of the songs), then I highly recommend this movie to you.  If you've never seen the stage musical or heard the music like my husband (who by the way loved the movie and said it was one of the most powerful movies he's ever seen), then you should see it too.  Oh yeah...remember to bring tissues...

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: This was an epic film! This incredible film is broadly scaled cinematically, extremely visceral in passion and extremely personal for the audience.  Director Tom Hooper (The King's Speech, John Adams) did a forceful job of making a true musical of passion and feelings truly come alive with real compassion on screen.Having seen the stage version of the original production of Les Miserables many times, I went in a little skeptical that this kind of production couldn't be translated from the stage to the big screen and not lose its essence. Boy was I proven wrong. Hooper did an outstanding job with everything he had to work with. Based on the original book by Claude-Michel Schönberg and Alain Boublil, (from the original novel by Victor Hugo of `Hunchback of Notre Dame' fame) with the masterful score by Claude-Michel Schönberg, the movie is packed with extremely compassionate moments of the heart and soul of every one of these characters.Hugh Jackman (X-Men, Reel Steel) gives the most colorful and compassionate performance of his career as Jean Valjean . Hugh is amazing to watch as he stars as the man who stole bread for his sister's son in order save his life. He intensely shows his 19 year imprisonment angst and his redemption of character with a true spirit of love and healing. I was impressed with how much of a range Hugh can really play.Anne Hathaway (Alice In Wonderland, Get Smart) gave a literally wrenching and tear evoking performance of the most recorded song in this plays history, "I Dreamed A Dream". She is passionate, visceral and real and you can only imagine what her character Fantine is going through. There wasn't a dry eye in the theatre when she sung her last note.Russell Crowe (Gladiator, Beautiful Mind) surprised me as the military leader Javert because I first, could not believe he could actually sing and then second, he played the passion and confusion of the man chasing the bread-stealer over decades as a real person with a misguided mission only to end up realizing he did the wrong thing all these years.Other stunning performances vocally came from Samantha Barks (Grover High) as the confused and heartbroken Eponine as well as Eddie Redmayne (My Week With Marilyn, The Other Boleyn Girl) as Marius who are both star-crossed - almost - lovers. Samantha swoons for Eddie and he swoons for Cosette played by Amanda Seyfried (Mamma Mia, Red Riding Hood). Samatha has an amazing stunning voice as does Eddie's commanding vocal passion while Amanda sweet subtle and compassionate notes (as she always does) weaned the desire for love throughout.Young Cosette was played by first time performer Isabelle Allen with such realism that she personifies the poster that has always immortalized the play for decades!Special note for Sacha Baron Cohen (Hugo, Borat) and Helena Bonham Carter (Harry Potter, Alice In Wonderland)  playing husband and wife Thénardier and Madame Thénardier with the frolicking musical number "Master Of The House". They couldn't have been cast better and their chemistry together is pure comical magic together.Director of Photography Danny Cohen (The King's Speech, Pirate Radio) did a masterful job at capture broad panoramic images and a dark mood of the troubled times of the French Revolution. Coupled with amazing matte photography and more than period extended sets, the visual were stunning as well.Overall the film is an amazing and extremely dynamic with all the real passion of the original stage production has, but done in a believable and visually artistic way for the big screen. I thought it couldn't be done - and it was done - and done well. It's operatic and may be considered somewhat slow for those expecting car crashes, kung-fu fights or gun battles, but its filled with a real story and characters that should move you if you understand the personal angst of what makes these characters real to the story.  Masterfully done on an epic scale, Les Miserables is an amazing cinematic production.
summary: `Les Mis' Is Cinema Majesty On The Silver Screen!

reviewText: I have seen Les Miserables on stage and also the movie version with Liam Neeson a few years ago.  Loved them both.  But this movie is truly a transcendent experience.  The decision by the director to record the cast singing live rather than dub in a studio recording over the action was brilliant.  There is an immediacy and urgency to the performances that I have never seen matched in any movie musical.  Because of the quality of the acting, this movie produces both heartbreaking moments, and life affirming moments.  Even some nice comedy thrown in with Sascha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter's larcenous innkeeper and wife.  Chances are anyone interested in this movie has already seen it, but if you haven't, do so NOW!

reviewText: I grew up in the theatre, and I knew the songs of this musical before I had ever known the whole storyline. I am one of those people who love musicals, just because they are musicals. I can forgive a lot of campiness and rough edges just because I love the storytelling and emotions of it all. So, one can imagine just how BADLY I WANTED TO SEE THIS! I pre-ordered it online, just knooowing that it was going to be one of the greats in cinematic storytelling. ...The Blu-Ray arrived in the mail, I prepared the entire evening for pure uninterrupted musical enjoyment. And then-- The singing began. My heart instantly sank to the floor, feeling as flat as Russell Crowe's notes.This is one of the world's greatest musicals ever written -- It is meant to be sung by some of the greatest voices we have today. Musicals need to be cast with singers who act, as opposed to actors who try to sing.This is how it is supposed to be sung: (Live Broadway singers sing at the "10th Anniversary Concert" --HUGE difference in quality of singing!)[...]
summary: I was aching to LOVE it-- HOWEVER... it was cast with good actors who moderately, or badly, sing. Watch Youtube for comparrisons

reviewText: I came to this movie with no prejudgements.  I had never seen a production of it on stage, and I was not familiar with the music.  This is the classic story of Jean Valjean, a criminal who changes his life, but lives in fear of police inspector Javert.  When one of the workers in his factory, Fantine, dies, Valjean vows to find her child and raise it as his own.  He finds Cosette slaving away at the inn of the Thenardiers.  Nine years later they are living in Paris.  It is a time of civil unrest and Cosette fall in love with an insurrectionist named Marius.  He is wounded during a confrontation with police and Valjean saves him.  Cosette and Marius are married, Valjean takes refuge in a convent, fearing that his past will somehow ruin the happiness of the pair of young lovers.In my opinion, most of the music in Les Misérables is forgettable, and it is keyed too high for the actors.  The lyrics, however, are beautifully written.  The actors all gave wonderful performances: Hugh Jackman as Valjean, Russell Crowe as Javert, Eddie Redmayne as Marius,and Amanda Seyfried as Cosette.  Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter were riotously funny as the innkeepers.  I would like point especially to Anne Hathaway.  She won an Oscar and a Golden Globe for her performance as Fantine, and she deserved it.  Her rendition of "I Dreamed A Dream" is the real show-stopper of the movie.  She did it in a continous four and half minute closeup.  That was as fine a piece of acting as I have ever seen.Les Misérables is melodrama to be sure, but it speaks of forgiveness, courage, and redemption, and there is something to be said for that.

reviewText: A couple of years ago, my wife and I saw the musical live. While I liked it, I had a hard time following the plot from the cheap seats and regretted not shelling out $25 more per ticket for better spaces. I found it hard to follow and was frustrated because all I had ever heard was how great a story it was.This time, overall, I was very impressed. Apparently, the singing for musicals is traditionally recorded in studio months or weeks before shooting begins. Then, while the movie is being shot, the actors/actresses simply act out their scenes while lip-synching the songs. This time around, director Tom Hooper (big fan, more on him below) decided to switch things up and record the songs live while the scenes were being shot. The working theory was this would sacrifice some of the music quality but greatly enhance the dramatic effect. Great decision.Did some the singing suffer as a result? Undoubtedly. I am sure a recording studio track would have sounded much more proficient and pretty. In particular, a couple of Russell Crowe solos seemed to stretch his voice to the limit. The singing certainly doesn't approach the soaring heights of theLes Miserables: The 25th Anniversary Concert [Blu-ray] recorded in 2010. But, in the movie, the emotions were raw and the characters vulnerable throughout. In short, the acting was simply superb.The entire cast turned in great, emotionally-driven performances. Hugh Jackman was surprisingly powerful as Jean Valjean and more than ready for such a leading role. Anne Hathaway was gut-wrenchingly sorrowful as Fantine. Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter were terrifically scummy as the Thenardiers. Samantha Barks probably stole the show in her unforgettable performance as Eponine. Russell Crowe and Amanda Seyfried (the weakest links) both turned in solid performances as Javert, the grim and determined law officer, and Cosettte, Jean Valjean's adopted daughter, respectively.These performances were all under the watchful eye of Tom Hooper. Hooper, though far from a household name - for now - is proving to be one of Hollywood's most promising up-and-coming directors. He first received recognition for directing HBO's exceptional John Adams miniseries a few years back and his last time behind the camera was in 2010's The King's Speech. In short, there's not much Hooper oversees that isn't excellent. His decision to record the singing live as opposed to prerecording the tracks was not the only prescient decision he made.Of course, the songs of Les Miserables are much more poignant when one is properly following the plot! For instance, now I understand that when Jean Valjean belts out, "Who am I? I'm Jean Valjean" he is making a profound and terribly difficult decision by coming out of hiding and accepting the consequences for his long ago actions. More lyrics from the same song:If I speak, I am condemned.If I stay silent, I am damned!These lyrics let us peek into the internal struggle of Valjean as he wrestles with his decision to turn himself in or to let another unjustly suffer in his place. He knows that if he turns himself in, he will be condemned to a life in prison. Indeed, he is, in essence, trading his life of luxury for a life in prison. But he also knows it's the right thing to do; hence his feeling of damnation from God if he doesn't do what his consciences declares to him to be right.Fantine's "I Dreamed a Dream" is a similarly powerful song about the naiveté of youth and the loss of innocence (mostly due to her premarital affair and subsequent unplanned pregnancy and birth of her daughter, Cosette).He slept a summer by my sideHe filled my days with endless wonderHe took my childhood in his strideBut he was gone when autumn cameAnd still I dream he'll come to meThat we will live the years togetherBut there are dreams that cannot beAnd there are storms we cannot weatherNow I am pretty sure I could have followed the plot in the movie even if I had not taken the time to read the book. My wife, who had the same trouble I did when we saw the musical, followed it much better this time around also and she has not had the benefit of reading Hugo's tome. The quick timelines appearing as text on the screen alone helped immensely. So I think it's safe to see the movie without already being familiar with the storyline. Of course, it could just be that my wife and I have had the benefit of seeing it twice.Hooper's rendition of the famous musical is simply superb; one of the best musical big screen adaptations in decades, in my humble opinion. Indeed, I think the movie might even resurrect the genre to a certain degree. It certainly has mainstream viability and the ability to capture fans, like me, that don't normally see these types of movies. I heartily recommend seeing the movie. It certainly deserves any and all of the attention and critical acclaim it receives this award season.
summary: Beautiful movie preaches grace and forgiveness

reviewText: You know I went to see "Les Miserables" on Christmas Day. You know I convinced family and friends to not get together for dinner on Christmas evening, as was the tradition, because seeing this film was more important. I've been waiting to see "Les Mis" for months, damnit, and I wasn't about to wait any longer. I was ready to see something phenomenal. Something that would be a sucker punch of emotion...and a chance to see some of my favorite actors in a film like I've never seen before."Les Miserables" is unlike any film musical I've ever seen. The level of emotion is unmatched. The performances are out of this world. The story is ambitious, and the scope is huge. It's at once a very personal story about its various characters, but at the same time, these people are singing for a generation, that has fascinating parallels to events going on today. It's an incredible feat that I didn't think could be committed to film so well.Director Tom Hooper certainly had the courage of his convictions. A film adaptation of Cameron Mackintosh and Claude Michel Schonberg's beloved stage musical "Les Miserables" had been in development hell since the mid 1980s. The pieces for a successful film adaptation never quite came together. A non-musical adaptation of Victor Hugo's novel starring Liam Neeson and Uma Thurman came out in 1998, but that film was sub-par at best.Hooper assembled a cast that doesn't seem like the best fit for a musical, including Hugh Jackman, Russell Crowe and Anne Hathaway, none of which, to my knowledge, are trained singers. He then decided that these actors, as well as everyone else in the cast, would sing live, instead of lip-synching to studio-prerecorded tracks. I had not known that movie musicals typically did it this way, and that singing live was a new and scary thing. This element would heighten emotion for the audience. This idea is superb and will show to be a game-changer for movie musicals. Each actor's performance is more intimate and personal than they would have been otherwise. Hooper really wants the viewer to connect emotionally with these characters, and for the most part, we connect with these people deeply."Les Mis" follows Jean Valjean (Jackman), a man who was jailed for nineteen years for stealing a loaf of bread for his starving family - five years for the theft, and thereafter for subsequent attempts to escape. He breaks his parole, and police inspector Javert (Crowe) dedicates his life to imprisoning Valjean again. Valjean comes across Fantine (Hathaway), an unwed mother who, after unjustly losing her job, is degraded to the point of no return, being forced to sell her hair, her teeth, her body and her dignity. Valjean promises Fantine that he will raise her daughter Cosette as his own, in her absence. Valjean then saves Cosette from the Thenardiers(Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter, pairing up in their second movie musical), neglectful guardians and scheming inkeepers, and the story picks up years later, where Cosette is a young woman (Amanda Seyfried), living mostly in peace. A young revolutionary Marius (Eddie Redmayne) falls in love with her. The Thenardier's destitute biological daughter Eponine has a hopeless and unrequited love for Marius. These young characters dive headfirst into what would become a very important part of the French Revolution.The story of the French Revolution, as depicted in the film, is so reminiscent of Occupy Wall Street protests that went on last year - a group of young idealists looking for a better tomorrow. They're willing to die in the name of a future. They're extremely passionate and exuberant. There are protests, except, you know, they're all sung.Yes, it's all sung. Les Miserables is two hours and forty minutes of song. There's no real spoken dialogue the entire way through. Every minute is sung live as well. And if this bothers you, please skip "Les Mis" and enjoy watching something like "Twilight" or "Jack Reacher". Tom Hooper made this film a game-changer for the way a movie-musical is supposed to work. Lip-synching a pre-recorded studio version seems economical, but today, can allow for auto-tuning and editing a singer's voice. It doesn't feel personal. The voices in "Les Mis" sound raw and real. The actors sang live onset with earpieces playing piano accompaniment, with a 70-piece orchestra being added in in post production. The music sounds extraordinary. There sure as hell isn't any auto-tuning going on.For example, take Anne Hathaway's rendition of "I Dreamed A Dream". At this point in the story, we don't know Fantine very well, but we see the struggle that she's put through. She's at her lowest point. Hathaway half-belts and half-sobs the iconic song, the entire thing being filmed in one take. It's an extremely emotional performance that will bring any person with a heart, to tears.Criticism that I've been hearing of the film mostly revolves around the performances of Russell Crowe and Hugh Jackman, as Javert and Valjean. I think both of these guys did fantastic jobs, quite frankly. Crowe isn't the best singer in the world, but his voice fits the part of Javert very well. As for Jackman, well, it could be argued that he carried the entire film. I think he did a splendid job; the role of Jean Valjean is a giant undertaking, and I think he nailed it.However, the real excellence of this film lies in the supporting cast. Everybody is perfectly cast, but particularly Samantha Barks in the role of Eponine. She played the same character in the 25th Anniversary performance of Les Miserables, only two years ago. One small criticism; my favorite part of Eponine's solo (and theme song to self-loathing masochists everywhere) "On My Own", the beginning part, is cut entirely. However, once you see what Barks does with this song it's easily forgiven.Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen, who look like they're in "Sweeney Todd 2", are great comic relief as the Thenardiers. Cohen is the only cast member in this Paris-set film who sings in a French accent, however... I find that strange. Eddie Redmayne and Aaron Tveit are perfect as Marius and his colleague Enjolras. Redmayne's "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables", near the end of the film, will make you cry. His voice goes to extraordinary places, and in such an emotional number, where he's telling the story of his friends who are no longer with him, this is a place where the live singing truly shines.The live singing, itself, is a huge undertaking, cinematically. Director Tom Hooper certainly had alot at stake with this project, however, there are still things that he could have done better. There are so many close-ups in the film. While they work for solos like "I Dreamed A Dream" and "Empty Chairs", they don't work for others. I also kind of feel like Hooper used the fish-eye camera lens a little too often, but these are inconsequential criticisms that don't make the film any less powerful.I hate it when people applaud in a movie theater. I find it trite and kind of pointless, unless you're at the world premiere of the movie, with the director and actors present. However, I'm not ashamed to say that "Les Miserables" brought me to tears no less than five times. I was completely enthralled by each actor's performance, and the applause that the entire theater gave at the end was completely appropriate and well-deserved. I wanted to watch it again the minute it ended, and for a nearly three hour long film, I think that's a pretty high compliment. Don't miss it.Grade: A+
summary: A cinematic and emotional wonder; a film for the ages.

reviewText: What can one say about LES MISERABLES that hasn't already been said?  It is a magnificent film, the best movie musical in years.Director Tom Hooper deserves acclaim for taking the huge riskj of having the singing performed live instead of later dubbing---something never done before.The use of actors who sing rather than singers who can't act gives the music a raw, unfettered quality that is often emotional and frequently overwhelming.  Hugh Jackman is superb as the tragic Jean Valjean, making it hard to believe he's the same actor who plays Wolverine.  Oscar winning Anne Hathaway is devastating as Fatine.  With only 15 minutes of total screen time, Anne's I DREAMED A DREAM is simply awesome!  The most powerful moment, however comes from newcomer Samantha Barks whose ON MY OWN is show-stopping perfection.  Colm Wilkinson's Bishop and Eddie Redmayne's Marius are likewise excellent.  The child actors are incredible, especially David Huttlestone (sp).  Let's remake OLIVER and have him star!  Sasha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter provide great comedic relief.I'm not a fan of Russell Crowe but his Javert does have an impact in spite of his merely passable singing.Amanda Seyfried makes a lovely Cosette but she pales in comparison to Barks and Hathaway.Every technical detail from costuming to production is flawless.LES MISERABLES is a rewarding movie experience and one I highly recommend!

reviewText: For fans of Les Mis, this is the movie to own: it is a fine drama in its own right, and surprisingly successful in putting across the larger-than-life 19th century romanticism and melodrama of Victor Hugo's original novel. Some things have to be said with more than words, and this musical says them. It has a big heart.In adapting it to the big screen, director Tom Hooper opted for quiet and intimate vocals rather than the full-throated Broadway style. Given this treatment, some of the songs have less impact, and at times their instrumental accompaniment is almost inaudible. But this style of "whisper-singing" is so great for the actors!Among a stellar cast, Hugh Jackman carries the show both vocally and dramatically. I was less convinced by Russell Crowe, whose singing was not up to snuff and whose characterization of Javert never quite came into focus for me. It was a pleasure to see (and hear) a shockingly deglamorized Anne Hathaway take huge chances and succeed wildly as the doomed Fantine; and casting the incredible, the beautiful, the hilariously funny, the totally twisted Helena Bonham-Carter as Madame Thenardier was a stroke of absolute genius.The ultimate test of any movie is what it leaves you with, and whether you want to see it again. For me, the redemptive conclusion of Les Miserables, after all that had come before, packed a huge wallop. It actually brought a tear to my eye, and what more can anyone want?

reviewText: "Les Miserables" is, first and foremost, Victor Hugo's tragic tale of one man's lifelong quest for redemption. Jean Valjean, having served 19 years hard labor for breaking the law in France around the time of the revolution, is a bitter and hardened man. But a series of events in his life turn him towards God, and on the path of redemption. He continues to do good deeds, even while pursued by lawman Javert.This movie, being an adaptation of the popular musical, manages to stay the closest to Hugo's original novel of any movie or musical adaptation I have ever heard of, and that is a good thing. The musical is also known for its amazing music, which has all been translated over as well. Some have been critical of the music aspect, saying that it isn't the "pretty" music, as it is all recorded live while acting (rather than dubbed in later), and that some of the actors are not very good singers. I admit to not having an expert's ear for music, but I found the music as wonderful as any rendition I have heard, if not more so. Perhaps it is not as "pretty", but it feels far more passionate, and real when performed this way. I find myself relating to these characters more than I ever have before for this "uglification" of the music, and thus I believe it is all the better for it.Aside from musical purist snobs, or those who simply hate musicals, I have a hard time imagining why anyone would not enjoy this film. It is well worth it, even if only once, for the experience alone. I am glad that so many people can now enjoy both this story and this music now that this movie musical has been made.
summary: A Beautiful Tale Set to Beautiful Music

reviewText: I was honored to be able to treat my mother and myself to see "Les Miserables" on opening day---Christmas Day. In all honestly, I needed someone to go with since this is my all time favorite musical and novel. Nonetheless, my mother too loves the music. How good was it? At the end there was an standing ovation in the theater. I've never witnessed that in my life. Yes, it's that good."Les Miserables" takes place in 19-Century France that evolves around the story of Jean Valjean (played by Hugh Jackman)---an ex-convict who turns his life around and meets Fantine (played by the amazing Anne Hathaway), an unwed mother. ****Spoiler Alert*** Fantine passes on and must take care of her daughter Cosette. Obviously this is a musical so pretty much all the dialogue is all sung but it is done marvelously. As everyone may have heard it, the actors sang live; no per-recording, no lip syncing. Pure live singing. I'm not going to lie, it makes it even more real and raw. Definitely not a disappointment. For anyone who love "Les Mis", they will not be disappointed with this adaption. I do believe though that they could have found a better Javert (played by Russell Crowe) but for the sake of being real, Crowe does a decent job as Javert. So don't judge him too harshly. Another fun fact: the original Broadway Valjean plays the Bishop of Digne! That was a great surprise.For those who are fans of the Broadway may be a little confused because some of the orders of songs have been changed, but if you look at it, it works better this way. And it makes a little bit more sense to have it like this. Just a warning, but believe me you won't even care to correct it in your head.The reviews were right, Anne Hathaway shines in this movie! Her version of the famed song "I Dreamed a Dream" is so great that there is no words. You'll probably cry, as did my theater at that part, and at the end. I'm not ashamed to admit that I too shed a few tears."Les Miserables" is more that just a regular musical, it's a story that somehow everyone can relate to. It's a story of hope, redemption and promise that no matter if you're in the worse times of your life "even the darkness night will end and the sun will rise".  Something that we all need to hear right now. You'll laugh, but you'll mainly cry and reflect and relate. A heed of warning though: this is a 2 1/2 hour movie so it may not be for everyone as it is also a musical. But give it a shot, it isn't a girly musical with a sappy love story. It's about life.So join the crusade and grab a box of tissues and a friend and watch "Les Miserables"!
summary: Do You Hear the People Sing?

El-Hewie

reviewText: Tom Hooper ("The King's Speech") pulls out all the stops in this newest iteration of Victor Hugo's tome.  Adapted from the 1985 musical stage production by Cameron Mackintosh, the movie is large, loquacious and long.  One of the first things you'll notice is that each cast member handles their own songs and does it live...and in one take!  Not only that but Hooper puts his camera right in the face of the actor much of the time.  There isn't a tear, a spec of dirt or a nasal drip that goes unnoticed.  It's actually pretty remarkable.  The film is loaded with talent and every actor handles his or her music well and rarely misses a note.  And when they do, it is an emotional hic up which would be expected.For the uninitiated, the film takes place in Paris beginning in about 1815 and ends about 20 years later.  Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman) is a prisoner who has served 19 years of hard labor for stealing bread.  He is released but he is given papers that label him dangerous so no one will hire or house him.  Starving and freezing, he seeks refuge in a church.  He then steals several items of silver.  When caught, the priest says he gave them to him.  This second chance changes Valjean who changes his name, eventually becomes mayor and tries to do good in the world.One of his employees at the garment factory he owns named Fantine (superb Anne Hathaway) is summarily dismissed by a supervisor because she had a daughter out of wedlock.  Resorting to selling her hair and her body to care for her daughter she becomes seriously ill.  By coincidence, Valjean discovers his earlier slight and takes responsibility for Fantine's daughter Cosette (Isabelle Allen then Amanda Seyfried).  Valjean is constantly dodging Inspector Javert (Russell Crowe) who thinks he recognizes the now much different looking mayor.As Cosette ages she becomes smitten with a young firebrand named Marius (excellent Eddie Redmayne) who is one of the leaders of a fledgling people's rebellion.  One of the surprising (to me) standout performances comes from Samantha Barks in the role of Eponine, who is the daughter of a pair of inn keepers (Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter) who housed Cosette when she was a young girl.  Speaking of Cohen and Carter, they provide some needed comic relief throughout the film as the thieves, scam artists and grifters to which they excel.So what, if anything, is wrong with this movie.  Not much, but I'll stick my neck out and say the music.  "I Dreamed a Dream" is probably the only standout song - OK maybe "On My Own" - and certainly it's hard to hold back tears when Hathaway delivers -  but other than that, nothing too memorable.  The lyrics certainly move the story along as they must.  Almost all the dialog is sung.  If you are familiar with the story, I suspect you will enjoy the film.  I did.
summary: If you are familiar with the story, I think you will enjoy the film

reviewText: I'm not a fan of musicals, but I did catch Les Miserables and The Phantom of the Opera when I visited New York City back in 2001. I was surprised to find that I enjoyed this one the most. The music was great and the story, while quite depressing, was well done.The big screen version did not let me down. Anne Hathaway is only in the movie maybe 15 minutes, but she steals the show. Her singing of "I Dreamed a Dream" in one take is almost too powerful. Her acting in this scene alone adds layers that the stage production could never achieve. Hugh Jackman makes a wonderful Jean Valjean and Russel Crowe has the presence of a good Javert, but he is the weakest singer in the cast. Not as bad as I had heard, so he was really better than I expected. All of the singing was done live while filming, so it's brave, but maybe the wrong choice for Mr. Crowe. Great visuals round out a film that no theater lover should miss.

reviewText: This is one of the best and most faithful adaptations of a stage musical to the big screen that I have seen. That being said, this is not for everyone. Nearly every line is sung. It is a tragedy filled with mostly sad ballads. Even the one piece of comic relief (Master of the House) turned out more creepy than funny. Still, if you understand this is a tragedy and that every one of the characters has a major sad aria, you'll love these performances.
summary: If you love the musical, you'll love the movie

reviewText: I have never been a huge fan of Victor Hugo and/or "Les Miserables" and I must say that performances to date have left me flat especially in comparison to creations such as "Cavalleria Rusticana" by Pietro Mascagni.  I did, however, spend a few shekels to watch the latest cinematic version from Tom Hooper.  OMG!!!  Genius, Tom.  Pure GENIUS!I immediately ordered the DVD from Amazon just to re-watch Anne Hathaway perform "Dream," which I predict will become an essential addition to precious moments in cinematic history.  This cast has made me re-evaluate Hugo and "Les Miserables," and to finally see what I have been missing.  Miss Hathaway's one glance downward and to her left, in abject misery, made me swoon and I don't swoon.  Those of you who have seen this film know the exact moment of which I speak.  Her voice is unique in a sea of voices and her range (working hard on the low notes) is stupendous.Russell Crowe singing?  Russell Crowe was Russell Crowe as in every one of his performances: PERFECT.  His rough, imperfect voice is what we should expect from a life-long cop, but his imperious, murderous glance froze me with fear as only Russell Crowe's deeply sparkling eyes, full of hatred, can.  Even in his lesser roles he commands attention, but he usually turns in a performance that is LARGER THAN LIFE.  In Les Miserables he proves that he can and does everything!Hugh Jackman is huge-o (forgive me) as Valjean.  Absolutely the pitiful protagonist that I never liked.  I am converted to a compulsive fan.  Amanda Seyfried has the sweet innocence of an angel with a voice to match.I was surprised and enjoyably fascinated by Sasha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter who scored bulls-eyes as they usually do.Congratulations to all.  You converted a sinner.  Anne Hathaway, will you marry me?

reviewText: I'm conflicted about Les Mis.  The story is excellent but so damned depressing that my feelings about spending my time watching a story like Les Mis are mixed.  The production was amazing with costumes, cast, story and songs.  There's no denying it was extremely well made and the cast did a fantastic job considering the footsteps they were following and even exceeding sometimes.  Russell Crow has to have big brass ones to follow Geoffrey Rush but I thought he did an excellent job though I wasn't as thrilled with the way the death scene was written, still I thought Russell did the best anyone could have done with it .  There are no spoken lines.  The entire film is done in song.  The story is excellent as ever (albeit depressing).  It's a classic story and  I'm glad I saw it, but I just can't say I enjoyed spending the time seeing the film, and I can't honestly say that I'd bother to see this version of it again.  If you enjoy musicals and enjoy the story you will probably love this film.

reviewText: Despite being a great admirer of musicals, for whatever reason, I never got into the whole "Les Miserables" fandom. Perhaps this stems from the fact that I find the voices of the principle cast members from the original London and Broadway recordings less than enjoyable. What selections I had heard sung by other vocalists interested me in the music; and, not having seen the show live on stage, I went into this film with not much in the way of expectations. When I came out, I was more than impressed; I was blown away. The music was wonderful, the costumes and sets gorgeous, and the acting...Well, let's just say that more than a few Oscar statuettes are going to be passed around between this marvelous cast.For those who don't know it already, the story of "Les Miserables", written by Victor Hugo in 1862 and set in France in the first half of the 19th century, concerns Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), a convict, out on parole after spending 19 years in jail for stealing a loaf of bread. After the intervention of the kindly Bishop of Digne (played by Colm Wilkinson), who convinces him to "become an honest man" and foster a belief in God, the story follows him as he attempts to escape from his past life--and the dogged Inspector Javert (Russell Crowe)--his interactions with various characters, and the repercussions that these interactions will have. Like the title suggests, the film is not a jolly, old-fashioned, toe-tapping extravaganza. Most of the film is either heart-wrenching or gut-wrenching, oftentimes both, and isn't afraid to deliver tough emotional blows one after the other; yet, despite the overabundance of death and despair, I was inexplicably uplifted and inspired in a way that only a good musical can achieve.It was a genius decision on director Tom Hooper's part to have the actors sing live instead of favoring the more traditional method of recording in a studio and lip-synching later. They are much more "in-the moment", and bring a more truthful sound to the music. While they seem to be a bit more restrained than if they were live on stage, which, for anyone who is used to the typically, big, bold sound of Broadway, might be a little disconcerting at first, it makes the performances so much more raw and real than what one typically expects to find in a movie musical; and with almost every song from "Les Mis" being more of a soliloquy with instrumental accompaniment than anything else, it works like a charm. Hopefully this will set a precedent for movie musicals in the future.Even if you think you know the songs already, it's like hearing them for the very first time, they sound so fresh and unique, with elegant yet unobtrusive new orchestrations and thrilling vocal performances across the cast. Anne Hathaway's bravura, one-take rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream" brought me to tears, and Hugh Jackman's "Bring Him Home" is quite possibly the most beautiful and touching version I have ever heard. The new song "Suddenly", written by the musical's original composers especially for this film, is excellent, adding some much needed optimism to the score (as well as a nice breather!), and is perfectly suited to its place in the film--sung by Valjean after he has rescued little Cosette from the cruel Thenadiers. Jackman brings a deep poignancy and tenderness to the lyrics, which might be due to the fact that he is an adoptive father in real life.Although most of the dialogue is sung-through rather than simply spoken, the acting is as good or better than in a regular, non-musical drama. Anne Hathaway will break your heart as the unfortunate Fantine, who is forced to sacrifice everything she has for the sake of her child. Her acting ability has really reached new heights, and don't even get me started on her singing. The few pieces to which she contributes her voice to had me bawling my eyes out. If anyone deserves a Best Supporting Actress Oscar this year, it's her.Hugh Jackman is so good as the reformed convict Jean Valjean it would be hard to imagine anyone but him in the part. At last, he has been given a role worthy of his prodigious talents--the only thing he doesn't do here is dance! He so completely becomes the man, transforming himself into a nearly-unrecognizable shadow in the first part of the film, it is almost impossible to tell where Valjean begins and Jackman ends. His voice is powerful and thrilling, and he does a great job of making each song his own. I could listen to him all day. Even if you don't like musicals, you should still see this, if only to enjoy his stellar performance.The rest of the cast are also uniformly incredible, including Eddie Redmayne, a total musical surprise to me, who, as Marius, is a great romantic lead; Samantha Barks as the poor, heartbroken Eponine; Russell Crowe as the conflicted, duty-bound Javert (who knew he could sing?); and the incomparable Helena Bonham-Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen as M. and Mme. Thenadier, who provide a much-needed, if slightly Sweeney-Todd-esque, comic relief to what would otherwise be non-stop despair. The only weak link in the chain is Amanda Seyfried as Cosette--her voice is quite thin--but wasn't so bad that it ruined my enjoyment of the songs. It was also great to see Colm Wilkinson, the original Jean Valjean, as the Bishop of Digne.What I found most refreshing about this production is that director Tom Hooper isn't afraid to let this film be what it is, a big screen adaptation of a musical--loud, theatrical, often implausible, and unashamedly heart-tugging--yet for all its broadness, the overall feeling is of something quite intimate, not nearly as bombastic and overblown as the trailers would have you think, and very character-driven. It is the music and the emotions that are epic, not the movie itself. Just as he did with "The King's Speech", he makes you become so deeply connected to the characters themselves that you're ready and willing to be manipulated to experience any emotion on their behalf. Case in point, by the finale, I was weeping like a child. While he might have gone a bit overboard with the whole steadycam/closeup thing, it really does put you right in the middle of the action--how often do you go to a live performance where you can see the tears in the actors eyes before they've even fallen down their cheeks?The only real problem I had with the movie was with the plot itself (too many characters dying tragic deaths, too much melodrama, too much focusing on the student revolutionaries, and, towards the latter end, too much time spent behind barricades and in cafes instead of fighting). All of this drags the film out a little longer than it should, but it is Victor Hugo after all, and his work is the epitome of French literature. For anyone worried about content, there wasn't really anything worse than what you might see in your average PG-13 movie, no real nudity, and only brief language, but some of the scenes involving prostitutes were a little excessive at times, and certainly not necessary to deepen my emotional connection with the main characters.To conclude, "Les Miserables" is a real masterpiece, with a fabulous cast and some of the most beautiful music ever written. I can't say any more about this film other than that is an emotional rollercoaster, and if you can ride it out, it is well worth the trip. Just be prepared to have lots of tissues on hand when you do.
summary: A Masterpiece: An Intense, Emotional Film With Intense, Emotional Performances.

reviewText: There are three distinct chapters to the Les Mis story. First and foremost is the original book by Victor Hugo, first published in 1862.  It eventually became considered one of the greatest novels of the nineteenth century. As early as 1935 an english language film adaptation of the book became the second chapter. As the book was an enormous 1500 pages long, it was understandable that the movie was limited in how the story could be re-told. There have been several film (and television) adaptations since that early version and all have been limited by how much they can fit into a relatively short period of time. The third chapter was written when two french men, Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg decided to try and produce the story as a musical in 1980.  It originally only lasted about three months and was severely criticized by the literary world.How ever, just as there is a faction which enjoys great literature, there is a faction which just as fervently enjoys great music and with the english version of the musical (lyrics by Herbert Kretzmer and supported by Cameron Mackintosh of theatrical production fame) the musical became a resounding success.So there we have the three distinct chapters, the book, the film adaptation and finally the musical.  It should be remembered that the musical was produced in the realm of a stage production. As a consequence, the performers needed very little in the facet of acting experience but they did need to have studied theatrical production and of course, have the ability to sing. It is because the casts chosen for the various theatrical productions were chosen for these reasons that the stage production became (and still is) such a success.And now we have those who would like to add a fourth chapter. A film adaptation of both the book and the musical.  Now this is a combination which could only work if those chosen to portray the various characters could both act and sing. And unfortunately whoever was responsible for "casting" this production seemed to concentrate more on a performers acting ability than on their singing ability. Perhaps it was considered that as a movie, it needed the "big name" acting stars to be successful.After all, who would want to go and see a movie full of "unheard of" actors, no matter how good their singing ability.Ultimately, the production failed to produce what it was originally intended to produce. Even the "big name" stars efforts suffered because of their lack of musical talent. Hugh Jackman, in his own right is a very accomplished actor but his acting performance suffered simply because he did not have the musical capacity to deliver the necessary combination of acting/singing.  And poor old "Rusty" Crowe. Mumbling and bumbling along in one of the most mono tone efforts at singing that it was difficult to know which were his spoken words and which were sung. The whole performance was only held together by some of the smaller name performers,like Eddie Redmayne (a suprisingly good performance as Marius) Aaron Tveit as Enjolras and good old Colm Wilkinson (an old and bold from the theatre) as the bishop.Overall, if they had simply tried to make a movie adaptation of the book (and leave the music to the satge) they may have had some chance of success and that would have left the three chapters of the Les Mis story intact.  If the fourth chapter is ever going to become a success and take it's part in the history of Les Mis, then they will need to keep in mind that they will need to find performers who can both act and sing.  At the time of writing this review, they have yet to find the combination which works.When Cameron Mackintosh was finally convinced to take on the stage production of the musical, he was unsure of the outcome but he took his time and finally with the help of a lot of people in the theatre business and a couple of years work, he put together a very succesfull production. It was a pity that he seemed so eager to rush headlong into this movie production. If he had approached it with the same degree of caution which he gave the stage production, he may well have succeeded.  Unfortunately he didn't and just as unfortunately, he failed.

reviewText: I love Lez Miz......love it. I have seen it on stage 7 times. I read the Victor Hugo novel (huge and haunting). I have viewed it as dramatic film 3 times (well actually there are two of the film versions that I have in my video collection and watch whenever I catch them on cable). I also have the musical on video in the form of the 25th Anniversary Concert and the Dream Cast in Concert. It has four of my all time favorite "show tunes": Look Down, At the End of the Day, Do You Hear the People Sing, A Heart Full of Love. AND the line in the finale speaks to the deep truth in this fine play:  "To love another person is to see the face of God."I enjoyed this 2012 treatment of the musical. It is gorgeous- France takes center stage; although the actual sites are almost entirely English. The orchestras (four of them) pull out all the stops. The acting is top drawer. BUT, the singing is not as gloriously elevating, or deeply heartrending, or gut split funny as it was on stage. Why? Well....Hugh Jackman as a fine cabaret voice; Russell Crowe is one of my favorite actors and he does a good Rex Harrison talking-song; Anne Hathaway has a good voice better at sounding hurt than outraged; and the rest of the cast is much the same. This could have been a disaster but the directors decision to mic the actors as they did each scene and to record their live singing rather than going to the studio works because it is the drama that carries the singing and not the other way around.I own the DVD because it is an essential part of my Les Miserables collection, just not the best part even though it made nearly $450 million dollars. WoW!
summary: Great Drama, Fantastic Settings, Powerful Orchestrations, Uneven Voices

reviewText: I have to give this a decidedly mixed review.My first impression before the film's first hour was over was a silent reminder "don't buy the soundtrack." The singing, even from Hugh Jackman who acquitted himself so well as "Curly" in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "Oklahoma!" is, to put it charitably, just passable. Russell Crowe does as well as can be expected since he is a non-singer to begin with, but the others do not have the kind of voices that are needed to put over this kind of material.Cinematically, it's a bit over-the-top with its wondrous camera views from high places. Nothing is done to suggest that the squalor isn't real. The mud is as muddy as possible and the make-up (in extreme close-ups of Anne Hathaway for example), is enough to convince us that these wretched people had nothing to sing about.Not being a fan of the show and familiar with only a couple of the songs, I was not expecting to be thrilled by the score alone--and I wasn't. Whether you have an appetite for these kind of musical numbers is clearly a matter of taste. Most of the lyrics are as downbeat and desperate as the story itself suggests.A much needed touch of humor is furnished by Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen, although some of the humor is a bit gross and overdone.The almost unrecognizable first appearance of Hugh Jackman as a slave hauling a ship with his comrades as Javert (Russell Crowe) looks on, is an astonishing moment. Jackman looks nothing like his real self, so part of his performance can be attributed to a marvelous make-up job. But he does well with the anguish and pain of seeing so much suffering around him. Anne Hathaway is obviously a singer/actress who does all she can with the powerful emotions she displays in her big scene, but her role, although noteworthy, is a small one in the scheme of things.Despite the power of some of the performances, the overall effect for me was a story that was not well told because of script problems, making it a confusing mess for anyone not familiar with the basic outline of the tale since it leaves out important plot details.Your musical taste will decide whether or not you love or hate this film, but it's fair to say that the songs are not rendered in the best possible way by having them performed live. The pre-recording of all the lyrics would have enhanced the big numbers which required more vocal ability and professional technique than is offered here.Summing up: Definitely not for everyone, but the squalor of the French Revolution period is magnificently realistic with lavish, detailed sets and costumes that convey the right atmosphere. Stunning photography is evident in the final scene where Crowe's conscience forces him to take drastic action.Biggest flaw: The lack of tension and connection in the cat-and-mouse game between Crowe and Jackman that was so powerfully portrayed in straight dramatic versions of the story filmed previously which sharpened the suspense. Both the '35 and '52 versions had this added strength of characterization. Instead, Crowe's realizaton that he has found and recognizes Valjean is done much too casually to have any real effect in building suspense.
summary: Epic tale would have been more impressive with real singers...

reviewText: I think it's safe to say that waiting for this film was pretty agonizing, both for director Tom Hooper's recent successes in The King's Speech and the John Adams mini-series, for for the renown that this book/play/film has accumulated ever since Victor Hugo penned it, and for the well-known cast that has shown a different talent through viral trailers.Because I don't know the full history of film adaptions, I won't be delving into the comparisons with such, but the history of the London (Queen's Theatre) play has been on the mind, since I took a trip there this spring to watch it performed live. It was an unforgettable experience, and while this adaption had a few pitfalls, it came close to that in many ways.An inescapable topic is the singing. In the first scene, Crowe (Javert) and Jackman (Valjean) moved the words into odd tempos, and their voices sounded a bit shallow (Crowe's in particular). With the exception of a great (if short) sequence, "A Work", it was a poor opening on the musical front, and they tried to erase it from our memory by quickly distracting us with landscape shots. After that, both Crowe and Jackman got louder, bolder, and much more appreciable. Anne Hathaway as Fantine was amazing. She provided one of the three best song performances in "I Dreamed A Dream", which was very heartbreaking and hardening. Next up comes Young Cosette, who did very well with "Castle on a Cloud," and made viewers sorry that they didn't hear more from her. Helena Bonham Carter did respectably, I suppose, but Sacha Baron Cohen's not a singer, and "Master of the House" had to rely solely on the acting and humor. The real disappointment, though, was Amanda Seyfried (Cosette), in my opinion. While her voice may be very good in other circumstances, her shallow trill didn't do justice to the opera-level voices that Les Mis has seen in the past. Instead, I favored Samantha Barks (Éponine) in every way, including acting. Her "On My Own" was possibly my favorite song from the whole film, and definitely making the top three. Finally, there is Eddie Redmayne (Marius). He is definitely a talented actor I will be watching for. And, he's a marvelous singer, too! Very down to earth, and very loud and bold when he ought to be. His "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables" also makes the top 3.As usual, there were some problems I had with the edits. Here and there, lyrics were changed, removed, and even added, which disappointed me. The worst part, I think, is when they cut nearly the entirety of "Turning" after uttering only a few lines. I can only hope it will come out complete in the extended version.**SPOILER ALERT** As my final point, for the whole movie, I'd been wondering how Hooper would portray Javert's suicide. I think he did it very well, and it was my favorite scene in the entire movie, for Crowe's great performance in it, the allusion from earlier in the film, the great scope and imager, and for Crowe's final song, in which he brings his best to the table. I had no idea he was as great a singer as he was at his character's final moments. **END SPOILER**I would not suggest this movie for kids under 13, because they simply wouldn't understand a lot of the underlying themes that make this movie really important. Also, there is some suggestive,  inappropriate material after Fontine is removed from the factory and resorts to the docks.In conclusion, this is a large-scale, impressive adaption that is definitely worth seeing as soon as you can manage, even if you aren't a big fan of musicals.
summary: A few issues, but otherwise magnificent.
