reviewText: The definitive version of "Les Miserables" for our time is Bille August's brilliant telling of that story with Liam Neeson doing full justice to the grandeur of Jean Valjean's Christ-like persona and Geoffrey Rush unforgettably menacing as the perversely principled, and ultimately tragic, Inspector Javert. The equally important role of Fantine was interpreted with Uma Thurman's intense pathos and Claire Danes rounded out that superb cast with an impressive rendition of Cosette.I continue to look back at the sheer artistry of this film,  its success in crystallizing the core depth of the main characters and its remarkable incisiveness in transposing the profound dramatic theme of that massive novel in an effective, highly dense, two hour film, as a small miracle in the recent history of great literary adaptations in cinema.I began this year at the movies with the hope that the much lauded and anticipated Tom Hooper 2012 musical version would conserve the spirit of the novel in the way Bille August did it fifteen years ago. Tom Hooper's imaginative feat is impressive and his screening of Amanda Seyfried, Hugh Jackman, Anne Hathaway, Eddie Redmayne, and Russell Crowe as Cosette, Jean Valjean, Fantine, Marius, and Inspector Javert, respectively, has merit. There is much inspired labor that has gone into Tom Hooper's "Les Miserables"  with the individual reprisals of each of its characters, with their accompanying songs, capturing the emotional "highs" of the novel.But the Hooper version of the great epic does not live up to its promise. While it is a good adaptation of the novel it falls short of the artistic merit of the definitive 1998 Bille August adaptation. This is not to say that the impressive sets and exacting imagination of Tom Hooper does not touch the high emotional notes of that drama. All this is to be found in this version. But when all we have are high emotional notes the pitch of tragedy is drowned out. The poetics of tragedy need the emotional lows to set the emotional highs in appropriate contrast between the characters of Javert and Jean Valjean; the much needed interlude of speech was found wanting. Prose as much as the poetry of song was needed to let the emotional weight of the characters permeate our consciousness. We long for the music, fantastic as it is in moments, to quieten for a while, and let the drama emerge in turns through conversation, through the ellipses of spoken discourse. If only this was an adaptation where song and dialogue blended into each other to set the contrasts of emotion that much more stark in some of those brilliant song numbers.The spirit of the novel, its tragic sense, in its telling contrasts of the characters of Jean Valjean and Inspector Javert is diluted, even stunted, in this musical adaptation. This is an odd problem that I have seen recur in the famed broadway staged version as well. The deepest emotional moments in the book are often found in the quieter moments of this great melodrama. It as if the key reversals in the drama, Jean Valjean's conversion in the early book, and Inspector Javert's defeat in the end, required music interspersed by long intervals of silence, to let the emotions drop into our soul at the end of long protracted building up of character. The dramatic might of a character like Javert and Jean Valjean in this version is allowed to emerge in a musical narrative in an episodic fashion. The episodic musical set pieces when characters break into song take turns building and demolishing the character.Hugh Jackman proves he is a formidable talent. He is all there, in character, from those unrecognizable shots of him as a bloodshot, worn down, helpless convict he has become under Javert's whip and chains, to those images of utter control, dignity, and empathy as the Mayor of Montreuil-sur-mer. Jackman surely succeeds as Jean Valjean, he does all he can, and he cannot do more. But where he succeeds gloriously in his convincingly commanding voice of the saint-like ex-convict, he soon bumps up against the formalistic restrictions of a purely musical performance.Anne Hathaway succeeds poignantly as Fantine; but if only she was allowed to lapse into speech, to have her "settle" in to that wonderful character that was waiting to be further developed. Amanda Seyfried is beautiful in her fragile and luminescent way and her looks have a way of settling her into character in her more modest role. Her singing is exquisite but she is also allowed to linger and take in the rhythms of her character a lot more than the central characters. The biggest surprise was Eddie Redmayne, who has the single most emotionally wrenching song, after he loses his comrades in battle. Like the Cosette character, Marius as supporting actor, is not overburdened by belting out one song after another. The supporting actors are done a great service by being left to define their performances as much by silence as by song.The shock of the film was the Inspector Javert character. I expected Russell Crowe to be as effective, if not more striking, as the Geoffrey Rush rendition of Javert in the 1998 version. His performance, good and respectable as it was, was not characteristically inspired. This is after all the great Russell Crowe, an actor who seemed to carry the burden of lifting the standards of acting single-handedly during a period when acting in American film needed a new face and voice. His great performances in The Insider, Gladiator, A Beautiful Mind, Master and Commander, Robin Hood, The Last Three Days set me up for another inspired performance. Like Brando, Crowe has had the remarkable ability of transcending the movies he has been in and if there is any actor who  could breathe new life into a film of the scale and power of "Les Miserables", after Geoffrey Rush's inspired turn, it would be him. Crowe has the range and subtlety to bring a fresh interpretation to the venomous, perverse, and tragic Inspector Javert.But it was not to be. This is Jackman's film from the first to the last frame. Crowe is strangely disengaged in the role. The crucial moment of reversal in Inspector Javert's life, during his great moment of resignation at the end of film when he admits to being wrong, and he submits to Jean Valjean's superior principle of compassion, ought to be the point of emotional climax in the film. In Hooper's hands this moment becomes a bombastic moment that undoes the dramatic power of the moment. The numbing paradox of following the law down to the letter is Javert's supreme moment of recognition; see how beautifully Bille August sets about capturing the emotion of this scene. Geoffrey Rush as Javert proves that the emotion at this moment is one of quiet failure. It is a crushing moment for Javert and a moment of release for Jean Valjean. The sense of tragedy is that of good triumphing over evil in a muted, subdued, way. There is a dignified admission of failure, but there is hardly a celebration of victory on the part of Valjean. This is a sad moment for both of them. During this supposedly meditative moment Hooper makes the wrong decision to have Crowe break out into song. The singing seems so out of place. I was hoping that Crowe would be spared here and allowed to lapse into speech; not because he is not a good singer here, he ably is,  but because this dramatic moment called for a quieter form of emotional depth, an almost lyrical moment of silence, a hushed soliloquy at best, rather than an operatic burst into song.To say that this 2012 version of Victor Hugo's epic, is a good, rather than great, version of "Les Miserables" is to say first that this film succeeds in scattered, though, inspired episodic moments of song and character. Tom Hooper's labor of love was, however, not translated well to an effective poetics on screen and was not sustained in the form of an emotional tour-de-force of a drama of good triumphing over evil, which was what that 1998 version superbly brought about in the perfect casting and performances of Geoffrey Rush and Liam Neeson. To register this distinction between good and great literary adaptations I recommend seeing both these versions as closely together as you possibly can. It will give you a sense of how the use and abuse of music has the net effect of diluting the emotional contrasts of the story.

reviewText: I read a lot of the reviews the first day because i discovered that neither the Blu-RAy nor the regular DVD would allow me to pause and resume or pick a scene. After testing my player on several other DVDs and BRDs, I can tell you it is this set and not my player. I guess there was a rush to get the movie to market.It's a movie, not the best but not the worst. Hugh Jackson is great, as is Eddie Tremaine, and I thought that Russell Crowe did the best he could with a script that limited his character's story. Understand that they had to limit the duration of the movie. Maybe better to limit the on-going chanted dialogue and increase time with the actual songs. Normally I like Anne Hathaway but I agree with others that she didn't show any of her character's strengths. I think my complaints are more against the director.Interesting - while i was waiting for the  movie to recycle through the first hour when it restarted at the beginning rather than resume after pausing - I turned off the sound and occasionally watched the actors without sound. Impressive acting!

reviewText: Having only seen lesser versions of this in local theater and growing up with the music around, I watched this movie having no real expectations. The music was well done. I wouldn't be able to tell which songs were missing. I noticed that during a lot of the songs, it was just a close up on the actor singing it the whole time. I found that stylistic choice strange, but at the same time, it was nice to see the emotion close up in the actor's face. That is something you don't get if you are sitting fifty feet away from the performer in the musical play. The movie got through Hugh Jackman's character's story well. But I didn't find myself terribly compelled by his adopted daughter's love story with the young revolutionist. I don't know if it is developed more in the musical, but I really did not care about their relationship at all. Now a note on the PG-13 rating: It definitely deserved the PG-13 rating it received. The sexual content mentioned in the mpaa rating is actually more graphic than you'd expect. There are two sex scenes where it is very clear what is going on. So you might want to think about that if you are taking younger kids. Also the violence was mostly bloodless and implied, however, you do see a lot of blood on the ground and in the gutter after the battle. Overall, the movie was worth watching with good music. Hugh struggled to hit a few high notes though. I won't be rushing out to see it again, but I am glad I watched it.

She was made for the movie role.When you have people in these rolls who can really sing well, it makes those who cannot stand in deep contrast.  While Mr. Crowe's acting is not in question, his singing ability is sub par to say the least.Eponine, Marius, Cosette, Enjolras, Gavroche...all were spectacular.  Even Fantine was believable.I am certain I will watch this movie any times over.

reviewerName: Paul D. Race "Writer, Teacher, Songwriter, Ra...
reviewText: Many musicals have failed the transition from stage to screen.  This does not.  The script and some of the characterizations are DIFFERENT from the stage play. But I've seen the play more times than I can count, and I would have to say that I have seen bigger differences between one professional production and the next.Before this came out, I read the book, then rewatched the Liam Neeson version and tried to watch the Michael Rennie version.  My conclusion from reading the book is that there are so many characters, so much backstory, so many Dickensian plot twists, etc. that ANYBODY who can make a single coherent story out of the thing without it being ten hours long deserves great praise. By the way, if you question this sentence, try reading JUST the Wikipedia plot summary - it will leave your head spinning, and it leaves out numerous characters to whom Hugo gave backstories and plot arcs, as well as several plot twists.I especially enjoyed the inclusion of visual elements that were compelling in the book but which would have been impossible or distracting to present onstage.  These include the decrepit war-memorial elephant in which Gavroche lives, the geometry of the streets and buildings where Enjolras and his comrades erect the barricades, the bottomless pit in the sewers that nearly costs Jean Valjean and Marius their lives, and the confluence of watersheds into which Javert leaps, ensuring his death.  Other changes that folks have found disturbing express the spirit of the book, even if they're not technically from either the book or the play.  This includes Javert showing Gavroche honor at the end.  Frankly, I don't mind that the director used that original scene to replace a whole (and somewhat silly) chapter that shows Javert's growing crisis of conscience.The "reviewer" who complains that Anne Hathaway played Fantine as TOO miserable obviously hasn't read the book.  Or paid attention to its title, apparently.  With the exception of Russell Crowe, who seemed to hit one emotional note and maybe three musical notes throughout the entire movie, the cast was well-chosen and each brought their "A-game."  By the way, this is the only Eponine I have ever found truly sympathetic (most never get beyond pitiable).Some have chosen to complain about plot elements which seem weak in the play and still seem weak on the screen, such as Marius and Cosette falling in love "at first sight."  Well, "A Heart Full of Love" is not my favorite song ever, but it's better than reading Hugo's FOUR chapters about why "love at first sight" happens.  Again, kudos to both the play and the movie for successfully bridging that gap and many others that are even more awkward in the book than they are in the play or screen.Thanks again to the musical producers who managed to get a coherent, compelling presentation out of a massive, complex, and sometimes contradictory tome, and to the movie producers who managed to be as true as possible to both the book and the musical while still making a ridiculously good movie.  - Paul Race, School Of The Rock
summary: Faithful to the book and play

reviewText: (I rented this from RedBox, but I am putting the review here).This is not a film of the musical. This is a film of the novel, using the music from the musical, and butchering almost every song in it.I have no idea how good a film of the novel it is, as I have no interest in the story as such. My interest is in the musical.I own many DVDs which /are/ films of a musical. There are many ways of making a film of a musical, from filming it on stage, to doing it as a film but not straying too far from what was possible on a stage, to rethinking it into a film and doing things impossible on a stage.The main problem here (for most of the songs, that is, the ones that were botched) was that the actors kept trying to express emotion /independently of the songs/ and so did not do the songs properly because they were too emotionally distraught. The whole point of a musical is that the /song/ conveys the emotion, not the actor. The actor's job is to sing.Also, great as she was in /Novocain/ and great as her "all three witches of Endor combined" persona was in the Harry Potter series, Helena Bonham Carter's Madam Thenardier is only the second-worst because Sacha Baron Cohen's Thenardier is, hard as it is to believe, worse.Granted, the film sort of comes together toward the end. One or two of the songs are done right. Javert shows some humanity, which is welcome because nobody else in the film shows much, and the Thenardier's almost work at the wedding. And while it is a pity that their song at the wedding is cut, bowdlerizing lyrics and dropping whole songs or verses to songs is a long-standing tradition in make a film of a musical, and so is regrettable but not really a cause for dislike.
summary: This Is Not How a Film is Made of a Musical

reviewText: Act 1 Scene 1 begins with silence and within seconds the sound trumpets loudly with the force of Beethoven's 5th symphony. We see a French Warship leaning to one side and at least half a dozen ropes running from it when the scene cuts to prisoners righting the ship and pulling it into dry dock.The singing begins and surprisingly, Hugh Jackman (As Jean ValJean) does a decent job with his vocals and can actually carry a tune, "Look Down, Look Down" and a cut to Javert standing on the side of the docking bay starring down at the convicts pulling the boat into the bay.Within Minutes, Javert is up and man, I have to say I am starting to question the casting of Russell Crowe in this part. I cannot tell you what Javert was singing because Crowe's voice was horrible at best and easily the worst in the movie, so bad in fact that I wanted to mute the movie (but, I resisted).The scene finishes with ValJean getting parole for the rest of his life. He served 20 years, 5 of which was for stealing a Loaf of Bread, 15 were for running from the law.Scene 2 is ValJean realizing his past is following him but, he gets taken in by the church, given food, and a bed. He repays them by stealing most of their Silver and is rounded up by the police and returned to the Church where, the priest corroborates ValJean's claim that the Silver was given to him. Later in the scene the priest tells him that his soul was purchased for God by that silver and he is now a changed man. ValJean struggles with the idea that somebody holds that much value in him and uses the Silver goods to start a new life.Without going much further into the story, a whole series of connected events lead up to ValJean taking on a new identity, violating parole, being exposed and adopting a child with whom he takes on the run with him. The whole time is set on a burgeoning Revolution and his whole life is spent running from Javert (maybe if he stopped singing ValJean would have stopped running) and raising his adopted Daughter.The highlight of the movie comes with Fantine's solo (Anne Hathaway) and is really one of the most powerful performances I've ever seen. I honestly believe that Anne Hathaway was feeling very deeply when doing that take as there was a point when she seemed truly distressed and she is easily what put the movie over the top.The lowlight was clearly with the casting and there's no way, I would have even considered casting Sacha Baron Cohen in any role of this nature and yet they did! There was one scene where the Inn keeper was peeing into the wine bottles of his patrons, no joke and it really seemed awkward. Also, as soon as Crowe started singing I would have found a replacement in a hurry!The biggest surprise in the movie, Samantha Banks as Eponine. She has a fantastic voice and really shouldn't have been playing second fiddle to Amanda Seyfried (Cosette) as far as continuity goes.Did I like the movie? Yeah, it was a very good and solid movie but, the lack of french accents in France, some poor casting choices, and set design that seemed to peak early on left you with an incredible begining and an average ending.Is it worth watching? Yes it is but, I preordered the movie and now I know why it was only $14 as it was good but, failed to live up to the hype so, rent it first and if you like it that much, then buy it.It is really a 3.5 star movie but, I'm giving it the benefit of a 4.
summary: A Mixed Bag Of Good And Bad.

reviewText: After seeing  a dvd of the film ,I was very disappointed. What went wrong? The acting was  superb as expected.The music  memorable, but I failed to get involved  with the  show which was over-long and bordering on the tedious in places.Almost the entire  film looked like the camera's lens was covered with a dark filter.Why? The rapid editing  really annoyed me. It seems to be the trend today but  in this film they went overboard. There seemed ,for the most part,a new camera angle every 3 seconds or less.I got  dizzy from the rapid  editing. You need to at least  look at a scene without  changing to another  in  a couple of seconds.It ruined the film for me. The opening  scene was  spectacular  but I thought it was totally over the top.There was no need to go back in time for the finale  as  many of the characters seen  were already dead.Filmed versions of musicals used to be superior to the stage shows but in this case the stage show  had a greater impact on me and was unforgettable.If you can get a copy of the  stage show then watch it and compare the difference.The film version was indeed Les Miserables.
summary: THE STAGE SHOW WAS FAR BETTER

reviewText: I just got back from seeing this with my mom. I've literally waited a year for this movie to come out. Don't listen to any bad reviews you may hear because this is one of the best movies I've ever seen.I don't want to spend too much time rehashing the plot, but I will say that its a meaningful story of love, sacrifice, redemption, hope, suffering, fighting and dying for what you believe, and having faith in god and the innermost goodness of the human soul. There were many times throughout the movie I cried or teared up. There was only one part I had a hard time watching and it had to do with the harming of a child. Otherwise, the violence and sex was minimal. Also something not everyone will enjoy is the recurring theme of religioun and a person's relationship with god. As other reviewers have said, this is an unashamedly Christian movie. It was something I enjoyed, but may not be up someone elsex 's alley.I thought everyone was very well casted, especially Hugh jackman and Anne Hathaway. They put their heart, soul, and body into this film. The cinematography was wonderful and so was the music. Don't go to this movie expecting it to sound like the Broadway or west end productions. This is completely different from how other musicals have been one and its best to appreciate the hard work the cast and crew broughtntonthe table in this highly successful musical adaptation.The difference between this musical and others is that its purpose is to bring a world of meaning to the viewer. I'm sure that many can relate to the characters, whether its Fantine' a single mother who tries desperately to protect her daughter. Or maybe Eponine whose love for Marius is in vain. Not everyone will like this movie and there are plenty of those who will find something to complain about. If you decide to try it out, go into it with an open mind.

reviewText: For somebody who is an ardent fan of both the stage musical and the 10th anniversary concert dvd (filmed at the Royal Albert Hall) this cinematic rendition was always going to have a lot to live up to.Russell Crowe is a marvellous actor, but his voice makes  him a curious choice for the part of Inspector Javert: his voice is too soft. The part of Javert calls for a strong, strident voice with a hard edge to it, and this is one of the reasons why Philip Quast was so good in the role. Crowe has a Crooner’s voice.By contrast, Hugh Jackman’s soft voice worked very well for much of the film, and his look at the beginning of the film was disturbingly reminiscent of the psychopath in the film “Slaughter of the Innocents”. As Valjean becomes more human, so Jackman’s soft singing voice suits him better.Whilst the film is different to the stage play and concert versions, with some lyric changes that will jarr with aficionados, and with a little less of the humour, it none-the-less draws the viewer along with a multi-stranded rope of emotion that reaches catharsis in Valjean’s final scene. The emotional Catharsis of Valjean’s final scene is made all the more intense for ardent Les Mis fans when the two Valjeans leave together.Anne Hathaway’s deep, gut-wrenching performance as Fantine is well deserving of the Oscar.Daniel Huttlestone goes a great way to relieving the weight of pathos as the cheeky and plucky mudlark Gavroche.

reviewText: The epic musical Les Miserables tells the story of a man named jean Valjean played by Hugh Jackman set during the dawn of the French revolution. After serving 19 years as a slave because he stole a loaf of bread, he breaks parole and spends years reinventing himself as a new man. Jean is being hunted by officer Javert played by Russell Crowe, who swears he will not rest until Jean is behind bars. While running from Javert, Jean Valjean finds himself caring for a factory workers young daughter, Cosette. The young child changes his life forever.Les Miserables is honestly one of the greatest films I have ever seen. This film is almost three hours long and I still wanted it to go on longer. Les Miserables is a very well known Broadway musical and the film stays so true to the play it is unbelievable. Not a single word is off. However, the one thing that changes for the better is that the movie version makes the story easier to understand and follow. I have been a huge fan of Les Mis for a long time and I know almost every single song by heart. I was trying so hard not to start singing along with the film. The musical score was amazing.The whole film is better than I could have ever hoped for, but seeing this tale up on the big screen is phenomenal! The visuals and special effects are truly breathtaking. It is set in France at the beginning of the French revolution when life for the poor was awful and life for the rich was grand. They capture the hard times of the streets perfectly by using dark colors and wonderful lighting contrasts. I loved seeing the world of Les Mis on a grand scale and exactly as I imagined it.I love this entire movie so much that when it was over I immediately wanted to see it again. I'm definitely going to see it again when it comes out in theaters. I have so many scenes that I love so much, but my favorites are the Lovely Ladies' scene and the Master of the House scene. I like the Lovely Ladies scene because that's where Fantine, Cosette's mother turns to the streets as a home after losing her job at the factory. It is a wonderful musical number and Anne Hathaway's performance is amazing! (Oscar Award for Best Supporting Actress) It is so historically accurate showing how people would do anything to make a quick penny from selling their teeth, to chopping off their hair. It was hard for everyone. I also love the Master of the House scene because it is so hilarious with Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter as the innkeeper and his wife. They con people into staying the night at their inn, then trick them into never leaving. They are so crafty and hilarious and they rob everyone blind. This scene is so clever and hilarious. Sacha and Helena make an amazing duo.I love all of the characters equally, but I'll only pick a few to talk about. Jean Valjean is a truly amazing character and Hugh Jackman brings him to life so well. Hugh's talents are really shown off during this film and I was very impressed by him. Fantine, played by the remarkable Anne Hathaway is a very memorable character. Anne is perfect as Fantine and this was, in my opinion, her best role. The last character that I really enjoyed is Eponine played by Samantha Barks. Eponine sings all of my favorite Les Mis songs and her incredible duo of A Little Fall of Rain with Eddie Redmayne. A little fun fact is that Samantha Marks played Eponine in the Broadway version of Les Mis.I give Les Miserables 5 out of 5 stars because it is truly the most amazing film I've seen in a long time and it far surpassed my expectations. This film is definitely for ages 13 and up because of the dark period it is set in and the violence and cruelty that occurs. Raven D, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.Raven's video review is online at kidsfirst dot org
summary: Loved seeing the world of Les Miserables on a grand scale. It is exactly as I imagined. When it was over I wanted to see it agai

reviewText: I went into this film without having seen the musical. Ultimately, what I found was a strong, very moving motion picture with some terrific songs. Performances are strong, especially from Hugh Jackman, Anne Hathaway, and Russell Crowe (I thought his singing was fine).The biggest quibbles I have of the film are over its direction and constant singing. Nearly the entire movie is sung through, which can make for a trying experience, especially during the film's slow spots. As mentioned constantly in the film's press and marketing, the film had the actors singing live on set as the cameras rolled. This works to underlie the emotions of the characters during the big musical numbers, but it works less well for when the actors have to sing their dialogue. It's often tuneless and flat, even from a great singer like Jackman! The film's director Tom Hooper likes to shoot his movies with fish-eye lenses and unconventional framing. Personally, I felt these were often distracting and distasteful, again, especially during the slow moments of the story. As things get going though, they're less of an issue.The movie presents a deeply moving story of one man's journey of redemption, which unfortunately gets sidelined during the second half for a thin and predictable love story. Still, it comes together quite nicely. The last hour or so is terrifically stirring and many of the big musical numbers are well done.Picture quality is solid and the the DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 audio is very dynamic. Both accurately reproduce the theatrical experience. Extras aren't plentiful but solid. There's a good hour-long documentary, an additional featurette on Hugo's original novel, and a commentary from the director which I chose not to listen to. The Blu-ray set includes a DVD and digital copies (iTunes and Ultraviolet).

reviewText: Les Mis is one of my favorite operas since I was a girl and watched it with my grandmother on Broadway. It's this tragic, heartfelt and heart-wrenching story of survival and love before and during the French Revolutionary War. It's beautiful... but this remake of it just lacks any of the heart of the operatic original. Too much of it is condensed or completely discarded, other parts are reworked to a more dramatic, showstopping kind of fervor that just doesn't work for me. I know it's a remake, so there are bound to be differences, but this was just a sad copy of what amounts to one of the moment beloved operas in the world.
summary: Too Over-dramatized, Not Enough of the Actual Plot

reviewText: Les Miserables 2012 has to be the most extremely riveting film adaptation of the most revered Broadway shows and novels to be produced thus far.  With an all-star ensemble cast, Hugh Jackman, Anne Hathaway, Russell Crowe, Amanda Seyfried, Helena Bonham Carter, and Sascha Cohen, Director Tom Hooper ("The King's Speech") has recreated the classic semi-operatic musical including its most trademark songs "I Dreamed a Dream," "Who Am I" and "One Day More."  When first glancing at the first few musical numbers, one may not help but to compare this film to other musicals that have been set onto film, "Phantom of the Opera," "The Wiz," or "Chicago."  But if one delves into the genre even deeper, the film may also have parallels to movie musicals, such as "Oliver," "Tommy," or "Moulin Rouge" because the actors are actually singing out their lines within the film that fittingly is well done.  However, a line is drawn, especially with this version of Les Miserables that specifically stands alone from the rest and outshines as well.The film contains an intense depiction of each of the main characters with fierce dramatic emotion and romance.  But the undeniable highlight of the film is the music itself that is performed by the actors that display their musical dexterity and experience that may most likely move the viewer; a reminder that music can easily translate to various interpretations especially if it is carefully selected and exceptionally played.  And within the first hour of the film, Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman) and Fantine (Anne Hathaway) are pure examples of how music may move an individual as well as the rest of the actors that are playing their part in exemplifying the major themes expressed within the storyline and the film; it is a storyline the weaves a tale of characters longing for a purpose that leads each into situations that tests their souls and progresses within almost a ten year span that begins with Jean Valjean and Fantine and the introduction of Fantine's daughter Cossette (younger Isabelle Allen and older Amanda Seyfried) that show the power and struggle of secrets buried and eventual truths foretold within a historic backdrop that takes place in France during a time of oppression and revolution of the mid-nineteenth century.  It is an epic film of cinematographic proportions from the hilly and coastal cloistered landscape to the dingy cityscape of bottom dwellers Monsieur (Sascha Cohen) and Madame Thenadier (Helena Bonham Carter) and antagonists such as Constable Javert (Russell Crowe) and romantics Marius (Eddie Redmayne) and Eponine (Samantha Barks) attempting to survive that looks a little like a Dickens novel of Tales of Two Cities that ring out the lines of "it was the best of times, it was the worst of times."  However, that quote was not even mentioned in the film but as one may watch, it connotes that thought in mind.  But aside from the parallels, the costumes and swagger of each of the actors bring the period alive.Les Miserables and its entire cast and crew are well deserving of all of the accolades and standing performances or at least hand claps at the end of the film.  They have shown that the sheer beauty of song and Victor Hugo's story has left a lasting impression upon audiences, and most importantly through music.

reviewText: If you've never seen Les Miserables in any form, then please, watch this movie.  This is an epic human story that you have to see at least once in your life.  This movie conveys the story well, and you should enjoy watching some of your favorite actors in a high-budget film.Now, for those of you who are Les Miserables gourmets, there are certainly things in this version that fall far short of perfection -- especially musically.  If you are a singer or a musician, please don't watch this!  You might experience physical pain as you listen to the marginal singers.  Russell Crowe, as Javert, was a particular disappointment; Cosette and Marius duets often bordered on laughable; and the innkeepers' scenes were abrasive.If, however, you aren't so musically picky, you might want to give this incarnation of Victor Hugo's novel a chance.  Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway portrayed ValJean and Fontine with their whole heart and soul.  While I'm not 100% endorsing this film, I am 100% in approval of Anne Hathaway's Best Actress award.  One cannot view her performance with apathy.  I felt that I was watching movie history when I viewed her scenes.  It wasn't over-the-top; it wasn't over-acting; it didn't feel like she was trying to win an Oscar.  It just felt absolutely right.While the singing is weak in spots, the acting, the story, and the overall scope of the film are all wonderful.  These are the reasons for the four-star-rating.
summary: For those who prefer emotion over perfection

reviewText: I was very impressed with the vocal talents of some of the actors in this movie.  I adore the musical and this novel is my absolute favorite.  I've read it twice.  The reason I did not give it five stars is this: the musical is best viewed as a stage performance.  Trying to put a work of this scope into a movie format, and squeeze it into even two hours is just not enough.  If you are going to put it on film, then you need to make it in several parts and cover it as close to the original novel as possible.  Otherwise, casual viewers will not (and did not in the case of my family) understand what was going on, and how very significant EVERYTHING was to the time the story was written.  Film gives you the potential to really put a work of this magnitude into context and give due diligence to the characters and plot.  The original musical takes many liberties with the story line due to time restrictions because they are performing in  front of a live audience, but the film version has the ability to truly portray this novel in all its brilliance and genius.  They did it with Lord of the Rings, and the same care and attention should be devoted to this masterpiece.
summary: My favorite book of all time....

reviewText: What a stunning and powerful cinematic triumph this is. A historical drama set to music...a musical dialogue of historical proportions. Adapted from a stage musical of Victor Hugo's 1862 novel of the same name. Beginning in 1815, 20 years after the French Revolution, and culminating in the 1832 June Rebellion in Paris, the novel follows the lives and interactions of several characters, focusing on the struggles of ex-convict, Jean Valjean, and his experience of redemption. The French were never very successful, at least during this period, in making revolution work; and the French people in the main were indeed poor, miserable, and wretched. Unlike other adaptations of Hugo's classic novel - and there are several excellent ones - the dialogue is set to music and the characters sing their lines. Hugh Jackman, as Jean Valjean, delivers a masterful performance, but dramatically and musically...he has a wonderful singing voice. The other main character, Javert, the police inspector, who pursues Valjean throughout the film, is played by Russell Crowe. Crowe also does well dramatically, but his singing voice is frankly less than adequate...but thankfully not so much as to detract from the overall quality of the film. Crowe and Jackman are the two stars, but the second most powerful performance in this film is by Anne Hathaway as Fantine...and can she ever sing. The balance of the featured characters are also perfectly cast, w/Eddie Redmayne as the revolutionary, Marius Pontmercy, who falls in love w/Cosette, played by Amanda Seyfried; and Helena Bonham Carter, Sacha Baron Cohen, as the Thénardiers, two swindling innkeepers...Samantha Barks, in her film debut, plays Eponine, their daughter. Can't say enough about the quality of this film as a historical drama, musical masterpiece
summary: "Oh my friends, my friends, don't ask me/What your sacrifice was for/Empty chairs at empty tables/Where my friends will meet no

reviewText: The singers and approach are great, but some scenes and special effects were irksome. I prefer the sparseness and darkness of the stage arrangements on Broadway, rather than the poorly crafted first few minutes, or the overly-colorful scenes of outside monastery. Things that worked well in the understated format of the stage just seem too grandiose in this film. It's just a matter of preference. Both can exist and do. I do feel sorry, however, for those who didn't see the stage version first.It was nice to see the original Jean Valjean playing the abbot! Without him the musical may have never been a success at all.I recommend at least listening to the original Broadway recording on CD before watching the film. The story is totally self-explanatory, and though the book is a huge hefty thing filled with philosophical asides and essays, that might be a good idea for some.I have to say: Hugh Jackman had scared me as a choice for this, because his work as Curly in Oklahoma was so lackluster (and I LOVE Hugh)...but his performance in Les Mis is sterling. Anne Hathaway is gifted and always has been, as a singer, and she did a swell job. Fantine is sometimes a sidenote in the stage version (and afterthought) and she was given the best female role (or in my opinion, she and her director made it into the best role). The young couple was adorable, and the young man/love interest was a great surprise to see, as I had adored him in Pillars of the Earth and Tess of the D'Urbervilles (BBC). We had no idea he sang so well. The young lady who played Eponine was so professional that it almost didn't suit her. She would be a much better live performer...oddly enough. I felt she emoted in a stage style rather than for a good close-up film performance. If you did watch the Academy Awards performance by the cast, she was the best part...and she had the chops and training and poise to sing live that the others didn't have. Many, I'm sure will be dismally disappointed by Russell Crowe's performance as Javert, as was I, but I knew beforehand that he wasn't a singer by any means. I felt mad that he had not been able to turn the role down, most likely. Who could, really? Javert is fascinating and the baritone/bass up to tenor range makes it the most challenging singing in the entire musical. I doubt any actor in Hollywood could have done it well. However, to point out his acting chops: even though he seemed far too depressed and worried about his singing to come across as a good Javert, he did have moments where he emoted the conflict within Javert better than anybody probably ever has. At moments in the barricade scenes, he defined what Victor Hugo was reaching for, and the role took on a 3-dimensional quality that you would never get on stage. The gray areas of Javert and his self-loathing for where he came from are very clear at moments, and I have to applaud Crowe for his acting abilities, given the setbacks. Just remember that Hollywood and British actors have all ruined well-loved musicals callously in the past: Richard Harris as Arthur in the film of Camelot, Vanessa Redgrave in the film of Camelot (who replaced Julie Andrews from the stage version), Even those actresses and actors who have had another voice dubbed-in for them have been very disappointing in the past: Natalie Wood's substitute in Westside Story, or Audrey Hepburn's part-time substitute in My Fair Lady (which also had belonged to Julie Andrews on stage)...even they were pretty lackluster and the director's could have had the pick of the litter instead.Overall, if you aren't hypercritical, I'd say this was better than I'd ever expected....and I'm a meanie.
summary: Better than I expected it would be

reviewText: I heard the singing was a little weak in places, especially at the beginning.The voices - not the recording technique. Russel Crow gets better later in the movie.This uses a new state of the art "live while film rolls" singing technique which is a littlerough in places since the orchestra is added later. As the camera rolls they sing live to a pianoin an earpiece. Mostly, they pull that off well.It does put a lot of strain on the orchestra later as they have to follow the mood and timing of the singer...Mine came with a BluRay+DVD+Streaming+ a digital D/L (locked to one computer?.)All for something I'd expect to pay for just a BluRay.I would have liked to get the referenced "4 hour *directors* cut" version on the BluRay, but most of that wasleft on the cutting room floor. I think they cut a little too close to the bone keeping it around 2 1/2 hours.Being a movie it can be more detailed as far as different things they can do that take longer on film...A stage version is limited to the stage and possible scene changes, the movie can explore all sorts of things.I have also seen this subject matter live on stage.

reviewText: This was my favorite show on Broadway.  If you expect a normal movie, some are going to be disappointed.  The dialogue is all sung with reoccurring musical themes.  But most of the songs are beautiful. The only part that fell short was first of all, Crowe singing the part of Javert.  Javert has two powerful songs that usually garners standing ovations.  Crowe's voice could not handle them and he gave the impression he wished he wasn't there.  Sad when there were so many Broadway singers that do that part so well.  This is a piece of history with the plot kind of squished together so you get the feel of the era and the injustice of it all.  It moves toward quite an emotional ending.  However the ending was not as powerful as it should have been because I think the directors were afraid of backlash from non-religious people.  They dumbed down the ending and therefore dumbed down the hope that you were supposed to be left with.  Anyone who caters to the politically correct instead of what was written is bound to have problems making it flow. You should see this either on Broadway (get good seats).  Or see the 25th Anniversary DVD concert they did in England.  There was enough acting with the songs and movement you will know what was going on and you can see the intended ending.

reviewText: This is not a bad movie by any stretch of the imagination.  It's the official film adaptation of the West End/Broadway musical Les Miserables (which is an adaptation of the French musical of the same name, which is based on the Victor Hugo classic - Whew).The Good- Ann Hathaway - Fantine is important, although she is relegated to being a medium character in the musical as far as stage/screen time goes.  She does as well as you can expect.- Russel Crowe - Probably the most controversial choice in the casting of the movie, I think he does a fine job.  I think he plays Javert a bit more introspectively than the inspector is usually played.  His singing is good (not great, but good.  I think those that listened to the cast recording are the reason we get that he sings so badly in Les Miserables.  On the cast recording, he is dreadful.  In the film, he is good.).  He's not Quast, but he really fills out a uniform!- Aaron Tevit - Maybe the best Enjolras I've seen.  Yummy to look at and just the right amount of intensity.- Daniel Huttlestone - A pretty good Gavroche.- Eddie Redmayne - I was leaning the other way until "Empty Chairs at Empty Tables."  To be honest, his voice sounded like a goose's honk up 'til this.  Then he cuts loose and wins me over.The bad- Hugh Jackman - Pretty much every reason that Crowe works as Javert is why Jackman doesn't work as Jean Valjean.  He was pretty much wrong from the start,  It's pretty interesting to say that the lead in a movie is bad when the movie turns out pretty good, but then again it is Les Miserables.- The cinematography - It's not that it is all bad, but it's so hit and miss as to be a distraction.All-in-all, it's a good movie (hence the 4 stars), but it could have been great.
summary: Better and worse than we should have expected.

reviewText: Tom Hooper's movie of "Les Miserables" is by far the biggest disappointment of the year and, in fact, one of the year's worst films. It wouldn't have been this way if the worthy project had been given to a different director.The original stage musical has been justifiably loved by many and won many awards in its various languages. Though flawed by its paucity of melodic creativity (there seems to be one song that keeps reappearing throughout with small variations) and a tendency toward over-bloating the material (Javert dies not from an ignominious death in a canal but a leap from a height that rivals the top of Mount Everest), the original musical was a masterpiece of adaptation from the Victor Hugo novel.The movie captures that accurately and perhaps beautifully but the beloved property has been undermined and eventually destroyed by the most incoherent and pedestrian film direction I've witnessed in at least a decade. In short, the film is a mess due to Tom Hooper's insistence of dizzying, relentless close-ups of grotesque singing faces spasmodically darting about, and his total inability to place two or three people into an organized and meaningful composed shot. Establishing shots are completely absent, and no attention seems paid to any visual relationships between characters, the organizing of which is a prerequisite for any director.One searches in vain for any intelligent use of space here, as Hooper haphazardly frames faces off-center, too high or too low, as if a child or a disabled grandparent inadvertently picked up the camera and aimed it without being able to see its image through the viewfinder.In the hands of a competent director a simple conversation (or a duet) between two lovers can be a thing of significance and beauty in which we experience one lover declaring love at the same time we experience the reactions of the other lover simply listening, but here all we get is one face at a time repeatedly shoved into our mugs in an assault as if an out-of-control jack-in-the-box puppet is out to get us. This is no way to convey the subtlety or sensitivity of a marvelous property like this epic musical. It only remains to see if the aficionados of the original have the good sense (and the imagination) to realize what this film could have been -- and how much they've been short-changed as well as dishonored.Sorry this functions as a mere footnote, but a word needs to be said about the singing. In essence, some are inadequate for the task (Crowe's weakness bothers me less than Jackman's irritatingly uncontrollable vibrato) but a few are marvelous (like Samantha Barks and David Heddlestone). However, it is truly Anne Hathaway's earnestness and heart-felt singing that towers over the rest of the movie and will surely garner her an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress.And in the future I can only hope that any project I value doesn't fall into the bungling hands of Mr. Hooper!
summary: I felt as if I were one of "Les Miserables"!

reviewText: Les Misérables is one of my favorite stories and this film captures it as well as any renditions I've read or seen. The story line is accurately followed but more important the specific scene selections are very well chosen. The libretto is beautiful and the music absolutely stunning. The fact that the singing is done live is totally obvious and that makes this film version very special and unique. The long single shot of "I Dreamed a Dream" could wring tears out of Mr. Scrooge. The emotion is so real I felt I could reach out and touch it. Well, well done.

reviewerName: Robert K. "Since hollywood wants to do nothin...
reviewText: What an abomination. I would have hoped that Les Miserables would be ONE beloved production that Hollywood could not completely destroy. I stand corrected. The singing styles combined with the acting -- an obvious product of horrific direction -- were awkward at best. Anyone who claimed that Hugh Jackman or Russell Crowe could sing is deluded to the point of needing medication. And anyone who claimed Anne Hathaway turned-in an Oscar-worthy performance wouldn't know a good actor if he/she slapped them in the face.Basically what you have in this rendition of the beloved musical, is a clunky, cringe-inducing half-measure that the Hollywood moguls actually managed to buttress with their last bastion of imagination: special effects. That's correct. They actually managed to pack this turd of a film with CGI special effects. Funny how the Geoffrey Rush/Liam Neeson version relied on terrific acting and an honest interpretation of Victor Hugo's book rather than flimsy computer effects. This musical (if you want to actually call it that) couldn't even manage to contain itself and stay somewhat honest to the stage production's already emotion-packed, heart wrenching story.Mind you, I've seen Les Miserables on and off Broadway and I can attest that this latest version is a sour attempt that was then propagated as some award-worthy film by the Oscar-voting crowd. Consider this: if those distant, arrogant "stars" feel the need to "lobby" for a film to win awards, what does that say about the film itself?
summary: A Film Concurrent With Hollywood's Drastically Lowered Expectations.

reviewText: ****1/2The long-delayed movie version of the stage musical “Les Miserables” has finally arrived - and the good news is that it is well worth the wait.  For the film harkens back to those glory days when musicals were massively-scaled, big-time events, and when all involved in their making wore their hearts unashamedly on their sleeves for all to see.“Les Miz” is, of course, based on the beloved Victor Hugo novel about the hardened convict, Jean Valjean, who devotes his life to helping others after a kind bishop shows him compassion and forgiveness at the darkest moment of his life. Through the course of the story, Valjean touches the lives of many people, but none so significantly as those of Fantine, the waiflike prostitute who has fallen on desperate times, and her daughter Cosette, whom Valjean dedicates his life to raising after her mother‘s death.  Valjean’s main antagonist is Inspector Javert, an unyielding stickler for the law who has made it his life’s mission to bring what he sees as a flagrant lawbreaker to justice, unmoved by all the good Valjean has done.With its vast array of larger-than-life figures, its melodramatic plotting, romantic flourishes and great themes of legal vs. natural law and the possibility of personal redemption - all set against the backdrop of sweeping social injustice in 19th Century France -“Les Miz” was obviously ideal material for composer Claude-Michel Schonberg and lyricist Alain Boublil ( with English translation by Herbert Kretzmer) to work with. In fact, so rich is the vein they’re mining here that “Les Miz” is closer to operetta than it is to those musicals of a bygone era, with very little spoken dialogue throughout the course of the movie. And this brings us to one of the minor quibbles I have with the film and with the show as a whole.For if there is a weakness to the film, it is probably the result of two factors: the inevitable difficulties inherent in trying to cram a 1200-page novel into a two-and-a-half-hour film, and the fact that the movie is entirely sung. The result of both of these limitations is that we lose some of the connective tissue that provides the characters’ motivations.  The story tends to move in fits and starts and lacks the cohesive flow that at least some dialogue might have provided. The constant singing also prevents the characters from engaging one another in conversation, which would help to clarify some of the finer details of the plot.  For instance, we don’t get a sense of why Valjean is so beloved as mayor of his town (he showed them how to manufacture jewelry more quickly and economically, thereby saving the community from ruin). We’re also deprived of the intense back-and-forth struggle between Valjean and Javert for Fantine’s soul.  Moreover, Valjean’s moment of great self-sacrifice, when he turns himself into the court to save the man falsely accused of being him, goes by so fast that many people, unfamiliar with the story, may not even understand fully what’s going on there.  Even worse, Cosette and Marius, the impulsive revolutionary who becomes the young girl’s love interest, aren’t even allowed a moment of communication before they’re pledging undying devotion to one another in verse.Yet, even with these flaws, “Les Miz” is a tremendously  moving and uplifting experience, unabashed in its sentimentality.  Much has been made of the fact that the singing was recorded live on set, a breakthrough that does indeed add a quality of immediacy to the production, even if the soundtrack will probably suffer in comparison to one of the many stage recordings that have been released over the decades.  Hugh Jackman and Anne Hathaway do a particularly fine job in the singing department, with only Russell Crowe as Javert failing to rise to the challenge to any appreciable extent. And there are many scenes, particularly in the second half, that are positively transporting: a poignant Hathaway nailing “I Dreamed a Dream,” Amanda Seyfried and Eddie Redmayne singing “In My Life,” Samantha Banks as Eponine performing “On My Own,” Redmayne singing the heartbreaking “Empty Chairs at Empty Tables,” the whole cast joining in on “One Day More” (the show’s homage to “The Quintet” from “West Side Story”), and the chorus performing the majestic “Do You Hear the People Sing?” which can’t help but lift your heart into your throat. And indeed your heart will be lodged there through significant portions of this movie.Tom Hooper (“The King’s Speech”) has directed the film largely as a succession of close-ups, which does deprive us of a sense of spatial geography from time to time but which helps to enhance the operatic nature of the piece.  And, oddly for a musical, there is no choreography to speak of, just as there wasn’t in the stage production.  For compensation, we have Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter having the time of their professional lives portraying the campy, comic-relief villains, the Thenardiers.Let’s just hope that the making of “Les Miserables,” and the audience’s obvious appreciation of it, will finally bring back the old-fashioned movie musical.  It‘s been far too long.

reviewText: I wanted so much to enjoy this when I saw it many many months ago, but it was truly an ordeal just to get through it.  And I have been a fan of most of the principals since early in their careers.  Plus I've enjoyed the show in more than one theatre, and have the 25th anniversary performance on Blu-ray.  Some have said that those who loved this as a musical are more apt to NOT like it and those who haven't seen it on stage are more likely to like it, and that is certainly true in my case.  The music never came alive for me, and there were moments when I was waiting for the music to reach certain notes, but it never did, because of the limitations of some of these actors who also sing, which was very disappointing.  After I watched this version on film, I pulled out my iPod and listened to the 2-disc London original with Colm Wilkinson and Patti LuPone and Michael Ball, and what a relief it was to hear these great songs sung by real singers!  Then I put on my Blu-ray of the 25th anniversary performance, which, while not 100% perfect, was head and shoulders above what I had heard while watching THIS misguided disaster.  As I wrote above, surely the most UNmusical musical I have ever seen on film.
summary: Surely the most UNmusical musical I have ever seen on film

reviewText: An ardent fan of the musical, I could not wait for this movie adaptation.  Though it earns its one star for effort, that effort delivers a musical movie that is claustrophobic, tortured and which strips the lush score from its passion and bigness at every turn.  The performances are isolated and disconnected from one another, and seem to be played only to the camera, which make them feel disembodied.  Everyone is heaving, sweating, dying, crying, sobbing, red-rimmed eyes swimming in dirty tears and gasps of pain.  The theatrical uplift and beauty of the musical version truly brings a heavenly respite from all this darkness, whereas the movie has no such comfort for its viewers.  Clearly, I see others' views are the opposite, and sure enough, when I saw this film in the theater many audience members were sobbing in the final scenes.  I bolted for the door.

reviewText: Imagine the scene:  A father has just accidentally intercepted a love note addressed to his only child, a daughter.  This letter reveals several facts:  The two have only met once.  She has given the young man a note confessing her love, and tell him she and her father are leaving the country.  The final fact?  The young man is currently involved in a rebellion against the government which he does not expect to survive.  Were this a scene in any other movie or TV drama I've ever seen except Les Miserables, this father would have surely said something like "Well, that's that, and she'd better get over him as quickly as she fell for him," before destroying the letter.  But this scene is from Les Miserables, which means something far more surprising happens instead.  More than almost anything else, Les Mis as it is called in short form, is a story about the conflict between justice and mercy.It is called Les Miserables, of course, because it primarily focuses on the miserable people.  This is a story about the oppressed, downtrodden, from whom hope has been stolen.  Characters sing, yes, but about things like being a slave, or feeling as though they are standing in their graves.  The world of this musical is harsh and unforgiving.  Each character faces despair, but none so thoroughly as Fantine, who, according to Anne Hathaway who played her, is the most miserable.  We see her life as a terrible downslide, with no kindness shown to her till it is far too late.  But of course, she is not the only outstanding character, or actor in the film.  Les Mis is an extravagant production, led by the always impressive Hugh Jackman, and including some very well cast and talented newcomers to my knowledge.  The scene, costumes, and singing are all brilliantly done, and the special features nicely add to my appreciation of these elements.  They also made me want to go and read the original novel by Victor Hugo.  Every member of this production who spoke waxed eloquent on how it was the true source of all this brilliance.They did not, however, talk about the unique method this filming of Les Miserables used for recording the singing, which I had heard about from other sources.  So as much as I recommend this movie, I also suggest getting whatever is the most deluxe edition available.  This is a movie for the ages, with perennial themes of justice, love, kindness, mercy, oppression, despair, crime, rebellion, and Hugh Jackman's incredible physical strength.  A true must-see, especially for the themes of grace and redemption.
summary: Even better the second time I watched !

reviewText: It's amazing that many reviewers who have reflected their feelings here seemed surprised, upon seeing the movie, that it is sung all the way through.  Les Mis has been around since 1985 and the fact that not only it, but many musicals written since the 70's, are sung all the way through is not news.  All of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals are, certainly, and Les Mis, with great acclaim, jumped into the midst of all that modern musical theater and has literally held up it's flag proudly all along.Les Mis is a classic story of a man's spiritual journey from being a bitter, resentful man who has not hope, to one who follows God and therefore changes many people lives for the better as their own lives intersect with his, except for Inpector Javert who, even though he does see the goodness of Jean Valjean, can't deal with it and makes his own life-altering choices.Is the movie all that it could be?  Probably not on all levels, but it really gets close.  Hugh Jackman has a long history with stage musicals and does a fine job.  Russell Crowe's singing is a bit lacking, especially comparing him with Philip Quast, the greatest Javert ever, but he does well enough.  Anne Hathaway's up-close interpretation is more emotionally intense than Patti Lu Pone's, but it works.  Amanda Seyfried does hit all the operatic Cossette notes, not with the skill of other Cossettes, but she does it.  Samantha Barks as Eponine hits a home run and why wouldn't she with her background.  Eddie Redmaine may be no Michael Ball, but he is a sympathetic Marius and he and Amanda do make a good couple.This is a great movie, it's great to have it on screen, and most who are familiar with the original stage presentation should be happy.For those out there who still don't like the "sung-all-the-way-through" aspect of Les Mis, you should probably be seeking out non-musical movies and plays in the first place.

reviewText: Why would anyone NEED to buy one more Miserables DVD when they've already seen first-rate versions of the stage musical multiple times and already own the 1995 "Dream Cast" concert version DVD (the one that winds up with all the world's best Jean Valjeans sharing the stage at the end), and also the powerful 1998 Bille August/Liam Neeson not-a-musical version?Two reasons:1. Because the brilliantly researched and recreated 19th century Paris sets and character closeups "bring it home" in ways that none of the above can do anywhere near as well,  and...2. Because rental copies contain ONLY the movie on them and NONE of the extras. The only way to see the key actors talking about their roles and the set designers showing us how they recreated 19th century Paris and the director's commentary...is to buy the DVD.

reviewText: The 2012 version of 'Les Miserables' was my first time seeing ANY version of the Victor Hugo classic, and in the very beginning it took me a bit to get into it - though once I did I really loved the story, the music, and how it all played out on-screen.The 19th-century story of Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman), who spends his life running from police captain Javert (Russell Crowe), after violating his parole (he'd been in prison for the "heinous" crime of stealing a loaf of bread to feed his starving sister's child), takes a new turn when Valjean also promises to care for the infant daughter of Fantine (Anne Hathaway's Oscar-winning role) when he feels responsible for Fantine's death.  How caring for Cosette changes Valjean's life, and perception of living - all in the middle of the French Revolution - makes for a grand-scale musical and, in the end, an emotionally touching film about sacrifice and love (corny-sounding, but true).  The incomparable Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen, as the insanely greedy innkeepers the Thenardiers, are so pitch-perfect in their comedy relief of all this drama, you may be tempted to hit the "back" button on your remote just to watch their scenes again.A wonderful film.
summary: More than just a "filmed stage play" - a beautifully-made musical with a heartbeat

reviewText: Les Miserables (2012) Hugh Jackman - This is a classic novel that transcends time, so I came to it already knowing the story from reading it for school. That, also, makes it come with high expectations.  Initially, I didn't like the delivery. My viewing came into it knowing it was a musical, but I expected some dialogue and that's not the case with this one.  However, the viewer gets used to everything being sung and realizes that speaking would take away from the relating of the story.  The performances and revelations of emotion are superb, well done. This version does require you to pay attention and it takes a lot of focus, so it's not a movie you watch again soon after.  You need a space of time in between viewings, but you find you miss it after a while as the songs dance in your head and the story tugs at your heart. Even if you've never read the classic book, please watch the movie.

reviewText: The new film adaptation of the classic novel and musical Les Mis is enjoyable but not without its own imperfections. For those who already love the play, this Les Mis for the most part sticks faithfully to the source material; offering some new great performances of songs now considered standards. For those who are film critics, this film is fine entertainment which at times works very well. There are two things I loved most about this film: Anne Hathaway and the sets. Anne Hathaway was without doubt the best part of the film; not only for playing a great Fantine that was both heart rendering and tragic, but also  for singing a rendition of "I've dreamed a dream" that was not only beautiful but agonizing in its despair. It's unfortunate that she is only in the first half of the film, because my main problem with Les Mis is that it doesn't consistently have that deep convincing fervor that was seen in her performance.Numerous critics have  panned Russell Crowe's Javert, and though I tried to like it ("Maybe he's purposely singing badly?"), I can't help but agree. I thought his performance was very bad: no vigor, no charisma, no menace, no life, and a congested voice.  The rest of the cast falls somewhere in between the bars that Crowe and Hathaway have set: most being good, but never reaching great. I liked Jackman's Jean Valjean, I liked Eponine, I liked Maurius, but I never felt any went to the next level. Many of the characters never felt as three dimensional and fleshed out as Fantine. Although Sasha Baron Cohen is usually very vibrant in his roles, here he and Helena Bonham Carter seemed oddly subdued.Not to say that any of these actors were bad, they weren't; there was emotion here. Yet for a film that portrays people going through such horrendous situations, I never felt it was enough. People react to different films on different emotional levels, so many will find these performances to be more powerful than I interpreted. But for me it just seemed like many of these actors were  going through the same motions of the actors that came before them, rather than looking deep within the characters themselves. Yes, Jean Valjean is a valiant character who has been through an incredible journey, but do what the book and play did and give me a personable reason to care, connect me with this character.The film ends on a resounding and empowering note, yet I couldn't help but feel I wanted more. This is a very grandiose film, at times tiresomely so, and for that I would recommend seeing it. The sets are fantastic, the costumes are authentic, and the music is of course powerful. I only wish that I felt more of an emotional connection with the characters who lived within this world, as I did with the book. The film and show are both nearly 3 hrs long, a very small time frame for an adaptation of an 1000+ pg. book, and for this I think the film does an admirable job of presenting such a huge story without losing THAT much of the plot. Again If you love the play and if you love the book, you will most likely find a sense of enjoyment here. But will it be as much? Probably not.3.5/5PROS: Some great performances, sets, costumes, overall a successful transition from stage to screenCONS: Russel Crowe, some of the performances needed more oomph!, drags toward the end
summary: 3.5  Not perfect but enjoyable at times

reviewText: Tom Hooper did an excellent job with this film. He took on quite the feat, trying to capture one of the most epic and moving musical ever on broadway and turning it into a movie. With so many ways that this could have gone tragically gone wrong, I believe he succeeded in capturing the magic, from the cast, to the sets, to the music.Hugh Jackman, playing Jean Valjean, and Anne Hathaway, playing Fantine, made some very trying life style changes to make this movie succeed so that you really get pulled into the story. I really believed them to be the characters they played.  Both of them have amazing voices that rose goosebumps on my skin. I was captivated by them at every turn.Amanda Seyfried shocked me with her high range and the delicacy with which she portrayed Cosette.I think the only part that disappointed me was Russell crowe as Javert. While he's a great actor and he has a surprisingly good voice, I was not a captivated by him. I often felt a little disconnected with his character as though he wasn't as interested in playing Javert. He has certainly done a lot better with getting into character in other movies than he did with this one.

reviewText: As a huge "Les Miz" fan, having seen the stage version probably 10 times, I was eagerly anticipating the film.  After Hugh Jackman's Oscar nomination and Anne Hathaway's win, I was certain it would be a fabulous experience. Had I never seen the Broadway productions, I may have been entranced, and so there is bias in this review.  Those who have never seen a performance on stage may be happy with the acting and the abbreviated snippets of song as well as the portrayals of the various characters.  So, here are the pros and cons from my viewpoint:Pros:  Hugh Jackman manages to capture Jean Valjean's character, his fundamental decency, his heart.  He does a good job vocally, and he engages the audience even through the stilted, sung dialog.  You have to care about Jean Valjean, and thanks to Jackman, the audience does so.Eddie Redmayne is a perfect Marius!  This British actor is not well-known to American audiences but his is a breakthrough performance, and we are sure to see a lot more of him.  And--surprisingly--he's not only good looking (in a typically English way) but by golly, he can sing!Anne Hathaway deserved her Oscar. 'Nuff said.Cosette was well-done also, although she struggled a bit with the vocals.  Her looks--perfect!As others have mentioned, the script did manage to portray the Christian message of love as salvation, carried out through forgiveness, compassion, caring for others, humility, and grace.  Its all there, and it isn't overdone.Cons:  I assume the songs had to be truncated to economize on the length of the film, but sadly, this sacrifice felt to me like throwing away the popcorn and eating the box.  I very much missed the orchestra, and especially the musical themes that reappear throughout the score of the beloved stage show, interwoven with one another.  Some of the solos, like "Who Am I...Jean Valjean" really sacrificed a great deal emotionally because of being shortened and without the orchestration.  Ditto for Fantine's death solo.In most of the Broadway shows, the Innkeeper and his wife are portrayed very differently--more as buffoons, and less as slimy, lecherous harlequins.  When portrayed as rather doltish clowns, the Innkeeper's "Master of the House" number is a hilarious, audience-rousing, almost joyful highlight of the show.  It allows us to laugh a little at this couple's stupidity, greed, and self-deception.  Alas, that isnt the case in the movie version.  The scene comes off as grisly and distasteful instead, with the Innkeeper and his wife cast as outright sociopaths, rather than clueless victims themselves of poverty and illiteracy and their own limited life circumstances.What happened to The Pup?  He is so central to the final scenes of the Broadway version--an elfish, beguiling youngster, who just captures your heart.  That makes his songs at the barricade particularly engaging and his death heartbreaking.  This movie somehow misses the mark.  Another opportunity lost.Others have castigated Russell Crowe's performance of Inspector Javert.  I like Russell Crowe.  But he took on a script that made his character into a 2-dimensional, Snidely Whiplash character, and he wasn't up to the vocals.  What can I say. To appreciate his acting chops, check out "Master and Commander", in which he is every inch the British seacaptain.So, in the end, if you are looking for anything close to the stage performance, I'd save the bucks and buy another ticket to the real deal.  If you have never seen Les Miz and don't mind the Cliff Notes version, this could work for you.But remember, you're getting a plain hamburger, not a Ruth Chris steak dinner :)

reviewText: I bought this on the strength of the trailer - something I normally do not do. Hathaway and Jackman were definite draws, but unfortunately in the scope of the bigger picture (vs. the trailer which was focused on them), they do not pop as anticipated. I can't over estimate how much I LOVE Hugh Jackman's singing and acting, but I think the part was too much for him. He was good, but not great. As far as Hathaway, well, she's not got the talent for Broadway. Her acting is fine, but her singing is weak - especially when combined with acting. It was like she was trying to act the songs instead of just feeling them. It came across as way overdone. The radical weight loss and cutting of her own hair makes a dramatic story, but didn't help her performance. Once Hathaway (Fantine) dies, the movie picks up A LOT.Crowe, well, I don't even know why he was cast in a musical. He sings like he talks. His two solos were his strongest.The standouts, in my opinion, were Bonham-Carter and Baron Cohen. "Master of the House" is always a show stopper, but this was magnificent. I had to see it twice. There are obvious differences to the stage show, which is expected, but the differences are what make it work. Redmayne (Marius) gave a surprisingly good performance as well! Who knew the guy could sing? He was excellent! He's definitely moving up in the world. Barks (Eponine) and the ensemble revolutionaries were EXCELLENT. The non-Hollywood stars made the whole thing vibrant and alive.I couldn't have imagined how the creators could pull off a film version of a theater production, but they succeed wildly.Maybe I am sentimental and emotional, but the story is FABULOUS. The sets, costuming and make-up make the perfect impact. I am probably drawing on my emotional connection to the theater production as well. When you add it all together, it is a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

reviewText: Unfortunately, I was rather disappointed with the new movie Les Miserables.  I expected a much more powerful result from the director of The King's Speech which is one of my favorite recent films.  I've seen the Broadway show twice, a few high school productions of it, and I've read Victor Hugo's book.  I've even played in an orchestra for a theater troupe that did Les Mis so I (like most of us) am very familiar with the characters, story, and the music.  One of my favorite musicals!  But I still nit-picked.First the good:  I thought the film's costumes were fantastic and the sets were very well done, though the wide-angle shots displayed some very unconvincing backgrounds.  Anne Hathaway's performance was by far the best in the movie; she certainly deserved that Oscar.  Despite being skeptic of Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean, I was impressed with his performance also.Criticisms:  With the exception of Anne Hathaway, not a single character/singer put much passion into the songs - a critical element considering such a passionate story with passionate music.  I thought Russell Crowe did very well as long as he wasn't singing.  When the characters sang "One Day More," I felt as though they were thinking let's-just-sing-this-real-quick-and-get-it-over-with, and the actress who played Cosette was killing me with the vibratos (it's not an opera, honey!).  Helena Bonham Carter was hilarious as she always is; too bad Monsieur Thenardier couldn't match her antics.  The dialog among the characters felt very jostled, as though they were always in a hurry to sing the next song - this resulted in a very odd pace and left the viewer thinking that the whole thing felt rushed.I will recommend this film to anyone who has never seen the musical and is curious of what all the hype is about (may want to first borrow it from the library or a friend or find it in Red Box).  There are also many other (and better) movie versions of Les Mis.  But to really gain a full appreciation of one of the best theater productions ever composed, you really should see it on stage.
