reviewText: Now, before you yell at me about the differences between stage and screen, I do know that they are different genres, and they present the works in different ways.  That having been said, I will begin with the things I did like.  Anne Hathaway's performance was breathtaking.  It is not the "pretty" version of "I Dreamed a Dream" we are used to, and that is not only ok, but completely appropriate.  Hugh Jackman is not Colm Wilkinson, but he did make the role of Jean Valjean his own.  I think having Colm on set was good for Hugh.  Colm could act as a mentor of sorts, and Hugh did a great job of showing the growth in Valjean over the course of the show.  Sasha Baron Cohen and Helenna Bonham Carter, two performers who I usually do NOT like, were fabulous in the roles of the Innkeeper and his wife.  They were deliciously evil and unscrupulous.  Cosset, who I usually find tedious, was portrayed in a much more in depth manner than I have usually seen, and I actually liked her.  Marius was good, but the actor has a sort of permanent smile on his face, which bothered me just a bit.  The student revolutionaries were magnificent.  Certainly a high point of the show.  Eponine was magnificent as well!Now for the low points.  First and foremost, Russell Crowe was awful as Javert.  His singing voice was shallow, and his acting was one dimensional.  I would have much preferred an unknown who could sing and act over Crowe.  The only other thing that I did not like was the director's apparent fondness for showing bodily fluids, and I don't mean blood.  If I never see another sweaty face or runny nose again as long as I live, that will be fine!With all of this, I would still recommend that anyone who likes musical theatre to see this.  If you have never seen Les Miserables, it is a must.  If you loved the stage version, you may have a few issues with this version, but keep an open mind.  After all, it is a different genre :)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Les Mis has had people wanting more since the beginning of its time. If you have ever seen the stage version the music so completely overwhelms you and sweeps you up that it's a miracle you can keep yourself from marching up on stage for the grand finale! And yet you also think, "Man, what if they incorporated amazing sets and acting and made this a real play... it would be EPIC!" And then you see the movie version and you just know that Liam Neeson is the perfect Val Jean, that if only every man, father, guardian were as he the world would spontaneously erupt into heaven; and that all the Javerts of the world would be compelled to commit suicide because Geoffrey Rush portrayed him so perfectly as the despicable villain that somehow still makes you feel sorry for him. And yet you are left thinking, "Man, what if they could sing too, and combine this incredible story with the soul hailing music... it would be EPIC!"Everyone looking forward to the new Les Mis, myself included, just knew that it had the potential to be the most EPIC of all EPIC movie experiences in the history of EVER! Which is why, I think, we have tried so hard to love it. Against our better judgment we act like it HAS to be amazing, because if not the disappointment will consume us, because there is no way in our lifetimes they'll ever re-do this movie. We desperately NEED to love it!But the problem is, it's just NOT epic. Not even close. It leaves you worse off than the play or the non-musical movie because now they've worked you up for nothing.We get a sleazy, staccato Val Jean who seems afraid to hold any one note too long for fear we'll realize his vocal ineptitude and who can't for the life of himself remember if he's merely haunted by his evil past, or continues to be haunted by an evil nature. It's a sad day in Les Mis history when Val Jean hasn't been able to present his good will, up-standing moral character and changed life well enough that when he comes upon Cosette in the woods all you can think is, "Run AWAY, little girl, don't you dare tell that creep your name, you're better off with the Thenardiers!"And then there's Javert.... Oh where do we start? Russell Crowe's singing "ability" (if you can call it that) makes you pity him so much you wish for his sake he'd just thrown himself off the dock at the beginning of the movie and gotten it over with it. There's no denying that Crowe is normally your fail-proof actor, and he does try his best, but even he sings as if simultaneously reading the future reviews that will come slamming on to his head after the movie comes out. There are moments where his gaze seems faintly apologetic - you can almost see his brain scroll reading, "Damn those iron-clad Hollywood contracts, I knew this was a bad idea!"  He's working so hard on getting.the.notes.right, that we don't even get the pleasure of seeing his facial expressions change, much less portray the relentless abiding-by-the-letter-of-the-law stigma of Javert.Now Anne Hatthaway is practically hallowed ground, upon which we dare not tread. But tread we must... or plod, or trample... heck, let's just pull out the backhoe and tear out the whole plot. Anne, in this role, is reminiscent of the community theater diva who thinks she's so amazing that she has to stay in character 24/7, and misses the point that it's not all about her (the actress) every time she's on stage... that there's a bigger story to tell than her own overly-acted pitiful drama that lasts only long enough for you to ponder how she went from "innocent sister" to "lovely lady" with a haircut and a lost tooth. I cannot deny that she's got fairly functional pipes (compared to her co-stars...which is like saying Brad Pitt is an excellent actor because his co-star is Kristen Stewart), but seriously, I don't want to actually SEE them. And while I could lament about the mind-numbing choice of the Academy to honor her with an Oscar, I stopped being shocked by them back when Sandra Bullock won for Blind Side and Kiera Knightly was nominated for P&P.; Clearly the highly acclaimed board is made up of E! retirees... or a million monkeys at a million Oscar ballot stations...In case you think I'm unwittingly bashing right and left out of pure spite, let me hit the two high notes before it plunges back down again: The Thenardiers and the Revolution Chorus.The Thenardiers = absolute perfection. Helena Bonham Carter and Sasha Baron Cohen (it's probably the matching last names) are absolutely the only actors to mesh acting talent, musical chops and the completely necessary, "I don't care if you like me or not" attitude so lacking in the rest of the cast. Sascha's deliciously over-the-top, hilariously disgusting, pick-pocketing rendition of Mr. Thenardier is spot-on, and Helena is the Victor to his Hugo. Her money-fetish flirting is only rivaled by her split-second switch to evil faces at those who would get in her way. I have read that some think she was too tame, too bland... but that is the problem with this whole movie. Subtleties are what bring about the richness of character. If you have to have every fleeting emotion blown up in lights for you to get it, well... then... go back and watch I Dreamed A Dream to your heart's content.The Revolution Chorus (aka all the people who SHOULD have had the leads) were so SO good. Painfully good. It was hard to understand how the director could have got it so right for those few, short scenes and so very wrong for nearly every other. Yes, I actually teared up during Red and Black... mostly mourning what the movie could have, should have been! *moment of silence please*I suppose I cannot forget to mention the younger actors who had a much easier time actually acting while singing. This came as a welcome respite... but only in the sense that a starved person relishes stale bread crusts. When you've been suffering so long, you'll take what you can get.Eddie Redmayne is probably the best of the bunch, and if you can get past him singing like he's got a small colony of frogs living in his throat you just might be able to appreciate his capability. Amanda Seyfried is hard to diss for her portrayal of Cossette. There was so little developing of her character that the actress had no time to let her talent shine and so all I could do was hope to goodness her out-of-control vibrato didn't send her spinning across the room. Samantha Barks is inexplicably the lone stage transplant, the Broadway aura seeping from her pores in every bland camera close-up. Yes, sure, she stands the test of the unforgiving choice to do live singing, but earns a bright red F when it comes to the unforgiving lack of distance she is usually afforded with her audience. She gives us no insight into why she loves Marius, why she would be willing to protect his love for Cossette, how on earth she turned out so normal being raised by the Thernardiers, why she had to dress like a man to fight, why she kept the love letter when she'd already taken Marius to the girl and why-oh-why her mascara didn't run when she sings in the rain! Her dimples are adorable, though.Of course, we must give credit where credit is due: The King's Speech. To be clear, the only reason Tom Hooper was allowed so MANY missteps in the painful, torturous destruction of a classic is the sainthood he earned in his flawless making of the rightfully acclaimed King's Speech film. But come ON, people. Just as we should have given Peter Jackson a hearty pat on the back after LOTR and then a hearty pat on the backpack as we sent him packing after the horror show King Kong, so must our treatment be of Mr. Hooper.I absolutely commend and SUPPORT the idea of live singing! As the cast explains, it is hard to decide how you will react in a studio months before you actually shoot the scene, which can lead to some of the robotic or slightly "off" moments we've seen in other blockbuster musicals (The Music Man, and even moments of Phantom of the Opera). But IF you will make this bold choice, you absolutely MUST compensate with TRAINED and GLORIOUS voices! Besides the fact that this heavenly score deserves only the most angelic voices our planet can produce, if you are going to slow down the action and, in essence, put the movie on pause for every musical number (98.2% of the movie), in order for your cast to be able to perform, you had better make those notes goose bump-worthy good. Instead, it feels like any momentum gained by the non-vocal parts of the score come to a screeching halt when a cast member puts to use his or her unassisted vocal chords and begins wandering around an obvious rolling camera, allowing us to scrutinize every painful note they eject.But truly, the greatest travesty of all is the disservice to the story, though I admit I have not read the book. It is a beautiful story of a man redeemed, a woman restored, a girl rescued, a villain drowned, true love... and the French Revolution. Oh, yes, that IS the major point around which the whole end of the narrative turns did you not notice? Considering that the startup of the rebellion at Le Marquis's funeral looks more like a flash mob than a revolution, that the only real fighting we actually see is when a cute little boy gets shot for apparently no good reason, that the empty tables and chairs are only tragic when you understand the cost, and that the final battle is to be waged between dead people and... no one... you probably didn't.Of course, you can't deny that the music in itself is inspiring, and they really did pull out the stops for the big numbers, and you almost... almost... get as excited as Anne Hatthaway at the final number... okay, scratch that, NO ONE gets as excited as Anne Hatthaway, but truly, the end does make you want to clap, to cheer, if only because you've finally finished this train-wreck on reels. And to top it all off, they even get you writhing at the credits... when you just realize you've watched Colm Wilkinson throughout the whole movie and were gypped of his phenomenal voice soaring through the flawless score!So, Epic? Well, to use another over-used idiom of the times... it's certainly an epic FAIL!

reviewText: I loved the Uma Thurman version. I am also a fan of the stars of this film. I was just not overjoyed to see them all together. Many of the songs worked magnificently. There was a lot of song dialouge that didn't work as well. I felt this should have been a musical rather than an opera. I was surprised at how well the actors could hold their notes, like a professional, yet not sound as well on simpler tunes. There are also professional singers who can act (not 50 Cent). Personally I would have cast them.How is it all these Frenchmen have British accents? The music enhances the already rolling coaster ride of emotion of the saga, making the highs higher and lows lower. There has been almost a void of decent musicals in the motion picture industry since the 1960's. This one fills the void with a great story and cinematography. You are hooked on the film by a brilliant opening scene with Jackman surprising the bejesus out of me with his singing and Crowe does not.As a musical, I won't rush out and buy the sound track. Looks good on the big screen. But seriously, 5 stars? Perhaps the most amazing thing is that Russell Crowe, who can't carry a tune in a bucket, got a major starring role in a musical. Don't look for that to happen again.Parental Guide: No f-bombs or nudity. Brief sex scene.

reviewText: It is a fairly accepted story that when the sculptor, Auguste Rodin wanted to sculpt Victor Hugo, Hugo agreed, but demanded Rodin come to his house, and he refused to pose for him. This prompted Rodin to frantically sketch the poet and attempt to capture his essence. This interpretation of Victor Hugo worked out and resulted in some famous sketches, busts and sculptures. It also worked out in 1985 when Claude-Michel Schönberg interpreted Hugo's masterpiece Les Misérables into a global musical sensation. Now, as 2012 draws to a close, another interpretation of Hugo's Les Misérables has been released. Director Tom Hooper follows his best picture Oscar winning film The Kings Speech with the first ever film adaptation of the 1985 musical Les Misérables. Unfortunately, Tom Hooper is no Rodin.Les Misérables (never to be referred to as "Lay Miz" in this review) is set during the French Revolution and follows the trials of ex-prisoner Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman) over a seventeen year period. During that time, Valjean experiences the endurance and integrity of the human spirit as he relentlessly sacrifices his wellbeing for the good of his adopted daughter, Cosette (Amanda Seyfried). Much of Hugo's original Romantic vision is simplified both for stage and for screen. All versions, however, do condemn the corruption of society as its technological advances inspire greed that leads to abuse of the working class, desperation, increases in criminal activity, and a justifiable uprising. Most evocative of this progression of devastation is the story of Fantine (Anne Hathaway), who when fired from her low-paying factory job is forced to sell her teeth, hair, and body to support her daughter. Hathaway has received praise and criticism for her performance as Fantine. However, the fact remains that while not a traditional Broadway-style singer, what Hathaway lacks in technical singing ability, she more than makes up for in emotional presence. Her rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream" is heartbreaking and touching.While Hathaway performs her role very well, there truly is not enough here to warrant too much attention. Hugh Jackman, on the other hand, turns out a career defining performance that alone makes Les Misérables worth the price of admission. This is Jackman's movie in every single way. Les Misérables is a "sung-through" musical, which means there is no spoken dialogue; all conversations and speeches are sung. This can prove a challenge for many actors, yet Jackman accomplishes this task expertly with every bit of rawness necessary. Jackman is so good in fact, that he makes it easier to overlook the film's two most glaring faults: its direction and Russell Crowe.Tom Hooper has directed a very standard looking and staged feeling musical here. His actors save the film, which in essence is stylistically a spliced together collection of absurdly close-up one shots that go on for several minutes without cutting. To call this minimalism would be vastly understating it. While it can be argued that more aggressive direction may compete with the actors' performances, it is impossible to look back on the film after viewing it and not feel like an opportunity was missed to make it something more. He does offer a glimpse of creativity with the film's opening scene as well as his staging of the comic relief number, "Master of the House," expertly casting Sasha Baron Cohen as Thenardier and Helena Bonhem Carter as his wife.Additionally, Russell Crowe, who plays Inspector Javert, simply can not hold his own as the film's second lead. It is painstakingly obvious how hard he is trying, and this perceptibility is deeply distracting. Crowe does not ruin the film, however since the heart wrenching story and incredible music make up for much of the film's shortcomings. "One Day More" is arguably the film's most powerful song, and it is sure to stick with audience members well after the credits roll. At the end of the day, Les Misérables is mostly effective, especially to original fans of the musical. Nevertheless, it is mostly an underwhelming film, with occasional glimmers of substance, all of which are a consequence of Hugh Jackman's powerhouse performance. B-Read more reviews at [...]

reviewText: A brilliant film version of an excellent musical, it really tugs on your heart strings, and makes you want to sing-along to the glorious songs. Great acting in the midst of the singing, by the way. Russell Crowe may not be the best singer in the world, but he does try his best, and he does act with the conviction and then the uncertainty of Javert. Jean Valjean, as played by Hugh Jackman, ages gracefully throughout the movie, becoming a noble man, and Anne Hathaway is great as Fantine. The Thenardier couple, played by Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter, are the right comedic notes necessary to sustain interest in the movie, and Eddie Redmayne as Marius and the rest of his revolutionary friends are absolutely tragic/brilliant, not to mention Eponine, wonderfully portrayed by Samantha Barks. A great movie version, despite the changes, and the close-ups.

reviewText: I thought it was time I put in my two cents on this, the movie version of Les Miserables. I have seen the play four times.Once in LA, once in Seattle, and twice in Florida and I must say each time was a thrilling experience. Having said that, my wife and I were really looking forward to the movie version.To be honest after seeing the stage show ,which was consistant each time I don't think I would have ever considered Hugh Jackman for the part of Jean Valjean but I must say he suprised ,delighted, and hit it out of the park for both of us. Another stellar performance was Anne Hathaway's Fantine and her rendition of I dreamed a dream. It was a stunner. Of all the times I have seen the show , nothing came close to her heart breaking performance .She brought me to tears.There were some changes and omissions but all in all the spirit, grandur,and the incredible music was there. Of course some things were better than others for instance,Helena Bonham Carter & Sacha Baron Cohen's Master of the House was just adequate but was a highlight in the show for comic relief. Here is my one rub. Les Miserables is not a musical, it is an opera, the difference is ,a musical has both spoken words and singing where an opera is singing only. When you see an opera you expect to have all actors with great singing voices. That brings me to Russell Crowe who plays Javert a main figure in both the play and movie. In the play Javert was powerful in both stature and voice . however, in Crowe's performance ,the stature was there but the voice was not and that was a bit of a disappointment thus, removing one star from my rating .Bottom line, it is a great movie experience.

reviewText: This is really a captivating rendition of the show and I found so much of it very moving.  Russell Crowe did his stalwart best with Javert, but in truth his singing is not even up to snuff for a high school musical, let alone a major film production of such a great stage work.  I admire him because it's clear he really worked hard to make this as good as could be, but the audience should not have to capitulate to such a poor casting choice.  A unknown with a singer's voice would have been a better choice.  Anne Hathaway and Hugh Jackman were truly impressive, but I can't fight the urge to root out the person who coached their vocal preparation, and urge them to take up another career.  Properly coached these two could have won complete and utter acclaim for these roles.  Some of the sounds Hugh Jackman made absolutely thrilled me, but also so many badly placed sounds....so many vowels pinched....so many great musical phrase turned into kitschy singing because he was not prepared well for this.  The ensemble pieces were brilliant and the choral sound was thrilling.If only the performance overall could have been on a par with Thénardier and Madame Thénardier and conveyed the outstanding singing done on roles of Cosette, Epinone, & Marius this review would be five stars.

reviewText: I would venture to say most American movie-goers have never had the opportunity to see a Broadway musical. Why? Opportunity, desire, you choose. And because musicals are a relative scarcity in the multiplex these days, people aren't used to live action musicals of any kind. Many are probably unaware there are different kinds of musicals. "Chicago", "The Producers", "Mamma Mia" and "Moulin Rouge" are the most common form of musicals. Actors speak dialogue and the story moves forward as most films do, but they frequently stop and break out into a song and dance, delivering a musical number that should help move the story forward. But there are also `operatic musicals', productions in which virtually every word is sung and the musical numbers are still there, but less defined. "Phantom of the Opera" and "Les Miserables" are examples of this type of musical.I know a lot of people who would rather have their toenails pulled out with pliers than to sit through a movie musical. These same people detest `operatic musicals' because they never get a break from the music and singing.If you are one of these people, you will not like "Les Mis". But if a musical is made well, it can really transport you, enveloping all of your senses. And "Les Mis" is made very well; a highly emotional, very satisfying adaptation of one of the most successful, longest running musicals in history.The story is very familiar. Jean Valjean (Hugh Jackman, calling on his Broadway skills) is imprisoned for stealing bread to feed a sick family member. Many years later, he is released on probation by Javert (Russell Crowe) who promises to keep an eye on the criminal, watching for any mistake, ready to jail him in an instant. Flash forward a few years and Valjean is now living under another identity as the owner of a factory making rosary beads. A successful man, he is surprised when Javert shows up in the small town. Javert seems to recognize Valjean, but can't place him. Nervous, Valjean ignores the pleas of Fantine (Anne Hathaway), one of the factory workers trying to evade the lecherous foreman. Fantine is fired and falls of hard times, very hard times. Eventually Valjean realizes what has happened and pledges to her that he will find her daughter and care for her. Javert also realizes who Valjean is and is hot on his heels. Valjean finds Fantine's daughter, Cosette in the care of the Thenardiers (Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter), dubious inn-keepers constantly looking for more money. Flash forward a few years and Valjean and Cosette (Amanda Seyfried) are back in Paris when Marius (Eddie Redmayne) spots the young lady and instantly falls in love. Marius is a very involved in the student movement and will soon help start the French Revolution. Valjean, Javert and Cosette will all become involved in the event that will change the history of France.Directed by Tom Hooper ("The King's Speech"), "Les Mis" is a passionate, rousing, extremely emotional and ultimately uneven experience. It is highly satisfying, but because so much of the film is so good, the parts that aren't are even more egregious and annoying.Hugh Jackman has been spending a lot of time performing on Broadway, shifting back and forth between stage and screen. He clearly has the chops to handle a musical and does a great job as Prisoner 24601. He goes through a lot, experiences a lot and changes a lot throughout the course of the story. This may be one of the biggest understatements ever, but to go into too much detail would spoil some of the surprise for people unfamiliar with the story. Let's just say he faces many obstacles and challenges.But as Valjean climbs each mountain and faces each challenge, you always get a feeling for his inner conscience. Jackman subtly shows us that even when Valjean is doing something wrong, he is at great pains when doing it. And he always tries to do something to compensate for the past error.Russell Crowe is another matter entirely. He doesn't have the skill or chops to carry the musical part of his role as Javert, the extremely tenacious gendarme. Everything he sings sounds the same which is problematic because he has to show us the emotions his character is living through. He pretty much glares at people throughout the film, rarely giving us insight into his character.Crowe deserves a lot of credit for going out of his comfort zone, but the filmmakers should have stayed away from the star's pull and sought out a performer who could do the role justice.Remember when Anne Hathaway and James Franco hosted the Oscars? There seemed to be two general thoughts about their work; 1. James Franco looked uncomfortable and uneasy throughout most of the show and 2. Surprise that Anne Hathaway could sing. Her performance as Fantine, the single mother working in a factory to earn money for her child, erases the question mark and any doubt. Anne Hathaway CAN sing.I have only seen the musical performed live once and didn't remember that her big moment came so early in the story, but the moment she appears on screen, get your hankies out. Her role is tragic and moving and as she is singing "I Dream a Dream", you can see the pain and emotion in her face and hear it in every word she utters. Her character's life ultimately steers Jean Valjean towards his destiny, so it makes sense and needs to happen pretty early to drive the rest of the story.Amanda Seyfried (who was also in "Mamma Mia"), Eddie Redmayne, who plays her true love, Samantha Banks who plays Eponine and Aaron Tveit who plays Enjorlas are all good, but when you consider the power of Hathaway's performance and the bravado of Jackman's, these younger actors pale in comparison. They all play a part in sparking the French Revolution, which closes the film.Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter play the Thernadiers, shady inn-keepers who seem included to provide a bit of comic relief. Normally, this type of thing wouldn't work very well, but their big song "Master of the House" is one of the most memorable and helps to compensate for the obvious nature of their characters.Watching a film musical is a very different thing from watching the same musical performed on stage. It should be a different thing. When you are watching a play, you are looking at the entire stage and as characters move around, your attention is directed to them. As they move back and forth, your eye follows them. Sometimes, you may be watching a scene between two characters at opposite sides of the stage. But the stage is always there and your eye is always moving. When you watch a filmed version of the same play, the filmmakers direct your attention to the focused performer with camera movement, editing, transitions and more. Your eye will process less because the filmmakers have already done this for you. Naturally, watching a live play is to a movie what reading a book is to watching a film adaptation of that book. When you read a book, your mind processes a lot of information and paints pictures for you, guiding you through the story. Sometimes, reading a scary story is a lot more effective than watching a horror story because the images your mind conjures are a lot scarier (and real to you) than what the filmmakers can come up with. Watching a live play is a very different thing because you have to decide where to look, what to concentrate on. You can also look at the whole picture.In "Les Miserables", Tom Hooper gives us an intimate view of the story. "Les Mis" isn't known for great choreography anyway, so Hooper smartly concentrates on the actors as they perform.He has also gone one step further; the actors sing live throughout the film. In most musicals, the singers record the songs in a studio and then perform the roles to a playback of the song. Watching "Les Mis" is a very different experience. You can see the words coming out of the actor's mouths, feel their power, and it also makes the performances more intimate and meaningful."Les Miserables" is an emotional, moving experience. And a fitting adaptation of one of the longest running musicals in history. It has some problems, but all-in-all, this is one of the most satisfying films of the year.

reviewText: Does the five star here mean "I love it"?  No, but I can't deny the fantastic story, the technical merits, and the stellar emotionally wrenching acting (Hathaway and Jackman, I'm looking at you).  This is simply a fantastic filmic translation of the play.  Whether you love it or not this is very close to a must watch (for adults at least).  And while I can't say I'm a fan of the musical genre in general there are some very moving, memorable numbers here.  The film will stay with you.

reviewText: I must have seen the musical about 5 times, and each time I watched I enjoyed like the first time. Then came the movie version. At the start I said to my self, its OK if Jean Valjean and any other characters in the movie have no voices as long as they the acting is great, which was, but that killed the intention of being one of the greatest musicals of all times. If I hadn't seen the stage production with fabulous voices and live music, I would probably have given 5 stars. Here are the major issues that I had.1. The make up was over done to create more horrors of the street life.2. 90% of the movie is gloomy, and sad, even when Mario meets Cosette for the first time. The scene should have been lighten with positive colors and emotions, common, its love, give us some light.3. The director missed a lot of details, especially in the song Master of the house.4. Master of the house and his wife wrong casting, they are the best looking actors in the movie, LOL. They should have missing teeth or whatever. Sasha Cohen, did not fit his role not in acting or singing. In stage production this scene is one of the main attraction5. "Bring him home" song, which always gives me chills and crowd's standing ovation on stage was destroyed.6. I could hardly hear the orchestra, because the voices were to weak. The music is very powerful and should have been played this way.I could go on, but will stop right there, in my opinion the movie Phantom was much better interpretation than The Miserables, in spite that Phantom had to compete with Michael Crawford.Over all, it was not bad, but I could only watch it once. And if the musical stage production will ever be back in town, I would go and see it again.

reviewText: I was wondering how they would make a film musical of Les Miserables. I thought the movie was okay, but it lacks the emotional depth, drama, and suspense of a traditional film. I think the audience had to have a good understanding of the original story in order to really understand the movie. Otherwise, it's just some former convict being chased by a french policeman, along the way he gains a child to take care of, she grows up, he saves her groom, the policeman and convict die, the end.I think musical is an interesting vehicle for a story that has been interpreted many times over the years. However, I prefer the traditional story. I understand the characters weren't supposed to sing very well (in keeping with their characters) but this means there isn't any amazing music in the movie.Anne Hathaway played Fantine superbly, and sang well. I liked Helen Bonham Carter and Sasha Cohen as the innkeepers. The child who plays Cosette is rather ethereal and haunting, but only appeared briefly. Amanda Seyfried and Russell Crowe sing terribly!The musical stripped the story down to a simple storyline...the full breadth of the story was taken away! The Paris Rebellion part was ridiculous. As the film went on, it just got more drawn out, tedious, boring, and the singing started to get wearing to listen to.

reviewText: The plot for Les Miserables is a complex one, so I will only summarize a little bit. Jean Valjean served 19 years in jail and then sheds his identity to escape his criminal past during during the aftermath of the French Revolution. There is so much more that the film is about, but that's the gist of it. I was extremely excited to see this film. I have been listening to the original cast soundtrack since forever with my family and I've seen the stage play about 5 times. I know every lyric and every musical line. I really didn't expect to see or feel anything different because I am so familiar with the source material. I was proven wonderfully wrong. This film made the music and story fresh and new to me.The look of the film is realistic and shows what the musical tends to gloss over: the poor, the dirt, the awful living conditions, and the reality of living in France after the French Revolution. The entire story is put into harsh perspective and put me on the edge of tears right from the beginning because of the realistic pain and suffering of the characters. The way Jean Valjean is treated after serving his time in jail and the conditions Fantine is subjected to after losing her job. The whole film has a raw quality that puts it in stark contrast to the stage play. Despite the lyrics and the makeup on stage, the audience doesn't feel the depression and plight of the poor being portrayed. Everything is put into perspective. The barricade is rather slap dash and small because that's what poor people in France would have been able to spare for it as opposed to the huge construct in the play. The lovely ladies look much more dirty and tired with grotesquely painted faces that inspire more pity than desire. Valjean lived in a constant state of paranoia, ready to flee at any moment and unable to make any lasting ties. I loved that the film took the familiar setting and costumes of the play and brought them into reality.The rawness of the film also extends to the singing, which is probably the most controversial issue. I personally loved the singing and acting. The focus isn't to just sound like a great singer or even to perform the songs flawlessly, but to convey the emotions of the character. These unpolished performances are oftentimes my favorite renditions of the songs over studio versions. The broadway versions are well sung, but don't have the right emotional impact and seem to be too concerned with hitting everything perfectly. Anne Hathaway as Fantine in particular performed phenomenally. Her rendition of I Dreamed a Dream moved me to tears when I never thought much of the song before. This portrayal of raw emotion suddenly made this song one of my favorites. Eddie Redmayne as Marius also greatly impressed me, possessing the most wonderful voice out of the whole cast. I had always dismissed him as the annoying, flat Romeo of the play that just mooned over Juliet/Cosette. The film fleshed out some of his backstory and made him a real, likable character with more aspirations and motivations than just his instalove relationship. His performance of Empty Chairs at Empty Tables is among my favorites and I don't think the emotion of that scene has ever been translated that well before. The other actors are good as well, but these two really stood out to me as talented actors that changed my perspective on their characters and songs.As with any adaptation, the plot and order of events is slightly changed and, for the most part, are improvements to the story. With the play, I was confused as to the logistics of how Valjean escaped with little Cosette and evaded Javert for so long. The film clarifies this and fills in the gaps that were previously left out. Some of the songs were shuffled around a little bit, but the changed order makes more sense to me. Having Lovely Ladies before I Dreamed a Dream makes more sense plotwise and provides the second song with much more emotional impact because Fantine had already hit rock bottom. I appreciated the expansion of Marius' backstory and how he turned his back on his wealthy family to fight for what he felt was right. It showed much more strength and dedication than just the superficial relationship between him and Cosette.The problems I have with the movie are pretty minor. I hate that a lot of the cinematography during the singing portions is super close up on the actors' faces. I can see a few shots like this for emotional impact, but in every single song is a little excessive. The other annoyance is the shortening or omission of important songs. A Little Fall of Rain is a very important and I was shocked to see that it was shortened. The song Turning was practically taken out altogether save for the very beginning of it. The new song Suddenly didn't really have any impact on the film and I thought it was unneeded when other, better songs were cut short. These are relatively small problems and I felt the film was very successful and effective.Les Miserables is the best film adaptation of the play I could have asked for. The performances are nothing short of amazing. (Yes, even Russell Crowe was good in his restrained version of Javert.) I have only seen the film once on Christmas and I plan to see it again soon. I would highly recommend it to fans of musicals that don't mind stripped down, imperfect renditions of these songs.
summary: A realistic and raw reimagining of the Broadway show

reviewText: The packaging and contents were perfect.  But a STRONG warning for those who had seen Les Mis either on stage in New York City or own the 10th and 25th Anniversary videos.  That is because only they will know the potential of Les Mis.  This is a movie so Hollywood gets involved where it shouldn't, actors singing instead of singers acting.  The "Javert" (s) on stage and in the two anniversary videos were fantastic.  In the movie he was okay.  Jean Valjean on stage in New York, Colm Wilkinson, played the priest in the movie.  Jean Valjean in the movie was okay.  Fantine's acting was well done.  But the singing never came close to broadway and therefore very disappointing.  M. Thenardier, the Inn Keeper, was a sleeze, not smart like the one on stage.  And the director having Santa Claus with a prostitute in the Inn was unforgiving . . . wasn't needed and political correct, which too often we can expect from the elites in Hollywood.  In the director's explanation cut on the video, he said Marius and Cosette were picked because they had looked like relatives in Victor's day.  What, in a musical you look for people with faces from old paintings instead of their singing?  Marius could sing but looked too young for the part.  And Cosette, played by the lead from Mama Mia the ABBA movie, just ruined it for us with her voice not even close to the wonderful Cosettes on stage.  In fact it has come to the point we can no longer watch the movie, knowing what Cosette can really sound like.  And the director, along with the actor who played Jean Valjean, said in the cut Les Mis reminded them of . . . wait for it . . . OWS.  What?!  Did they not know OWS was lead by communists in the crowd on the streets against businesses and banks in New York City?  OWS wasn't about abuses of society like in Les Mis. OWS didn't like successful people making money, this in a society overflowing with entitlement programs not exactly the world of Les. Mis.  By the way, the 10th Anniversary is only on DVD, but has an excellent ending with all the Jean Valjeans on stage that have played that part around the world. The 25th Anniversary is on Blu Ray and also excellent. As a final remark, the backgrounds in the movie were truly outstanding.  It's sad the quality of the singing didn't match.  Again, the music for Les Mis is for professional singers who can act, not popular actors who can sing.

reviewText: A 2012 USA/UK production "Les Misérables" has lots of songs and rhymes, but has little sense of rhythm and flow. With fine production design and powerful performances from some players (if not all), the film adaptation of the Broadway musical based on the Victor Hugo classic novel is not boring, but the pace is too fast, even rushed, while the film is always striving to be emotional.You know this is a famous story about Jean Valjean, a man who stole a loaf of bread for his sister's children, the story that was made into a movie in 1998 with Liam Neeson as Valjean, and a TV mini-series with Gérard Depardieu in 2002. Did I find something new and original in this new version, except the great music, of course? Not much.There is one thing I couldn't understand about the latest version of "Les Misérables." Director Tom Hooper of "The King's Speech" fame somehow decided every single line had to be sung. Yes, I know this is a musical and I haven't seen the stage, but on screen it just doesn't work.Finally, a few words about the cast of "Les Misérables." The cast is impressive, but some of the players' performances are not. I don't name names. Hugh Jackman is very good. I only add that among the many well-known stars, Samantha Barks impressed me most as tragic Éponine, the only character I cared. She is the real star of the film to me.

reviewText: the movie for the most part is straight out from the famous author' novel, where nothing is highly expected in terms of plot or denouement.  However, the movie is expected to deliver characters as described in the book, and in this regard, the movie fails to impress; i.e. most acting is subdued by the singing portion assigned to each actor. That is, the musical aspect of the motion drama dominates the viewing yet, IMO, is not high quality to your ears in the same level as that provided by the likes of Andrew Lloyd Weber music.  The singing of the actors can be at most described as mediocre or at best acceptable.  Maybe, this singing is most acceptable in the performing by "Cosette", which is not much.  The special effect and spectacular (Paris & costumes) part of the motion picture would be commendable to many if the movie is presented at a theather ambiance.  In all, the singing is not making this movie (e.g. streamed into your Home Tv) highly enjoyable when the viewer is not unfamiliar with Victor Hugo's novel.  For someone who'd seen many versions of Les Miserables, any four-star rating would be somewhat unjustified, IMO.

reviewText: This is a beautifully done movie that truly does justice to the epic stage play. The scenery is both beautifully understated (the convent scenes) and appropriately depressing (the opening slave scene, the dark, dirty brothels). The entire mood of the movie is perfectly appropriate and what you want to see; muted colors, grimy streets, dirty disheveled commoners. The music is glorious.Hugh Jackman is marvelous! Who knew he could ever look so un-handsome and sexy? Forget Wolverine, this guy is aged, weathered, gaunt, and scruffy. Jackman is not a natural tenor, and his voice strains towards the higher notes of his songs, but he hits them. A former musical actor, he's well suited to a singing role. Russell Crowe has also left his sexy young self behind, and is now the middle aged, beefy Javert, and he plays the role elegantly. However, his singing is mediocre at best. He hits the notes, but his voice is very "chesty" and not too pleasant to listen to. I'm not a big fan of Anne Hathaway, but she gave it 110% and she has a beautiful voice. I both liked and disliked her emotional butchering of "I Dreamed A Dream"; it was more realistic in some ways, but I also feel like you should just NEVER undermine that epic song. Amanda Seyfried was a believable Cosette; cute, angelic, innocent, but her quivery chipmunk-like vibrato was almost comical and detracted from her character. Eddie Redmayne as Marius... ughh... Marius is supposed to be handsome! He captures Cossette's heart with one glance. Redmayne is so unbelievable in that role; the guy is UGLY, sorry! Of course H.B. Carter has to make an appearance (seriously, she's like an STD, she's everywhere and not really wanted) as the wife of the innkeeper we all love to hate. I thought their scenes were a bit too corny. While they provide the comic relief in an otherwise dreary story, it's supposed to be understated and brief, not an obnoxious circus act, and I was disappointed in their scenes. I was also delighted to see Colm Wilkinson as the Bishop, as he played Valjean back in the 80's! What fun that must have been for him, to play opposite "his" role in the movie. Lastly, Samantha Barks as Eponine was a natural choice, she's played the role on stage and does a lovely job.Note To Parents* While this film has a PG13 rating, there is some graphic violence as well as two very graphic sex scenes that honestly shocked me, as I was in the theater with my friend and her two daughters. It was like WHOOPS, didn't mean for you girls to see that! So just be forewarned.So overall, LOVED IT, beautifully done, with just a few critiques, mainly on the casting. Enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: What can I saw about this movie?  I have seen the broadway musical twice.  I have watched the Les Mis concert presentations (10th and 25th anniversaries) which include amazing singing but leaves out the acting.  I have watched about three different non-musical dramatic movie presentations.For hard-core broadway buffs, this movie will not satisfy.  The singing is not perfect, there is a raw element to the  singing and the tempo changes within songs based on the actor's portrayal.  As a straight musical, the lack of perfection can be a distraction from songs that theatre buffs know by heart and expect to hear sung brilliantly.But looking beyond perfection, this movie adaptation of the musical brings to life elements that cannot be placed in the live theatre.  A lot of close-ups, showing dirty, scarrred, and uglified faces of the people that must have been in the streets of 19th century France.  There is a raw grittiness to the scenes... nothing is pretty, even Anne Hathaway comes across as emaciated and steadily declines in appearance as her hair is roughly chopped off and she has  teeth pulled for a few francs.  Hugh Jackman's appearance is startling.  The theatre cannot do justice to the rough appearance of  early Valjean that Jackman portrays.The singing is a huge part of this movie, and it ranges from spectacular to passable.  I have read critics who panned Crowe's singing, and although he is certainly not a match for some of theatre's great presentations of Javert, Crowe sings at least decently.  What he lacks in singing he makes up for in his presentation and acting, and all in all I thought he made a fine Javert.I saw this on Christmas day this year and now am waiting impatiently for the DVD.
summary: Finally - the musical comes to the movies

reviewText: Loved the opening scene. It took a further ninety minutes for me to be fully engaged in Les Miserables. The last hour really is very affecting. Revolution has that effect on me.Never read the book or seen the stage production. Strange thing is after having seen the film I can understand how the show was so successful. It's a great date show. An old fashioned weepy. I mean we're talking deep down sad here!It is an opera not a musical. A lot of recitative and only two show-stopping arias. The Table and Chair lyric hit the spot for me even if musically tame.Comic relief was via the triple barrelled twosome of Sasha Baron Cohen and the ever delicious Helena Bonham Carter who returns to the chesty slut role similar to Fight Club. And the Artful Dodger returns! Complete with over-cooked cockney (London) accent but no walking off into the sunset ending for the little scallywag.What more can I say? When it comes to hit London West End stage musicals the 1960s had Oliver! The 1970s had The Rocky Horror Show, the 1980s had Les Mis. I often wondered why an affluent society would flock to see this tale of oppression and despair. But that rousing ending must have been great on stage. Individuals singing together. But it's a four star movie at best. One gorgeous hit song which should have been reprieved later in the film. A lot of close-ups for the singing but no dancing if my memory serves me right.It was a full-house for my cinema viewing in Liverpool. A few ladies managed a ripple of applause at the end. I recall the massive tingle up my spine when 'I dreamed a dream...' was heard.

reviewText: I've watched theater productions of Les Mis, watched screen adaptations, and read the book several times over, and this cinematic adaptation ranks highly on my list of adaptations. As a musical film, it is well put-together, utilizing a stellar cast who delivers compelling performances in both acting and singing, excellent set-up of scenes, credible costumes and sets making the period and setting of 19th century France come alive, and spectacular effects.I read some critical reviews which found the singing of the cast members to be less than impressive. I agree only with regards to three characters - Russell Crowe's Inspector Javert, and Sacha Baron Cohen and Helena Bonham Carter as the Thenardiers. Crowe's emoting as Javert was well done with his facial expressions credibly portraying his resolute nature and steadfast obsession in hunting Jean Valjean, but his singing just wasn't up to par although to be fair some of his songs were incredibly difficult. I felt an actor who had more of an established singingbackground would have fared much better in this role. The Thenardiers' portrayal did not sit well with me either - Cohen's and Helena Bonham Carter's singing performances were just plain awful.Now that I've got the criticisms out of the way, let me comment on the positives. Hugh Jackman blew me away with his performance - I avoided comparing his performance to the Broadway productions because they are two entirely different mediums. These actors had to sing live on set and Jackman's background in singing with his strong, commanding voice as well as his experience as an actor really served him well in the challenging role of lead character Jean Valjean. There were scenes where Valjean displays his inner conflict - the beginning when he is railing against the injustice of his imprisonment, the scene where he is praying and reflecting on the priest's kindness to him and how he experiences this epiphany of how to transform his life, later still when he has embraced a new identity and is prospering as the Mayor of a city and his turmoil when he finds Javert has been dispatched to work in his city, so much more, and all done with impeccable finesse. Even when his voice at times breaks during a performance, I found it compelling because this is how one would expect it to be in real life - emotions impacting one's voice (not that people go through life singing their emotions out all the time). It was heartbreaking, 'real', and did not feel put on at all. Jackman delivers an Oscar worthy performance and I hope he gets it.Fantine as portrayed by the beautiful and talented Anne Hathaway (I grew from a non-fan to a fan - starting from The Devil Wears Prada to the latest Batman and this) just broke my heart. That one song, "I Dreamed A Dream" was so achingly poignant and full of despair - this is a woman brought so low by life's circumstances and filled with despair - as I watched Fantine sing, I could only think, "God, this is how I imagined Fantine when I read the book," so really, what more could be said. Hathaway embodies Fantine - her hopes, dashed dreams, and her despair with heartbreaking clarity.Amanda Seyfried as Cossette was lovely but I would not go so far as to say it was a spectacular performance but my, what a revelation Eddie Redmayne was as Marius. I've been a bit of a fan after watching him in My Week With Marilyn, and he is amazing here as the young revolutionary who is besotted with Cossette. His voice is compelling and his yearning and aching love for Cossette is credibly conveyed by his voice in song.Eponine as played by Samantha Barks was another favorite character who also broke my heart. Her songs, delivered with such sadness and yearning, and those haunting eyes just tugged at the heartstrings. The young actor who plays Gavroche, Daniel Huttlestone, the street urchin and young revolutionary in the making delivered a performance that is memorable for its sincerity and spiritedness.Though the movie is rather long in length at slightly over two and a half hours, I did not feel like the movie dragged at all. Each scene was carefully set up and orchestrated and the songs and dialogue all came together beautifully. When I heard that famous line, "To love someone is to see the face of God", I wept because that scene to me at least embodied what Hugo's work was all about. This is a beautiful cinematic masterpiece and I feel richer for having watched it.
Title: N/A
